Twilight was upon him in seconds, lifting the struggling stallion up with a burst from her horn. Twilight spoke softly and furiously.\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cLesson three. You would do well to remember that so long as I still take breath into this body, House Twinkle lives. And the last time I checked, House Twinkle outranks yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tAnd with that, Twilight released the cowering cadet. She retrieved Grace and fit it back into its holster, and as she did so, she became aware of the tumult of noise around her. Stunned murmurs and the occasional cheer cut through the air as the weary unicorn turned to find Princess Luna. Her mentor nodded softly at her, indicating approval. Twilight could barely do much more than smile once in return before making her tired way back up to the Dining Hall. She had a dinner to finish, after all.\r\n\t\r\n\t<<((*))>>\r\n\t\r\n\tPrincess Luna sat up in her study when the knock resounded at the door. It was late and most ponies were already in bed, but Luna knew who this was. \xe2\x80\x9cEnter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tIn walked a weary Twilight Sparkle. The young mare still sported the aftereffects of her little battle. She had been so focused on filling her belly with some sort of sustenance she had flat out refused to go to the hospital wing to get healed. Studying her student silently, Luna decided that it really made Twilight look the part. The Lunar Princess could almost believe that it was the Valkyrie standing there, having just returned from a successful defensive skirmish. Luna mentally shook that image away; there was still a ways to go yet before Twilight was ready for that title and its responsibilities. Luna was the first to speak, already guessing Twilight\xe2\x80\x99s first question.\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cThat was your trial in combat, Twilight. I had told you I wanted to see how proficient you were, and the opportunity presented itself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cBut against three opponents? Most others would have fallen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cBut you did not, which shows you have far greater strength in you than others know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cI almost died, Luna!\xe2\x80\x9d The Lunar Monarch flinched slightly at the raised voice. So this was what was bothering her student. \xe2\x80\x9cIf not for my magic, I would have left this world for good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tLuna composed herself; she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford to show the raw emotion running through her at hearing Twilight so frightened. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd they will be punished accordingly. Dumbbell especially. They were only supposed to defeat you in honorable combat. I had not anticipated them to act so out of hand. It would appear that I made some nobles rather angry, in accepting you as my apprentice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tTwilight huffed. \xe2\x80\x9cYou could say that again.\xe2\x80\x9d She was silent for a moment, before finally shifting slightly. \xe2\x80\x9cI also have a bit of a question.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tThe princess raised a brow. \xe2\x80\x9cOh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I was out there fighting\xe2\x80\xa6 It felt as though I had lost control of my body. I\xe2\x80\x99ve never, ever fought like that before, even against Shining Armor. I knew what to do. How to fight like that. How to keep myself centered. I knew that my odd fighting style would be unpredictable to those unaccustomed to it. Why, Luna? Why do I suddenly have all of this knowledge?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tLuna had to work to keep her face calm. Twilight was advancing along at an almost frightening pace. Her mind raced, scrambling for something, anything, to tell her student. Finally, she spoke. \xe2\x80\x9cLooks like I may have to have a word with Starshard about using the Link to influence you. You\xe2\x80\x99re not going to learn much on your own if she\xe2\x80\x99s helping you too much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tTwilight breathed a slight sigh of relief. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought it was something a little more sinister. Tell her I\xe2\x80\x99d much rather learn things on my own. I\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\xa6 also sorry for raising my voice at you earlier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tLuna inclined her head. \xe2\x80\x9cI feel you were perfectly within your rights to shout at me, Twilight. But, I feel you also learned a valuable lesson tonight, and one that could be very important to your future studies: Never be afraid to involve magic in a fight, even if your opponents do not have any. As you saw tonight, it may save your life. Now. I want you to return to your quarters, and get some sleep. I know you are exhausted, and your training continues tomorrow. While your Link to Starshard was a huge step in your studies of Necromancy, it was also just the beginning. There is quite a bit more for you to learn before you are ready to move on to the next branch of magic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tTwilight tilted her head. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Starshard, anyway? I didn\xe2\x80\x99t even see her at the fight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cI believe she has taken up residence in one of the many unused guest rooms this place has. As to why she did not personally appear, I imagine that her appearance would have been quite jarring-- first of all, because she is undead. Though she might mask some of her nature, there are a few who are bound to pick up on it. Secondly, she does look almost identical to you. That right there would cause even more of a stir. Now, off with you, my faithful student. I have yet to converse with my advisors before I may turn in for the night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tTwilight bid her teacher goodnight and left. Mere moments after her departure, another knock sounded at the door, and in walked Princess Luna\xe2\x80\x99s oldest friends. The Princess smiled.\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cSpitfire,\xe2\x80\x9d Luna greeted warmly. The flaming pegasus flashed her trademark grin in response, before tossing herself carelessly into the chair Twilight had just vacated. \xe2\x80\x9cZecora. Always my eyes and ears, yes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tThe zebra chuckled and answered, \xe2\x80\x9cThe eyes and ears of our Princess we are, EI has our spies wide and far.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cShimmer. The reason many of us are still here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tThe pegasus blushed a little. \xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, Luna. All the Corps does is aid recovery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cWhich is why we are all the more thankful to have you.\xe2\x80\x9d Luna turned to the last newcomer, regarding him with twinkling eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cHalt. Silver Bit got his nose up his ass again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tHalter O\xe2\x80\x99Carrick stepped forward, struggling to hide his grin at his Princess\xe2\x80\x99 foul language. Halt never ever smiled. At least, not in all of the hundreds of years Luna has known him. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course he does. That stupid Sol thinks he\xe2\x80\x99s better than anyone else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cRemind me as to why you\xe2\x80\x99ve not had him locked up, or banished him from Equestria yet?\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire asked.\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s not really done anything wrong. I can\xe2\x80\x99t lock up a pony just because he wishes that Corona Flare had brought about neverending day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tSpitfire snorted, which Luna decided to ignore. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, you know why I\xe2\x80\x99ve called you all here, so lets get this out of the way first, so that we might be able to enjoy a little bit of each other\xe2\x80\x99s company before we have to turn in for the night. Spitfire, you start.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tSpitfire seemed to mull over her next words a bit. \xe2\x80\x9cDash is, hands down, probably the best recruit the Wonderbolt Academy has seen since I graced its halls many many years ago.\xe2\x80\x9d Everypony in the room gave some sort of exclamation. This was high praise, coming from Spitfire. \xe2\x80\x9cThat pegasus does things with her wings I\xe2\x80\x99ve never seen any other pony accomplish. She does exceedingly well with pretty much everything--except her actual classes. While she does get good marks in them, they still bore her. Being such a natural flier means that most of the stuff the instructors are teaching her are nothing new to her. I might end up having to place her in advanced classes, like I was. I\xe2\x80\x99ll have to do it cautiously, to ensure she does not get too cocky, but I would hazard a guess she\xe2\x80\x99ll be a full blown Wonderbolt in a year and a half. Maybe less.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t the normal Wonderbolt training program a total of four years before becoming a full fledged member?\xe2\x80\x9d Shimmer asked.\r\n\t\r\n\tSpitfire nodded. \xe2\x80\x9cIt just goes to show how talented she is, if I think she\xe2\x80\x99ll become a Wonderbolt before I did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tLuna rubbed a hoof over her chin thoughtfully. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is interesting, but definitely a good thing. What about you, Shimmer? How is young Fluttershy coming along?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cDespite being extremely shy of even her own shadow, Fluttershy is already the top of this year\xe2\x80\x99s class. She takes to healing very naturally, and being a Whisperer gives her an even bigger edge. She\xe2\x80\x99s quite interesting to work with when she\xe2\x80\x99s really focused. The other night we had a pegasus come through with a broken wing. At the time, Fluttershy was the only medic in the vicinity, even if she\xe2\x80\x99s still only a trainee. When she beheld the injured pony, her entire demeanor changed. She went from being this timid little pony to being assertive, analyzing the situation and gathering information about the accident. She then proceeded to heal the wing faster, and probably better, than most of our senior medics. She\xe2\x80\x99ll be a useful asset to the team.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Pinkie Pie?\xe2\x80\x9d Luna turned towards Zecora.\r\n\t\r\n\tThe zebra laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Pinkamena is a full blown agent in everything but attitude, but even that does not change her aptitude. She has a complete disregard for what is supposed to be impossible, and because of that, she\xe2\x80\x99ll be an agent who\xe2\x80\x99ll be unstoppable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tSmiling slightly at the shaman\xe2\x80\x99s rhymes, Luna turned towards the last one. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd Applejack?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tHalt frowned slightly. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99ll make a good Equestrian Ranger, no doubt about that. But she has a stubborn pride streak almost a mile long, one that even her brother can barely bring her out of. To be honest, that stubbornness could be a potential boon. It\xe2\x80\x99ll mean she\xe2\x80\x99ll be less likely to give up ground when on the losing side of a battle. However, she is quite honest and follows orders well. She\xe2\x80\x99s also quite strong, even stronger than her brother, and her brother seemed like he was born for this kind of work. I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen her buck a thick tree clean in two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tLuna let out a thoughtful whistle. \xe2\x80\x9cHmm. Well, it seems as though things are shaping up nicely. If we play our cards right, we just might be able to beat Corona Flare once and for all when she returns. On a slightly similar subject, we need to decide to do with those three cadets of yours, Spitfire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cBanish them, for all I care.\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire retorted. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve suspected those three have been up to no good for a while-- bullying other cadets just because they\xe2\x80\x99re some spoiled nobility brats and are in their second year. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve never had any hard evidence before now. However, shortly after their tussle with Miss Sparkle, three other cadets approached me with concerns about their bullying: First Year Rainbow Dash, and Third Years Lightning Dust and Ditzy Doo. Apparently they decided almost killing your student was reason enough to finally report them for their acts at my Academy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps banishment is just what they need. Whether or not it will be permanent, I am not sure\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tSpitfire shrugged. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t matter to me. I also must say, I thought for a moment that your student belonged in the Wonderbolt Academy, and not learning under you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tLuna smiled at that. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I am quite proud of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tHalt shook his shaggy head. \xe2\x80\x9cYou always knew how to pick the strong ones, Luna. Does she know yet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\t\r\n\tLuna was already shaking her head. \xe2\x80\x9cNo. And I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to tell her. Not yet. I will, when she is ready to bear the burden of our mistakes. When she is ready to finally call the other Orphans her friends. But for now, let us forget about the uncertainties of the future, and enjoy each other\xe2\x80\x99s company this night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n", 'epub': None}

2015-02-23 12:03:15,132 - DEBUG - {'version': 1, 'chapter_number': 7, 'fields': ['chapter_text', 'chapter_number', 'parent_chapter_id', 'chapter_html', 'version', 'parent_story_id'], 'chapter_to_insert': {'chapter_text': '//------------------------------//\n// Chapter 7// Story: Valkyrie// by Flicka Ravenhide//------------------------------//\n\n\tIn one of Canterlot Castle\xe2\x80\x99s many private forges, a marshmallow mare was preparing to be hard at work. Her mane lacked its usual coiffer, instead done up in a tight little bun to ensure it would not get in the way. Normally, she wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be here. Not since she\xe2\x80\x99s mastered everything about metalsmithing Princess Luna and her forgemasters could teach her. But her presence here was special. Try as Luna might, the Monarch couldn\'t hope to keep her plans a secret when she came to Rarity, asking the talented mare to work her craft once more. Rarity, of course, had been extremely enthusiastic. Not only would she be able to ply her trade, but she was creating equipment for the new Valkyrie. Armor, to be exact, as well of a couple of other things that could prove useful. Armor that just happened to be the right size for Princess Luna\xe2\x80\x99s own powerful prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9e. Rarity, for her part, knew exactly who it was for. There was only one student of Luna\xe2\x80\x99s who held the actual title of prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9e, after all. It also helped that Rarity still recalled Twilight Sparkle\xe2\x80\x99s exact measurements from a couple of years ago. That mare hadn\xe2\x80\x99t grown all that much since then.\r\n\r\n\tDespite what other ponies might think about Orphans in general, Rarity was not stupid. If Luna was grooming a new Valkyrie, after years and years of not having one, something big was going to happen soon. She didn\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to know what, exactly, and even her slight penchant for gossip wasn\xe2\x80\x99t cause enough for her to wonder. But she could think of no other pony more suited to the title and all it entailed than Twilight. The studious mare didn\xe2\x80\x99t see it yet, but she was leader material. Rarity knew this without a doubt. The rest of their band of Orphans knew it. Its what had caused them to come together to face an uncertain world that disliked them simply for having the ear of the Princess. Twilight might not want to admit it, but they were all friends. Maybe not close friends, true, but it was there. They\xe2\x80\x99ve already been through so much, and even now they were still sticking together as much as possible.\r\n\r\n\tRarity shook those thoughts from her head and once more focused on her movements, prepping her forge for the task ahead. The metal itself had to be extremely thin, almost impossibly so. The only thing the metal part of the armor would be used for was to give shape to the rest of the structure. Naturally, brightsteel was the only reasonable solution; it could be compressed so thin it resembled a piece of paper, yet could still turn aside even the sharpest of weapons. Over the brightsteel was going to be a layer of compressed magic, allowing ease of movement even if the wearer were not used to the heavy weight of the armor. Then, the last layer was going to be amethyst, mined from the Canterlot mines far beneath the castle itself. This amethyst would then have some of the most powerful enhancements any mage could offer placed upon it. In reality, this armor was going to make its wearer a living fortress. It was designed to be light, with full range of movement. The amethyst would then give it a pleasing color and provide some natural protection against magic and weaponry. Then the enchantments and other protections would further offer defensive capabilities. It was, quite easily, the most daunting task Rarity had ever been assigned.\r\n\r\n\tOf course, this really didn\xe2\x80\x99t concern Rarity. She knew what she was doing. Daunting or not, it would be done to perfection. Deciding that she was ready to begin, Rarity picked up the pieces of brightsteel and held them before her, testing their weight with her magic. These were solid nodes, and would serve her well. She placed all three cantaloupe sized pieces into the forge. She would not use all of them, but what she did not use in the crafting of the armor could be used for other things. With a slight flare of magic from her horn, Rarity fed magic into the fire, causing it to burn three times as hot as before. Normally she wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t dare use magic to speed the process, but doing so would cause the brightsteel to become familiar with the touch of magic, preventing the metal from rejecting it later. So long as she was careful, speeding the process wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mar her work. After several moments and when the metal was a cherry red, Rarity used her tongs to remove the brightsteel from the fiery forge. She then laid the metal on her anvils and, with a practiced series of blows, hammered the metal into large plates that were no more than a half an inch thick.\r\n\r\n\tFinished with each plate, the metalsmith then dropped them into a nearby trough of brine. The unicorn paused in her work once more, and then, mentally determining that the metal had cooled sufficiently, pulled all three oblong sheets from the watery substance. Then the mare produced a block of sandstone from her tool station and proceeded to scrape it against the plates to remove the unpleasant black scales that had formed upon the brightsteel. As she scoured the plates, the crystalline structure of the metal was revealed. Rarity set aside one of the plates of metal and examined the other two; it was imperative that the metal she used was of the highest possible quality, and only by examining the crystals could she ensure that her work could proceed. Deciding that the quality of the metal was as perfect as she could hope for, Rarity moved back over to her forge and superheated the brightsteel once more.\r\n\r\n\tThis time she left them in the flames until the metal was blindingly white, then removed the metal and slapped both pieces down upon her anvils. Hammers pealed in tandem as they struck the metals, creating a musical symphony. Then, on each plate, Rarity made a cut in the middle, folded each piece back onto each other, and welded those pieces together. As the color of the brightsteel began to fade from white to yellow, Rarity again placed them within the forge. Four more times she repeated this procedure, heating the metal and folding it back upon itself. At the end, she could easily bend the precious metal without it tearing; exactly what she wanted in the first place. Next would come the task of actually fashioning the suit of armor, a feat that made Rarity glad she was a unicorn. Even though her training had taught her how to create metal things without magic, like an earth pony, the fact that she could use her magic made things a whole lot easier in the long run.\r\n\r\n\tRarity continued her work for a long time. Once the single piece suit of armor had been finished, it was time to fuse it together with the amethyst. The air practically hummed with magical energy as the metalsmith continued her task. This part was actually quite easy, as amethyst responds well to magic and is willing to change its shape, so long as somepony knows how to handle it. Rarity eventually began to run on autopilot, her magic completing its tasks without her actively thinking about it. Even though she had only done something like this once before in a lesson, thanks to her penchant for details, once was all she needed to recall every step required. Naturally, with her mind having much more free space, it once more began to wander.\r\n\r\n\tUnlike other students within Canterlot were sure to act when they found out, Rarity couldn\xe2\x80\x99t feel any sort of animosity towards Twilight Sparkle. Sure, being the Valkyrie meant prestige and recognition. It meant the only other pony higher on the chain of command was Luna. But it also meant having hundreds, if not thousands and millions of underlings looking up to you. Expecting you to know what to do no matter the situation. It meant a whole lot of dedication to the Crown, and aiding Luna with the running of Equestria. Rarity didn\xe2\x80\x99t want any of that. It would take far too much out of her if she even tried. It was much easier to be the realm\xe2\x80\x99s most talented metalsmith, than to have so much responsibility thrust upon her shoulders. She could only hope that Twilight would be up for the task too.\r\n\r\n\r\n<<((*))>>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\tFluttershy loved her job. Granted, she was not yet a full blown medic, but she knew she was getting there. And just as surely as she felt herself approaching the completion of her training, her shyness was starting to recede. Part of it, she knew, was from the cloak they had given her-- Head Medic Shimmer, that is. A vast majority of the members of the Medic Corps in the field had one; not only did it distinguish them as a healer, it also provided something else: protection from emotions that could cause a field medic to hesitate. Some emotions, Fluttershy had learned, were good. Compassion, for example, was not something negated by those wondrous cloaks. Compassion for a wounded comrade on the field of battle could speed up a medic\xe2\x80\x99s work, make them eager to take care of the patient. Courage was another emotion that the cloak did not foil, and even sometimes gave to the wearer. Courage could allow a medic rush to the aid of those in need while in the heat of battle.\r\n\r\n\tFor some, the cloak blocked emotions like fear-- fear of failure, of not being fast enough. For others, the cloak blocked hesitation. The slightest bit of pause could cost the patient their life. For Fluttershy, however, the cloak blocked a very important thing: Her shyness. Most of the time, without that cloak of office, Fluttershy was her usual painfully shy self. Once she put that cloak on, she was a different mare entirely. She could feel it. She was assertive. She was in control, and her head was clear enough to make solid decisions while working. And what was even better, she was starting to slowly come out of her shell even with the cloak off. And to her eyes, that right there was the best part of her training. It was surprisingly nice to be able to look ponies in the eye and not flinch away, or immediately hide behind her mane.\r\n\r\n\tAt the moment, Fluttershy was the medic on duty at the front of the main hospital the Medic Corps were stationed at. Why they called it a hospital, Fluttershy was not entirely sure. The towering building was more like an army headquarters that just so happened to have hundreds of rooms to hold patients. Ordinarily, Fluttershy might have questioned why she was the only healer on duty in the reception area; should a patient suddenly be admitted, it would be up to Fluttershy to take care of them, see if they could be healed, and have a room prepared for them if they needed to stay a while. But, Fluttershy knew that Head Medic Shimmer had faith in her. If Shimmer decided that the buttery pegasus was capable of being at this particular post, then Fluttershy would stay here until she was relieved. She was not about to let her mentor down.\r\n\r\n\tFluttershy\xe2\x80\x99s ears quirked, snapping to attention. All was silent. She had thought, for the briefest of moments, she had heard a siren. She strained her ears, trying to catch the elusive sound again. The emergency dispatch teams were the members of the Corps out in the city, at numerous smaller bases. Each member of the EDT carried special magic infused gems, that, when activated, flashed blue and red and emitted a shrill warbling. It warned ponies to clear a path to the closest hospital for the EDTs to take. About the time Fluttershy had decided she had imagined it, the sound came again, and this time stayed. It was faint still, but growing louder by the minute. Fluttershy trotted over to the massive double doors and shoved them open, magical clasps keeping them that way. Then, she waited. There was only one hospital in this area of Canterlot, after all.\r\n\r\n\tFluttershy saw the flashing lights far before the EDT came into view, bouncing off of buildings and lightning up the night sky.The wailing sirens grew to a crescendo of sound, nearly deafening the pegasus. Then the EDT appeared, six earth ponies strong, bearing a stretcher with something on it. The bright lights made it hard for Fluttershy to see what. The six earth ponies skidded to a halt in front of the pegasus, blowing hard, and the sirens mercifully stopped. Without wasting a moment of time, Fluttershy approached the team to see exactly what she was up against. One of the earth ponies, the captain of this unit judging by her short cloak, noticed Fluttershy approaching and spoke, heaving great breaths as she did so.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cGiant club fire--down in Night District. Numerous-- were wounded, but this one-- was too severely burned-- for the hospitals down there to deal with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tFluttershy barely heard the words, staring past the captain with a dawning sense of horror. The pony on the stretcher was so badly burned that at first, Fluttershy couldn\xe2\x80\x99t even tell it was a mare or a stallion. Upon closer inspection, the medic in training determined this was a mare, as her features-- what little of them had not been burned-- were less blocky than a stallion\xe2\x80\x99s. Aside from that, and the horn protruding from the mare\xe2\x80\x99s forehead, there was almost nothing remaining to identify who this mare was. What was left of her main and tail was covered in soot. Her coat and cutie mark was a mystery with all of those burns. The only other thing that could have identified the unicorn was a melted mess of purple colored plastic perched upon her nose, that might have been a pair of fashion glasses at one point in time. The mare, to Fluttershy\xe2\x80\x99s astonishment, was still breathing, but even she could tell it was weak and harsh.\r\n\r\n\tEven as the medic took all of these details in, her cloak was working to neutralize the horror freezing her in place. In control of her limbs once again, Fluttershy rushed to the burn victim to begin her analysis. Luckily, the unicorn did not seem to be wearing any clothing. This was a good thing, as it would make her treatment much easier later on. The only thing that would pose a problem was the melted plastic stuck to the unicorn\xe2\x80\x99s muzzle, but that was something that could be taken care of later. From within her ever present satchel Fluttershy withdrew a long, thin tube. She gently prized open the victim\xe2\x80\x99s mouth and fed the tube inside; this would allow medics to use a small ventilator to help the air passageway to remain open. Sticking the other end of the tube into her mouth, Fluttershy blew air into the tube slowly. Judging by the slightly stronger breaths the unicorn was now taking, her airways were clearer.\r\n\r\n\tShe motioned to the exhausted emergency dispatch team and they began to move inside the hospital. Several other medics met them, having heard the sirens and flashing lights. They joined Fluttershy on either side of the patient, checking for severe shock and other complications. Aside from being unconscious, the burned mare didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to be suffering from shock, but it never hurt to be sure. The medic in training led her small posse directly to the burn center, where real treatment of the mare could commence. Fluttershy had done all she could by ensuring that the unicorn could still breathe, but the rest was beyond her capabilities. The victim would have to be injected with fluids, to replace those lost and to make sure she didn\xe2\x80\x99t go into shock. Then she\xe2\x80\x99d have to be placed in one of those special burn tanks, while doctors and surgeons set about the task of healing her and regrowing her body. Deciding that the unknown unicorn was in good hooves, Fluttershy decided it would be a good idea to return to her post.\r\n\r\n\tInstead, as she turned around, she came face to face with Shimmer. Fluttershy meeped, startled. \xe2\x80\x9cI--I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry, Head Medic. I--I didn\xe2\x80\x99t see you there.\xe2\x80\x9d Her accursed shyness was returning, despite the cloak\xe2\x80\x99s effort to dispel the emotion.\r\n\r\n\tShimmer was smiling gently. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no need to be afraid, Fluttershy. And I certainly did not mean to startle you. You did well, with that mare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tFluttershy perked up a bit. \xe2\x80\x9cReally?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tShimmer nodded once. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, you did. You remembered your training, and because of you, that mare is likely to live to see another day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tThe Head Medic\xe2\x80\x99s apprentice blushed at the praise. \xe2\x80\x9cI, um, I just did what I could.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cExactly. You didn\xe2\x80\x99t hesitate, you just acted. And, in light of this, I think it is time we start the next phrase of your training.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tFluttershy tilted her head. \xe2\x80\x9cYou mean, um\xe2\x80\xa6 advanced training? Or something?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cI guess you could call it that. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to start teaching you the art of combat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tThe pegasus squeaked at that. \xe2\x80\x9cC-Combat? But I don\xe2\x80\x99t--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Fluttershy. It is time I taught you how to fight. We Medics cannot always rely on our comrades to protect us while we\xe2\x80\x99re on the battlefield, doing our jobs. The Medic Corps have their own style of fighting, one that has served us well. For we do not fight with weapons, dear Fluttershy. We fight with utensils. Mixtures designed to confuse and incapacitate a foe."\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cO--Oh. I guess that\xe2\x80\x99s better than fighting with weapons, and killing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tShimmer shook her head. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course we don\xe2\x80\x99t fight to kill! We save lives, not take them. Report to my office early tomorrow morning, and we shall begin. You are dismissed, Trainee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tWith only a small nod towards her mentor, Fluttershy retreated towards the front doors. The walk to her foster parent\xe2\x80\x99s house was full of thoughts about what Shimmer had just told her.\r\n', 'chapter_number': 7, 'parent_chapter_id': 438032, 'chapter_html': '<html>\n\t<head>\n\t\t<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head>\n\t</head>\n\t<body>\n\t\t<h1><a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/story/104188/valkyrie">Valkyrie</a></h1>\n\t\t<h2>by <a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/user/Flicka+Ravenhide">Flicka Ravenhide</a></h2>\n\n\t\t<hr />\n\n\t\t<a name=\'7\'></a><h3>Chapter 7</h3>\n<p class=\'indented\'>In one of Canterlot Castle\xe2\x80\x99s many private forges, a marshmallow mare was preparing to be hard at work. Armor, to be exact, as well of a couple of other things that could prove useful. Armor that just happened to be the right size for Princess Luna\xe2\x80\x99s own powerful prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9e. If Luna was grooming a new Valkyrie, after years and years of not having one, something <i>big</i> was going to happen soon. She didn\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to know what, exactly, and even her slight penchant for gossip wasn\xe2\x80\x99t cause enough for her to wonder. But she could think of no other pony more suited to the title and all it entailed than Twilight. The studious mare didn\xe2\x80\x99t see it yet, but she was leader material. Rarity knew this without a doubt. The rest of their band of Orphans knew it. Its what had caused them to come together to face an uncertain world that disliked them simply for having the ear of the Princess. Twilight might not want to admit it, but they were all friends. Maybe not close friends, true, but it was there. They\xe2\x80\x99ve already been through so much, and even now they were still sticking together as much as possible.</p><p class="indented double">Rarity shook those thoughts from her head and once more focused on her movements, prepping her forge for the task ahead. The metal itself had to be extremely thin, almost impossibly so. The only thing the metal part of the armor would be used for was to give shape to the rest of the structure. Naturally, <i>brightsteel</i> was the only reasonable solution; it could be compressed so thin it resembled a piece of paper, yet could still turn aside even the sharpest of weapons. Over the <i>brightsteel</i> was going to be a layer of compressed magic, allowing ease of movement even if the wearer were not used to the heavy weight of the armor. Then, the last layer was going to be amethyst, mined from the Canterlot mines far beneath the castle itself. This amethyst would then have some of the most powerful enhancements any mage could offer placed upon it. In reality, this armor was going to make its wearer a living fortress. It was designed to be light, with full range of movement. The amethyst would then give it a pleasing color and provide some natural protection against magic and weaponry. Then the enchantments and other protections would further offer defensive capabilities. It was, quite easily, the most daunting task Rarity had ever been assigned.</p><p class="indented double">Of course, this really didn\xe2\x80\x99t concern Rarity. She knew what she was doing. Daunting or not, it would be done to perfection. Deciding that she was ready to begin, Rarity picked up the pieces of <i>brightsteel</i> and held them before her, testing their weight with her magic. These were solid nodes, and would serve her well. She placed all three cantaloupe sized pieces into the forge. She would not use all of them, but what she did not use in the crafting of the armor could be used for other things. With a slight flare of magic from her horn, Rarity fed magic into the fire, causing it to burn three times as hot as before. Normally she wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t dare use magic to speed the process, but doing so would cause the <i>brightsteel</i> to become familiar with the touch of magic, preventing the metal from rejecting it later. So long as she was careful, speeding the process wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mar her work. After several moments and when the metal was a cherry red, Rarity used her tongs to remove the <i>brightsteel</i> from the fiery forge. She then laid the metal on her anvils and, with a practiced series of blows, hammered the metal into large plates that were no more than a half an inch thick.</p><p class="indented double">Finished with each plate, the metalsmith then dropped them into a nearby trough of brine. The unicorn paused in her work once more, and then, mentally determining that the metal had cooled sufficiently, pulled all three oblong sheets from the watery substance. Then the mare produced a block of sandstone from her tool station and proceeded to scrape it against the plates to remove the unpleasant black scales that had formed upon the <i>brightsteel</i>. As she scoured the plates, the crystalline structure of the metal was revealed. Rarity set aside one of the plates of metal and examined the other two; it was imperative that the metal she used was of the highest possible quality, and only by examining the crystals could she ensure that her work could proceed. Deciding that the quality of the metal was as perfect as she could hope for, Rarity moved back over to her forge and superheated the <i>brightsteel</i> once more.</p><p class="indented double">This time she left them in the flames until the metal was blindingly white, then removed the metal and slapped both pieces down upon her anvils. Hammers pealed in tandem as they struck the metals, creating a musical symphony. Then, on each plate, Rarity made a cut in the middle, folded each piece back onto each other, and welded those pieces together. As the color of the <i>brightsteel</i> began to fade from white to yellow, Rarity again placed them within the forge. Four more times she repeated this procedure, heating the metal and folding it back upon itself. At the end, she could easily bend the precious metal without it tearing; exactly what she wanted in the first place. Next would come the task of actually fashioning the suit of armor, a feat that made Rarity glad she was a unicorn. Even though her training had taught her how to create metal things without magic, like an earth pony, the fact that she could use her magic made things a whole lot easier in the long run.</p><p class="indented double">Rarity continued her work for a long time. Once the single piece suit of armor had been finished, it was time to fuse it together with the amethyst. The air practically hummed with magical energy as the metalsmith continued her task. This part was actually quite easy, as amethyst responds well to magic and is willing to change its shape, so long as somepony knows how to handle it. Rarity eventually began to run on autopilot, her magic completing its tasks without her actively thinking about it. Even though she had only done something like this once before in a lesson, thanks to her penchant for details, once was all she needed to recall every step required. Naturally, with her mind having much more free space, it once more began to wander.</p><p class="indented double">Unlike other students within Canterlot were sure to act when they found out, Rarity couldn\xe2\x80\x99t feel any sort of animosity towards Twilight Sparkle. Sure, being the Valkyrie meant prestige and recognition. It meant the only other pony higher on the chain of command was Luna. But it also meant having hundreds, if not thousands and millions of underlings looking up to you. Expecting you to know what to do no matter the situation. It meant a whole lot of dedication to the Crown, and aiding Luna with the running of Equestria. Rarity didn\xe2\x80\x99t want any of that. It would take far too much out of her if she even tried. It was much easier to be the realm\xe2\x80\x99s most talented metalsmith, than to have so much responsibility thrust upon her shoulders. She could only hope that Twilight would be up for the task too.</p><p class="double"></p><p><center>&lt;&lt;((*))&gt;&gt;</center></p></p><br /><p><p class="indented double">Fluttershy loved her job. Granted, she was not yet a full blown medic, but she knew she was getting there. And just as surely as she felt herself approaching the completion of her training, her shyness was starting to recede. Part of it, she knew, was from the cloak they had given her-- Head Medic Shimmer, that is. A vast majority of the members of the Medic Corps in the field had one; not only did it distinguish them as a healer, it also provided something else: protection from emotions that could cause a field medic to hesitate. Some emotions, Fluttershy had learned, were good. Compassion, for example, was not something negated by those wondrous cloaks. Compassion for a wounded comrade on the field of battle could speed up a medic\xe2\x80\x99s work, make them eager to take care of the patient. Courage was another emotion that the cloak did not foil, and even sometimes gave to the wearer. Courage could allow a medic rush to the aid of those in need while in the heat of battle.</p><p class="indented double">For some, the cloak blocked emotions like fear-- fear of failure, of not being fast enough. For others, the cloak blocked hesitation. The slightest bit of pause could cost the patient their life. For Fluttershy, however, the cloak blocked a very important thing: Her shyness. Most of the time, without that cloak of office, Fluttershy was her usual painfully shy self. Once she put that cloak on, she was a different mare entirely. She could feel it. She was assertive. She was in control, and her head was clear enough to make solid decisions while working. And what was even better, she was starting to slowly come out of her shell even with the cloak off. And to her eyes, that right there was the best part of her training. It was surprisingly nice to be able to look ponies in the eye and not flinch away, or immediately hide behind her mane.</p><p class="indented double">At the moment, Fluttershy was the medic on duty at the front of the main hospital the Medic Corps were stationed at. Why they called it a hospital, Fluttershy was not entirely sure. The towering building was more like an army headquarters that just so happened to have hundreds of rooms to hold patients. Ordinarily, Fluttershy might have questioned <i>why</i> she was the only healer on duty in the reception area; should a patient suddenly be admitted, it would be up to Fluttershy to take care of them, see if they could be healed, and have a room prepared for them if they needed to stay a while. But, Fluttershy knew that Head Medic Shimmer had faith in her. If Shimmer decided that the buttery pegasus was capable of being at this particular post, then Fluttershy would stay here until she was relieved. She was not about to let her mentor down.</p><p class="indented double">Fluttershy\xe2\x80\x99s ears quirked, snapping to attention. All was silent. She had thought, for the briefest of moments, she had heard a siren. She strained her ears, trying to catch the elusive sound again. The emergency dispatch teams were the members of the Corps out in the city, at numerous smaller bases. Each member of the EDT carried special magic infused gems, that, when activated, flashed blue and red and emitted a shrill warbling. It warned ponies to clear a path to the closest hospital for the EDTs to take. About the time Fluttershy had decided she had imagined it, the sound came again, and this time stayed. It was faint still, but growing louder by the minute. Fluttershy trotted over to the massive double doors and shoved them open, magical clasps keeping them that way. Then, she waited. There was only one hospital in this area of Canterlot, after all.</p><p class="indented double">Fluttershy saw the flashing lights far before the EDT came into view, bouncing off of buildings and lightning up the night sky.The wailing sirens grew to a crescendo of sound, nearly deafening the pegasus. Then the EDT appeared, six earth ponies strong, bearing a stretcher with <i>something</i> on it. The bright lights made it hard for Fluttershy to see what. The six earth ponies skidded to a halt in front of the pegasus, blowing hard, and the sirens mercifully stopped. Without wasting a moment of time, Fluttershy approached the team to see exactly what she was up against. One of the earth ponies, the captain of this unit judging by her short cloak, noticed Fluttershy approaching and spoke, heaving great breaths as she did so.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cGiant club fire--down in Night District. Numerous-- were wounded, but this one-- was too severely burned-- for the hospitals down there to deal with.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Fluttershy barely heard the words, staring past the captain with a dawning sense of horror. The pony on the stretcher was so badly burned that at first, Fluttershy couldn\xe2\x80\x99t even tell it was a mare or a stallion. Upon closer inspection, the medic in training determined this was a mare, as her features-- what little of them had not been burned-- were less blocky than a stallion\xe2\x80\x99s. Aside from that, and the horn protruding from the mare\xe2\x80\x99s forehead, there was almost nothing remaining to identify who this mare was. What was left of her main and tail was covered in soot. Her coat and cutie mark was a mystery with all of those burns. The only other thing that could have identified the unicorn was a melted mess of purple colored plastic perched upon her nose, that might have been a pair of fashion glasses at one point in time. The mare, to Fluttershy\xe2\x80\x99s astonishment, was still breathing, but even she could tell it was weak and harsh.</p><p class="indented double">Even as the medic took all of these details in, her cloak was working to neutralize the horror freezing her in place. In control of her limbs once again, Fluttershy rushed to the burn victim to begin her analysis. Luckily, the unicorn did not seem to be wearing any clothing. This was a good thing, as it would make her treatment much easier later on. The only thing that would pose a problem was the melted plastic stuck to the unicorn\xe2\x80\x99s muzzle, but that was something that could be taken care of later. From within her ever present satchel Fluttershy withdrew a long, thin tube. She gently prized open the victim\xe2\x80\x99s mouth and fed the tube inside; this would allow medics to use a small ventilator to help the air passageway to remain open. Sticking the other end of the tube into her mouth, Fluttershy blew air into the tube slowly. Judging by the slightly stronger breaths the unicorn was now taking, her airways were clearer.</p><p class="indented double">She motioned to the exhausted emergency dispatch team and they began to move inside the hospital. Several other medics met them, having heard the sirens and flashing lights. They joined Fluttershy on either side of the patient, checking for severe shock and other complications. Aside from being unconscious, the burned mare didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to be suffering from shock, but it never hurt to be sure. The medic in training led her small posse directly to the burn center, where real treatment of the mare could commence. Fluttershy had done all she could by ensuring that the unicorn could still breathe, but the rest was beyond her capabilities. The victim would have to be injected with fluids, to replace those lost and to make sure she didn\xe2\x80\x99t go into shock. Then she\xe2\x80\x99d have to be placed in one of those special burn tanks, while doctors and surgeons set about the task of healing her and regrowing her body. Deciding that the unknown unicorn was in good hooves, Fluttershy decided it would be a good idea to return to her post.</p><p class="indented double">Instead, as she turned around, she came face to face with Shimmer. Fluttershy meeped, startled. \xe2\x80\x9cI--I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry, Head Medic. I--I didn\xe2\x80\x99t see you there.\xe2\x80\x9d Her accursed shyness was returning, despite the cloak\xe2\x80\x99s effort to dispel the emotion.</p><p class="indented double">Shimmer was smiling gently. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no need to be afraid, Fluttershy. And I certainly did not mean to startle you. You did well, with that mare.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Fluttershy perked up a bit. \xe2\x80\x9cReally?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Shimmer nodded once. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, you did. You remembered your training, and because of you, that mare is likely to live to see another day.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">The Head Medic\xe2\x80\x99s apprentice blushed at the praise. \xe2\x80\x9cI, um, I just did what I could.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cExactly. You didn\xe2\x80\x99t hesitate, you just acted. And, in light of this, I think it is time we start the next phrase of your training.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Fluttershy tilted her head. \xe2\x80\x9cYou mean, um\xe2\x80\xa6 advanced training? Or something?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cI guess you could call it that. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to start teaching you the art of combat.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">The pegasus squeaked at that. \xe2\x80\x9cC-Combat? But I don\xe2\x80\x99t--\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Fluttershy. It is time I taught you how to fight. We Medics cannot always rely on our comrades to protect us while we\xe2\x80\x99re on the battlefield, doing our jobs. The Medic Corps have their own style of fighting, one that has served us well. For we do not fight with weapons, dear Fluttershy. We fight with utensils. Mixtures designed to confuse and incapacitate a foe.&quot;</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cO--Oh. I guess that\xe2\x80\x99s better than fighting with weapons, and killing.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Shimmer shook her head. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course we don\xe2\x80\x99t fight to kill! We save lives, not take them. Report to my office early tomorrow morning, and we shall begin. You are dismissed, Trainee.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">With only a small nod towards her mentor, Fluttershy retreated towards the front doors. The walk to her foster parent\xe2\x80\x99s house was full of thoughts about what Shimmer had just told her.</p><p></b></u></i></span></center></blockquote></p>\t</body>\n</html>', 'version': 1, 'parent_story_id': 104188}, 'chapter_id': 438032, 'cursor': <mysql.connector.cursor.MySQLCursor object at 0x02E3BB70>, 'connection': <mysql.connector.connection.MySQLConnection object at 0x02E01A70>, 'html': '<html>\n\t<head>\n\t\t<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head>\n\t</head>\n\t<body>\n\t\t<h1><a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/story/104188/valkyrie">Valkyrie</a></h1>\n\t\t<h2>by <a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/user/Flicka+Ravenhide">Flicka Ravenhide</a></h2>\n\n\t\t<hr />\n\n\t\t<a name=\'7\'></a><h3>Chapter 7</h3>\n<p class=\'indented\'>In one of Canterlot Castle\xe2\x80\x99s many private forges, a marshmallow mare was preparing to be hard at work. Her mane lacked its usual coiffer, instead done up in a tight little bun to ensure it would not get in the way. Normally, she wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be here. Not since she\xe2\x80\x99s mastered everything about metalsmithing Princess Luna and her forgemasters could teach her. But her presence here was special. Try as Luna might, the Monarch couldn&#039;t hope to keep her plans a secret when she came to Rarity, asking the talented mare to work her craft once more. Rarity, of course, had been extremely enthusiastic. Not only would she be able to ply her trade, but she was creating <i>equipment</i> for the new Valkyrie. Armor, to be exact, as well of a couple of other things that could prove useful. Armor that just happened to be the right size for Princess Luna\xe2\x80\x99s own powerful prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9e. Rarity, for her part, knew exactly <i>who</i> it was for. There was only one student of Luna\xe2\x80\x99s who held the actual title of prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9e, after all. It also helped that Rarity still recalled Twilight Sparkle\xe2\x80\x99s exact measurements from a couple of years ago. That mare hadn\xe2\x80\x99t grown all that much since then.</p><p class="indented double">Despite what other ponies might think about Orphans in general, Rarity was not stupid. If Luna was grooming a new Valkyrie, after years and years of not having one, something <i>big</i> was going to happen soon. She didn\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to know what, exactly, and even her slight penchant for gossip wasn\xe2\x80\x99t cause enough for her to wonder. But she could think of no other pony more suited to the title and all it entailed than Twilight. The studious mare didn\xe2\x80\x99t see it yet, but she was leader material. Rarity knew this without a doubt. The rest of their band of Orphans knew it. Its what had caused them to come together to face an uncertain world that disliked them simply for having the ear of the Princess. Twilight might not want to admit it, but they were all friends. Maybe not close friends, true, but it was there. They\xe2\x80\x99ve already been through so much, and even now they were still sticking together as much as possible.</p><p class="indented double">Rarity shook those thoughts from her head and once more focused on her movements, prepping her forge for the task ahead. The metal itself had to be extremely thin, almost impossibly so. The only thing the metal part of the armor would be used for was to give shape to the rest of the structure.
