The third year glanced around desperately, looking for somepony to help her. Fleetfoot finally made her way over.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s going on here, Blossom?\xe2\x80\x9d Fleetfoot had originally called this to Blossom\xe2\x80\x99s attention and told her to reprimand the pair for deviating from the pattern. That reprimand should have already been delivered, and practice resumed. But now however, the entire class had their attention, and it was being disrupted.\r\n\r\n\tThird year Blossom came to a salute. \xe2\x80\x9cMa\xe2\x80\x99am, both trainees claim they completed the sequence as it was called. They both repeated it in order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tRainbow Dash opened her mouth to rebuke the scathing tone Blossom used, but suddenly decided against such an action. The last thing she needed was demerits.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cHold a moment.\xe2\x80\x9d Fleetfood and Blossom glanced around, a little flabbergasted. They had not seen Spitfire approaching. All around, the rest of the Cadets all came to stiff attentiveness. Both Dash and Flitter paled a little at seeing their commanding officer approach. They looked as though they could already see their immediate dismissal from the Wonderbolt Academy looming upon the horizon.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cDo you recall the sequence, Cadet Rainbow Dash, Cadet Flitter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tBoth pegasi nodded eagerly. Then, remembering that this was not a suitable response in the presence of their senior, they spoke. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am! Sequence seven, ma\xe2\x80\x99am!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tSpitfire noted that they both called the sequence correctly for the second time. She also doubted that any of the other Cadets could have even come close to calling it right. \xe2\x80\x9cThen perhaps you could repeat it for us again,\xe2\x80\x9d she commanded, her voice hiding her burning curiosity.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cTake your positions\xe2\x80\xa6 begin!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tThe two pegasi performed the sequence flawlessly, calling the strokes as they went. \xe2\x80\x9cSide slash! Overhead cut! Thrust! Backhoof slash! Backhoof overhead!\xe2\x80\x9d The wooden caps clashed with each other magnificently. The timing was perfect. The forms of the two first years were completely flawless. Spitfire hadn\xe2\x80\x99t even seen experienced second years able to pull off a sequence so perfectly. But, this time around, there was no extra stroke. After a bit of careful consideration, Spitfire thought she knew why: The first years were focused on getting the sequence correct. They weren\xe2\x80\x99t doing everything by instinct. Soarin, attracted to the presence of his commander on the field itself, slowly approached, asking with his eyes. Spitfire barely shook her head, warning him to step lightly. She didn\xe2\x80\x99t need the Cadets to have their concentration interrupted.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cSequence two! Go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cOverhead cut! Thrust! Backstep! Cap parry! Side slash! Underhand side slash!\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin and Fleetfoot were starting to look impressed. The two Cadets were practically chanting the sequence. The partners were moving lightly on their hooves now, hoof caps flickering out and about, following the cadence nearly half as quickly again as Soarin had originally been calling them. Spitfire once more shook her head imperceptibly. She wanted to show them what she was sure was going to happen next. Before Dash and Flitter even had time to think, Spitfire called again. \xe2\x80\x9cSequence seven!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cSide slash! Overhead cut! Thrust! Backhoof slash! Backhoof overhead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cSide slash!\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire snapped and, completely instinctively, Dash executed that dangerous extra move that Flitter neatly blocked with her own blazing speed, then proceeded to do the same thing against Dash. There were very slight noises of surprise from Soarin and Fleetfoot. They understood the significance of what they had seen, and seemed even more impressed on how quickly Flitter had responded to that extra attack.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cRest!\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire ordered, and once more, her two Cadets immediately returned to their ready stances, forehooves up and weaving slightly on their hind hooves.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Rainbow Dash, Flitter.\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire said softly. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember that side slash you executed the first time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tComprehension dawned in their eyes at roughly the same moment. \xe2\x80\x9cUm\xe2\x80\xa6 I think so, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x9d Flitter replied.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cSorry ma\xe2\x80\x99am. It won't happen again.\xe2\x80\x9d Dash echoed.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cWell, no harm done. Just next time, pay better attention to what is being called.\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire turned away and was a few steps towards the fencing when she casually turned back towards Soarin and Fleetfoot.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cBy the way, I want to see you two in my office later. We have some issues to discuss regarding the state of the armory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tBoth senior Wonderbolts nodded. They understood that Spitfire wanted to discuss what had happened here, but did not want Dash or Flitter to be aware.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cCarry on, then.\xe2\x80\x9d And as Commander Spitfire turned away, she heard Soarin call out the preparation orders, and then the solid sound of wood striking wood resumed.\r\n\r\n\r\n<<((*))>>\r\n\r\n\r\n\tPinkie Pie frowned thoughtfully. This by itself was surprising; Pinkie never frowned. Ever. Since the death of her parents, Pinkie became a firm believer in smiling to make the pain go away. And being able to bring smiles to other ponies was just icing on the cake. Or maybe cupcake? Pinkie loved cupcakes more than cake, sure. Cupcakes were travel ready. The pink mare shook her head swiftly, as though to chase away those errant thoughts. Now was the time to focus, not go off on some tangent that had nothing to do with her current mission. The thought of the mission Zecora had tasked her with deepened her frown, if that was even possible. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t her superior she was annoyed with, oh no. Zecora was a really nice Zebra and an excellent teacher. But what Pinkie was upset about the most was the nature of this mission. Her parents had died in a fire, and being told to investigate the still smoldering ruins of that giant fire from last night made her uneasy, and was thus partially the source of her frown. \r\n\r\n\tThe other part of her frown was simply a by product of wanting to find the culprit who had started the fire. Early intel strongly hinted at the fire being set on purpose, rather than just happening in an accident. So Pinkie was also frowning at the thought of somepony being meany pants enough to deliberately start a fire. Which was why the pink mare was out here in the first place, prowling around the outskirts of what used to be a building. Zecora firmly believed that the only way to learn the trade of an information gatherer was to actually be out in the field at all times. As Zecora had cleverly put it, you cannot hand an agent a book and expect them to learn from said book. There wasn\xe2\x80\x99t any real way to learn what needed to be learned unless you were out in the real world, learning from your mistakes and teaching yourself new tricks.\r\n\r\n\tThe Royal Guards still patrolling the wreckage paid her no mind, even going so far as to stare seemingly straight through her. This caused Pinkie\xe2\x80\x99s frown to slowly melt, to be replaced by a slight smile. She touched the gem at her throat, the little thrum of magic telling her it was still active. True invisibility was something only the most adept unicorns could accomplish, so agents of Equestrian Intelligence settled for the next best thing: Being unnoticeable. Rather than attempting to cause light to bend around the pony body like most unicorns do, an Unnoticeable Charm rendered a caster well\xe2\x80\xa6 unnoticeable. Pinkie didn\xe2\x80\x99t grasp the full mechanics of it, to be honest. All she really understood was that the charm would prevent others from perceiving the fact that she was standing in plain sight. There were drawbacks to being unnoticeable, of course. If she ran into somepony the spell would fail to hide her. If she moved too quickly or made a loud noise, she could be discovered. But slinking past a pair of Royal Guards? Cake. Or cupcake. Whatever.\r\n\r\n\tOnce she actually entered the burned building proper, she moved a little easier, knowing that the ash that coated everything would mask her hoofsteps. The sharp tang of burned wood greeted her everywhere she turned, and she wrinkled her nose. Her baby blue eyes glanced around carefully as she tried to decide where to start. She had entered the building from the right side, where the natural shade cast by the store next door made it even easier to make it past the guards. Judging by the stone foundations, this had been a small storage room of sorts. It was far too small to be a part of the main floor, or any of the other private rooms. After some careful prodding, she found a bent piece of metal, like what you would find in the head of an industrial broom. It seemed her assumption was correct, but this room really didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell her much of anything. Stepping lightly, Pinkie moved into what had probably been a long hall once. There were intervals in the foundation, as if doors had once stood there.\r\n\r\n\tBehind Pinkie was the outside, so she moved forward, passing non-existent doors as she went. She cast her eyes carefully from left to right, but these assumed rooms didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to offer much in the way of clues. Pinkie finally moved far enough inside she made it to what had definitely been the main room. Remnants of a dance floor dotted the ground here and there. In the very center of the room rested what was left of the stage. Trotting over for a better look, Pinkie noted the thick, relatively unscarred chains attached to all four corners. So this had been one of those popular suspended stages then. Hanging from the center of the room, such stages provided increased sound. This one looked as though it had been cracked in two when it struck the ground below, long before the flames had managed to ravish it. Easing gently around part of the stage that was canted upward, Pinkie\xe2\x80\x99s hunch was confirmed as she saw the remains of a small staircase that would have lead up to the stage floor. As the mare went to move farther into the place, she stumbled and nearly fell.\r\n\r\n\tCatching her balance swiftly, Pinkie glanced back at what she had tripped on. Eyes narrowing slightly, a forehoof gently brushed away ash. She had uncovered a fire suppression system. Or what was left of one, anyway. The metal was twisted almost completely beyond recognition, but what caught Pinkie\xe2\x80\x99s attention was the fact that the sprinkler head was still sealed with the protective seal. There was only one reason why the head would still be sealed: The fire had appeared so suddenly, and burned so hotly, that the metal piping had collapsed before the sprinkler could go off. And judging by the destruction around her, the water inside the suppression system had been nowhere near enough to put out the fire. Pinkie mentally filed away this information to be put on her report for later, and continued on.\r\n\r\n\tBut no matter how much she probed into the ruined club, she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t find anything other than the failed suppression system. The only thing she really knew was that the fire had apparently appeared out of thin air, and burned hot enough to melt metals and evaporate water before it could be doused. None of this made any sense at all. A part of her wanted to just mark this off as an extremely dangerous accidental fire, but something was stopping her. There had to be something she was missing. As the pink mare turned to start heading back towards the front of the building, though, a slight flash of orange caught her eye. She whirled back around, staring intently. In one of the rear-most corners of the building, there was something orange gleaming there. It seemed to pulse, as though it were some monstrous heart. The only reason she had seen it was because the area it was resting in was overshadowed by the restaurant next door.\r\n\r\n\tPinkie approached the thing cautiously, almost expecting an attack. But nothing happened. Whatever it was just sat there, like it had been casually tossed aside. The infiltrator in training stopped a short distance away, her head titled quizzically. It looked like nothing she had ever seen before. She stood like that for a long time, observing it. Little strands or darker red-orange snaked across the object\xe2\x80\x99s surface, almost like veins. It was the size of a small watermelon. And all the time she stared at it, it never stopped pulsing. Finally, Pinkie inched forward slowly. As she did so, she began to notice the heat. It grew slightly in intensity as she approached closer, though it never got unbearable. Finally, tentatively, Pinkie reached out a hoof and brushed the strange thing. It was warm, quite warm, but not hot enough to burn. It almost felt as though it was cooling off after whatever it had been used for. \r\n\r\n\tPinkie lifted the round object up carefully, but the even closer inspection did not reveal any secrets to her. Hesitating for but a moment, the mare pulled open one of the saddlebags she had strapped to her sides. The thing just barely fit inside, filling the dark space with bright orange light. She waited for a moment, ensuring that whatever this was would not burn through her bag. Then, satisfied that the evidence was secure, she carefully made her way back towards her infiltration point. Pinkie didn\xe2\x80\x99t know if this odd object had caused the fire here or not, but Zecora would want to see it. The zebra might even actually know what it was.\r\n\r\n<<((*))>>\r\n\r\n\tSpitfire had barely taken a seat behind her slightly cluttered desk before the Soarin and Fleetfoot entered. While they settled themselves, Spitfire reached off to one side and grabbed a jug of ale sitting there. She took a quick swig of the drink to clear her thoughts before she turned to regard her two officers. The commander folded her forehooves before her as she awaited the inevitable question. It was Soarin who spoke first.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cSo, you saw it. What do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire moved to set the jug of ale on the surface before her, making a simple gesture. Soarin nodded in thanks and took a quick swig before passing it off to Fleetfoot, eyes slowly wandering around the room. Soarin had only been in Spitfire\xe2\x80\x99s office once or twice, and each time it really amazed him at how spartan it was. Other high ranking officers used their important status to decorate rather lavishly, but that simply wasn\xe2\x80\x99t how Spitfire did things. She was efficient and practical, and the surroundings drove home the point.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cI saw it,\xe2\x80\x9d Fleetfoot said. \xe2\x80\x9cWasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure if I did at first, but I saw it all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tSpitfire shook her head. \xe2\x80\x9cYou both only saw it once. They were doing it the entire time. At first I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t even pinpoint why the rhythm seemed off. I was watching the overall drill, and not looking at specific areas. It took me a few minutes to hone in on where it was coming from, and then I watched them repeat those moves for several minutes before you became aware of it yourself, Soarin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the only instance?\xe2\x80\x9d the male pegasus sounded as if he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t decide what emotion he wanted to feel.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t. And it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t just that drill set, either. Each drill you called out, no matter which one it was, they were adding an extra little move that could potentially have devastating effects if put into actual use.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tFleetfoot frowned slightly. \xe2\x80\x9cOkay, I kind of expect something like this from Dash. But Flitter? I mean, she\xe2\x80\x99s a good recruit, but I just can\xe2\x80\x99t see her instinctively doing something like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was because Dash was teaching it to Flitter subconsciously. If I were to hazard a guess, Dash is going to make a very good leader someday in the near future.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cBut is that even possible? Teaching a move to somepony else without actually pausing to explain what was going on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tSpitfire shrugged slightly. \xe2\x80\x9cAll I know is what I saw. Unless Dash has been coaching Flitter outside of drill practice, it was all instinctual-- like Dash was the leader and Flitter was the follower. Dash is commander material. Plain and simple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cLike you?\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin asked, an eyebrow arched subtly.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cYes, like me.\xe2\x80\x9d came the steady reply. Spitfire held the gazes of her officers, unflinching.\r\n\r\n\tFleetfoot seemed to be hesitating with her next words. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think its because of her ties to\xe2\x80\xa6 well\xe2\x80\xa6. you-know-what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tSpitfire paused to actually consider the question, before the reply: \xe2\x80\x9cYes. There could be other reasons, but this is the one that makes the most sense. But to Inspire others so easily\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9c... She\xe2\x80\x99s going to be even more powerful than you were at the height of your power.\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin finished for his commanding officer.\r\n\r\n\t\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly. The signs are there. The best we can actually do right now is coach her as best we can. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let her realize that there is something unique about her. She\xe2\x80\x99s got to come into this slowly, or she risks becoming corrupt. And we all know what happened last time, even if you two weren\xe2\x80\x99t here for it. Now, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you both have duties to attend to. Return to them, and remember: Keep quiet about this to everypony. You\xe2\x80\x99re both not supposed to know half of what you do, but I trust you. You\xe2\x80\x99re dismissed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\tSoarin and Fleetfoot both saluted, touching their right hooves to their left aligned Wonderbolt pins. Then the two lesser officers turned smartly and left Spitfire alone with her thoughts.\r\n\r\n\t\r\n", 'chapter_number': 8, 'parent_chapter_id': 552937, 'chapter_html': '<html>\n\t<head>\n\t\t<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head>\n\t</head>\n\t<body>\n\t\t<h1><a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/story/104188/valkyrie">Valkyrie</a></h1>\n\t\t<h2>by <a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/user/Flicka+Ravenhide">Flicka Ravenhide</a></h2>\n\n\t\t<hr />\n\n\t\t<a name=\'8\'></a><h3>Chapter 8</h3>\n<p class=\'indented\'>Commander Spitfire leaned against the oak fence surrounding the practice area, keeping an eye on her newest recruits. She pawed the turf with a forehoof thoughtfully. There were a grand total of twenty six new Cadets this year. All of them were completely green behind the ears, but in time, they\xe2\x80\x99d all make fine Wonderbolts. Well, except for one. The familiar chromatic mane stood out glaringly from the rest of the Cadets, practically screaming, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m different!\xe2\x80\x9d. Spitfire had meant what she had told her Princess. Before long, Rainbow Dash could easily take over Spitfire\xe2\x80\x99s position, if the Commander ever decided to retire. However, that abrupt turn of thoughts made her smile wryly. Her, retire? The thought was preposterous. Commander Spitfire has been commanding officer of the entire Wonderbolt military division for the past thousand years at least, and it would probably be several thousand more before she would be spent. That thought, naturally, led to yet another. Such a long timespan, to be in service to Equestria and her beloved Princess. Once upon a time, it had been more than one Princess she had served\xe2\x80\xa6 And as soon as she had that thought, Spitfire mentally slapped herself and buried the painful memories yet again. She really needed to get her mind to stop wandering like that.</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire forced herself to return back to idly watching her Cadets. They had each split off into pairs, sparring with each other. Each was dressed in a light chainmail tunic, heavy padded helm, and had wooden taloned caps on their hooves. Eventually, the recruits would progress to drilling with actual hoof caps-- albeit with blunted edges and points, and then later would choose the weapon they planned to master. But that was still some months away, by which time the less suitable recruits would have been weeded out. It was quite normal for at least a third of Wonderbolt applicants to drop out of the harsh training in the first three months. Sometimes it was the pegasus\xe2\x80\x99 choice. For others, it was at the discretion of his or her instructors or, in extreme cases, Spitfire herself. The Wonderbolts were harsh and standards were strict. They had to be. The practice yard rang with the thudding of wood against wood. At the head of the yard, Captain Soarin called the standard strokes that were being practiced. As he called out the sequence, one Cadet would administer the attacks while the other blocked them. Then, when Soarin started the same sequence over, the second Cadet would deliver while the first blocked.</p><p class="indented double">Five third-year cadets, under the direction of Lieutenant Fleetfoot, moved among the pegasi, attending to the detail of the basic hoof strikes: correcting a wrong movement here, changing the angle of a stroke there, making sure another recruit\xe2\x80\x99s caps weren\xe2\x80\x99t dropping too far as he or she struck. It was rather repetitive work under the glaring hot sun, but it was necessary. These drills might be what decides if a Wonderbolt lives or dies at some later point. These basic moves needed to be instinctual, plain and simple.</p><p class="indented double">It was actually with this thought in mind that Spitfire once more found her eyes returning to Rainbow Dash and her sparring partner, a promising young filly named Flitter. She had been watching Dash for some time now, observing the strikes the chromatic Cadet was delivering. As Soarin called out the basic strikes, Rainbow Dash was adding an extra stroke or two to her strikes, and somehow managed to not fall behind in her timing. If that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t interesting enough, <i>she was teaching Flitter how to do it</i>. Dash would add in an unexpected and uncalled strike, Flitter would counter, and then, within the next sequence, Flitter would perform the same move. Dash would counter, and then begin anew. Soarin began another sequence and Spitfire narrowed her eyes, watching the duo attentively.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSide slash! Overhead cut! Thrust! Backhoof slash! Backhoof overhead!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">And there it was. As Soarin called the backhoof overhead, Dash would deliver it, then immediately switch to a side slash, allowing the block from the backhoof overhead to redirect her weapon into the second blow. Flitter would then perform a swift block and immediately come in with a return side slash as Soarin began the sequence again, starting her return attacks. The move had been so lightning fast, it would have been devastating if Flitter had not blocked it. The opponent&#039;s own guard would have been raised high to stop the backhoof overhead, and wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been able to get his guard down fast enough to stop the attack from the side. Spitfire continued to watch as Flitter delivered the sequence, then, like Dash, added the blazing side slash. Dash blocked, and prepared to start anew. Spitfire had first became aware of this situation from the corner of her eye, noting a slight variation in the normal flurry of activity. And even then, the extra strike came so fast it still took her a while to hone in on where it was coming from.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cRest!\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin called. Spitfire then noticed that while most of the other recruits lowered their weapons and returned to standing on all fours, Rainbow Dash and Flitter maintained their ready position, forehooves up in the classic ready stance. But apparently, somepony else had finally noticed the variation in the drill. Fleetfoot called over one of the third year cadets and had a whispered conversation, gesturing at the pair. Dash and Flitter, still focused on each other, didn\xe2\x80\x99t see the exchange. They both looked up, startled, as the third year approached them.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cYou two! At training circle three. What do you two think you\xe2\x80\x99re doing?\xe2\x80\x9d Both Cadets looked a little anxious now, even more so when they realized that every eye in the area was focused on them. Including their superiors.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cMa\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x9d Both inquired at almost the same time. It was clear they didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand why they were being singled out.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cNeither one of you are following the correct pattern. Follow Captain Soarin\xe2\x80\x99s call, understand?\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire, now watching carefully, was convinced that the pair\xe2\x80\x99s confusion was very real. The first years shared a slight look, before Dash asked again.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cMa\xe2\x80\x99am? What\xe2\x80\x99re you talking about?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">The third year was starting to get annoyed now. She hadn\xe2\x80\x99t seen the extra strokes, but now assumed that the first years were simply following an attack sequence entirely of their own devising. She frowned at the pair dangerously, speaking in a voice that was far too loud for the occasion. \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Soarin calls the drills. You perform them as he calls them. No more funny business.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Rainbow Dash looked slightly angry now, glaring at the third year, and Flitter frowned herself before speaking. </p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cMa\xe2\x80\x99am\xe2\x80\xa6 We did.\xe2\x80\x9d Flitter gulped nervously. She knew she was never supposed to argue with a senior pegasus, but she <i>knew</i> they had completed the strokes as Soarin called them.</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire saw the third year hesitate. She still didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what the pair had supposedly done, but had only followed Fleetfoot\xe2\x80\x99s comments. The third year now tried to cover her hesitation with confidence. \xe2\x80\x9cOh you did, did you? Then what sequence did he call?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Rainbow Dash replied tersely. \xe2\x80\x9cSequence seven, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. Side Slash. Overhead cut. Thrust\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9c...backhoof slash. Backhoof overhead.\xe2\x80\x9d Flitter finished for her partner, proving that she had been paying attention too.</p><p class="indented double">The third year looked completely flummoxed now. She had expected the two to hesitate, or try to bluff their way through the matter. But to the best of her memory, the pair had called out the strikes perfectly, and in the correct order. The third year glanced around desperately, looking for somepony to help her. Fleetfoot finally made her way over.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s going on here, Blossom?\xe2\x80\x9d Fleetfoot had originally called this to Blossom\xe2\x80\x99s attention and told her to reprimand the pair for deviating from the pattern. That reprimand should have already been delivered, and practice resumed. But now however, the entire class had their attention, and it was being disrupted.</p><p class="indented double">Third year Blossom came to a salute. \xe2\x80\x9cMa\xe2\x80\x99am, both trainees claim they completed the sequence as it was called. They both repeated it in order.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Rainbow Dash opened her mouth to rebuke the scathing tone Blossom used, but suddenly decided against such an action. The last thing she needed was demerits.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cHold a moment.\xe2\x80\x9d Fleetfood and Blossom glanced around, a little flabbergasted. They had not seen Spitfire approaching. All around, the rest of the Cadets all came to stiff attentiveness. Both Dash and Flitter paled a little at seeing their commanding officer approach. They looked as though they could already see their immediate dismissal from the Wonderbolt Academy looming upon the horizon.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cDo you recall the sequence, Cadet Rainbow Dash, Cadet Flitter?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Both pegasi nodded eagerly. Then, remembering that this was not a suitable response in the presence of their senior, they spoke. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am! Sequence seven, ma\xe2\x80\x99am!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire noted that they both called the sequence correctly for the second time. She also doubted that any of the other Cadets could have even come close to calling it right. \xe2\x80\x9cThen perhaps you could repeat it for us again,\xe2\x80\x9d she commanded, her voice hiding her burning curiosity.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cTake your positions\xe2\x80\xa6 begin!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">The two pegasi performed the sequence flawlessly, calling the strokes as they went. \xe2\x80\x9cSide slash! Overhead cut! Thrust! Backhoof slash! Backhoof overhead!\xe2\x80\x9d The wooden caps clashed with each other magnificently. The timing was perfect. The forms of the two first years were completely flawless. Spitfire hadn\xe2\x80\x99t even seen experienced second years able to pull off a sequence so perfectly. But, this time around, there was no extra stroke. After a bit of careful consideration, Spitfire thought she knew why: The first years were focused on getting the sequence correct. They weren\xe2\x80\x99t doing everything by instinct. Soarin, attracted to the presence of his commander on the field itself, slowly approached, asking with his eyes. Spitfire barely shook her head, warning him to step lightly. She didn\xe2\x80\x99t need the Cadets to have their concentration interrupted.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSequence two! Go!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cOverhead cut! Thrust! Backstep! Cap parry! Side slash! Underhand side slash!\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin and Fleetfoot were starting to look impressed. The two Cadets were practically chanting the sequence. The partners were moving lightly on their hooves now, hoof caps flickering out and about, following the cadence nearly half as quickly again as Soarin had originally been calling them. Spitfire once more shook her head imperceptibly. She wanted to show them what she was sure was going to happen next. Before Dash and Flitter even had time to think, Spitfire called again. \xe2\x80\x9cSequence seven!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSide slash! Overhead cut! Thrust! Backhoof slash! Backhoof overhead!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSide slash!\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire snapped and, completely instinctively, Dash executed that dangerous extra move that Flitter neatly blocked with her own blazing speed, then proceeded to do the same thing against Dash. There were very slight noises of surprise from Soarin and Fleetfoot. They understood the significance of what they had seen, and seemed even more impressed on how quickly Flitter had responded to that extra attack.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cRest!\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire ordered, and once more, her two Cadets immediately returned to their ready stances, forehooves up and weaving slightly on their hind hooves.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Rainbow Dash, Flitter.\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire said softly. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember that side slash you executed the first time?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Comprehension dawned in their eyes at roughly the same moment. \xe2\x80\x9cUm\xe2\x80\xa6 I think so, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x9d Flitter replied.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSorry ma\xe2\x80\x99am. It won&#039;t happen again.\xe2\x80\x9d Dash echoed.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cWell, no harm done. Just next time, pay better attention to what is being called.\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire turned away and was a few steps towards the fencing when she casually turned back towards Soarin and Fleetfoot.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cBy the way, I want to see you two in my office later. We have some issues to discuss regarding the state of the armory.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Both senior Wonderbolts nodded. They understood that Spitfire wanted to discuss what had happened here, but did not want Dash or Flitter to be aware.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cCarry on, then.\xe2\x80\x9d And as Commander Spitfire turned away, she heard Soarin call out the preparation orders, and then the solid sound of wood striking wood resumed.</p><p class="double"></p><p><center>&lt;&lt;((*))&gt;&gt;</center></p><br /><p class="indented double">Pinkie Pie frowned thoughtfully. This by itself was surprising; Pinkie never frowned. Ever. Since the death of her parents, Pinkie became a firm believer in smiling to make the pain go away. And being able to bring smiles to other ponies was just icing on the cake. Or maybe cupcake? Pinkie loved cupcakes more than cake, sure. Cupcakes were travel ready. The pink mare shook her head swiftly, as though to chase away those errant thoughts. Now was the time to focus, not go off on some tangent that had nothing to do with her current mission. The thought of the mission Zecora had tasked her with deepened her frown, if that was even possible. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t her superior she was annoyed with, oh no. Zecora was a really nice Zebra and an excellent teacher. But what Pinkie was upset about the most was the nature of this mission. Her parents had died in a fire, and being told to investigate the still smoldering ruins of that giant fire from last night made her uneasy, and was thus partially the source of her frown. </p><p class="indented double">The other part of her frown was simply a by product of wanting to find the culprit who had started the fire. Early intel strongly hinted at the fire being set on purpose, rather than just happening in an accident. So Pinkie was also frowning at the thought of somepony being meany pants enough to deliberately start a fire. Which was why the pink mare was out here in the first place, prowling around the outskirts of what used to be a building. Zecora firmly believed that the only way to learn the trade of an information gatherer was to actually be out in the field at all times. As Zecora had cleverly put it, you cannot hand an agent a book and expect them to learn from said book. There wasn\xe2\x80\x99t any real way to learn what needed to be learned unless you were out in the real world, learning from your mistakes and teaching yourself new tricks.</p><p class="indented double">The Royal Guards still patrolling the wreckage paid her no mind, even going so far as to stare seemingly straight through her. This caused Pinkie\xe2\x80\x99s frown to slowly melt, to be replaced by a slight smile. She touched the gem at her throat, the little thrum of magic telling her it was still active. True invisibility was something only the most adept unicorns could accomplish, so agents of Equestrian Intelligence settled for the next best thing: Being unnoticeable. Rather than attempting to cause light to bend around the pony body like most unicorns do, an Unnoticeable Charm rendered a caster well\xe2\x80\xa6 unnoticeable. Pinkie didn\xe2\x80\x99t grasp the full mechanics of it, to be honest. All she really understood was that the charm would prevent others from perceiving the fact that she was standing in plain sight. There were drawbacks to being unnoticeable, of course. If she ran into somepony the spell would fail to hide her. If she moved too quickly or made a loud noise, she could be discovered. But slinking past a pair of Royal Guards? Cake. Or cupcake. Whatever.</p><p class="indented double">Once she actually entered the burned building proper, she moved a little easier, knowing that the ash that coated everything would mask her hoofsteps. The sharp tang of burned wood greeted her everywhere she turned, and she wrinkled her nose. Her baby blue eyes glanced around carefully as she tried to decide where to start. She had entered the building from the right side, where the natural shade cast by the store next door made it even easier to make it past the guards. Judging by the stone foundations, this had been a small storage room of sorts. It was far too small to be a part of the main floor, or any of the other private rooms. After some careful prodding, she found a bent piece of metal, like what you would find in the head of an industrial broom. It seemed her assumption was correct, but this room really didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell her much of anything. Stepping lightly, Pinkie moved into what had probably been a long hall once. There were intervals in the foundation, as if doors had once stood there.</p><p class="indented double">Behind Pinkie was the outside, so she moved forward, passing non-existent doors as she went. She cast her eyes carefully from left to right, but these assumed rooms didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to offer much in the way of clues. Pinkie finally moved far enough inside she made it to what had definitely been the main room. Remnants of a dance floor dotted the ground here and there. In the very center of the room rested what was left of the stage. Trotting over for a better look, Pinkie noted the thick, relatively unscarred chains attached to all four corners. So this had been one of those popular suspended stages then. Hanging from the center of the room, such stages provided increased sound. This one looked as though it had been cracked in two when it struck the ground below, long before the flames had managed to ravish it. Easing gently around part of the stage that was canted upward, Pinkie\xe2\x80\x99s hunch was confirmed as she saw the remains of a small staircase that would have lead up to the stage floor. As the mare went to move farther into the place, she stumbled and nearly fell.</p><p class="indented double">Catching her balance swiftly, Pinkie glanced back at what she had tripped on. Eyes narrowing slightly, a forehoof gently brushed away ash. She had uncovered a fire suppression system. Or what was left of one, anyway. The metal was twisted almost completely beyond recognition, but what caught Pinkie\xe2\x80\x99s attention was the fact that the sprinkler head was still sealed with the protective seal. There was only one reason why the head would still be sealed: The fire had appeared so suddenly, and burned so hotly, that the metal piping had collapsed before the sprinkler could go off. And judging by the destruction around her, the water inside the suppression system had been nowhere near enough to put out the fire. Pinkie mentally filed away this information to be put on her report for later, and continued on.</p><p class="indented double">But no matter how much she probed into the ruined club, she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t find anything other than the failed suppression system. The only thing she really knew was that the fire had apparently appeared out of thin air, and burned hot enough to melt metals and evaporate water before it could be doused. None of this made any sense at all. A part of her wanted to just mark this off as an extremely dangerous accidental fire, but something was stopping her. There had to be something she was missing. As the pink mare turned to start heading back towards the front of the building, though, a slight flash of orange caught her eye. She whirled back around, staring intently. In one of the rear-most corners of the building, there was something orange gleaming there. It seemed to pulse, as though it were some monstrous heart. The only reason she had seen it was because the area it was resting in was overshadowed by the restaurant next door.</p><p class="indented double">Pinkie approached the thing cautiously, almost expecting an attack. But nothing happened. Whatever it was just sat there, like it had been casually tossed aside. The infiltrator in training stopped a short distance away, her head titled quizzically. It looked like nothing she had ever seen before. She stood like that for a long time, observing it. Little strands or darker red-orange snaked across the object\xe2\x80\x99s surface, almost like veins. It was the size of a small watermelon. And all the time she stared at it, it never stopped pulsing. Finally, Pinkie inched forward slowly. As she did so, she began to notice the heat. It grew slightly in intensity as she approached closer, though it never got unbearable. Finally, tentatively, Pinkie reached out a hoof and brushed the strange thing. It was warm, quite warm, but not hot enough to burn. It almost felt as though it was cooling off after whatever it had been used for. </p><p class="indented double">Pinkie lifted the round object up carefully, but the even closer inspection did not reveal any secrets to her. Hesitating for but a moment, the mare pulled open one of the saddlebags she had strapped to her sides. The thing just barely fit inside, filling the dark space with bright orange light. She waited for a moment, ensuring that whatever this was would not burn through her bag. Then, satisfied that the evidence was secure, she carefully made her way back towards her infiltration point. Pinkie didn\xe2\x80\x99t know if this odd object had caused the fire here or not, but Zecora would want to see it. The zebra might even actually know what it was.</p><p class="double"><center>&lt;&lt;((*))&gt;&gt;</center></p><p class="indented double">Spitfire had barely taken a seat behind her slightly cluttered desk before the Soarin and Fleetfoot entered. While they settled themselves, Spitfire reached off to one side and grabbed a jug of ale sitting there. She took a quick swig of the drink to clear her thoughts before she turned to regard her two officers. The commander folded her forehooves before her as she awaited the inevitable question. It was Soarin who spoke first.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSo, you saw it. What do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire moved to set the jug of ale on the surface before her, making a simple gesture. Soarin nodded in thanks and took a quick swig before passing it off to Fleetfoot, eyes slowly wandering around the room. Soarin had only been in Spitfire\xe2\x80\x99s office once or twice, and each time it really amazed him at how spartan it was. Other high ranking officers used their important status to decorate rather lavishly, but that simply wasn\xe2\x80\x99t how Spitfire did things. She was efficient and practical, and the surroundings drove home the point.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cI saw it,\xe2\x80\x9d Fleetfoot said. \xe2\x80\x9cWasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure if I did at first, but I saw it all right.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire shook her head. \xe2\x80\x9cYou both only saw it once. They were doing it the entire time. At first I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t even pinpoint why the rhythm seemed off. I was watching the overall drill, and not looking at specific areas. It took me a few minutes to hone in on where it was coming from, and then I watched them repeat those moves for several minutes before you became aware of it yourself, Soarin.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the only instance?\xe2\x80\x9d the male pegasus sounded as if he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t decide what emotion he wanted to feel.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t. And it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t just that drill set, either. Each drill you called out, no matter which one it was, they were adding an extra little move that could potentially have devastating effects if put into actual use.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Fleetfoot frowned slightly. \xe2\x80\x9cOkay, I kind of expect something like this from Dash. But Flitter? I mean, she\xe2\x80\x99s a good recruit, but I just can\xe2\x80\x99t see her instinctively doing something like that.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cIt was because Dash was teaching it to Flitter subconsciously. If I were to hazard a guess, Dash is going to make a very good leader someday in the near future.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cBut is that even possible? Teaching a move to somepony else without actually pausing to explain what was going on?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire shrugged slightly. \xe2\x80\x9cAll I know is what I saw. Unless Dash has been coaching Flitter outside of drill practice, it was all instinctual-- like Dash was the leader and Flitter was the follower. Dash is commander material. Plain and simple.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cLike you?\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin asked, an eyebrow arched subtly.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cYes, like me.\xe2\x80\x9d came the steady reply. Spitfire held the gazes of her officers, unflinching.</p><p class="indented double">Fleetfoot seemed to be hesitating with her next words. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think its because of her ties to\xe2\x80\xa6 well\xe2\x80\xa6. you-know-what?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire paused to actually consider the question, before the reply: \xe2\x80\x9cYes. There could be other reasons, but this is the one that makes the most sense. But to Inspire others so easily\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9c... She\xe2\x80\x99s going to be even more powerful than you were at the height of your power.\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin finished for his commanding officer.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly. The signs are there. The best we can actually do right now is coach her as best we can. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let her realize that there is something unique about her. She\xe2\x80\x99s got to come into this slowly, or she risks becoming corrupt. And we <i>all</i> know what happened last time, even if you two weren\xe2\x80\x99t here for it. Now, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you both have duties to attend to. Return to them, and remember: Keep quiet about this to everypony. You\xe2\x80\x99re both not supposed to know half of what you do, but I trust you. You\xe2\x80\x99re dismissed.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Soarin and Fleetfoot both saluted, touching their right hooves to their left aligned Wonderbolt pins. Then the two lesser officers turned smartly and left Spitfire alone with her thoughts.</p><p class="indented double"></p><p></b></u></i></span></center></blockquote></p>\t</body>\n</html>', 'version': 1, 'parent_story_id': 104188}, 'chapter_id': 552937, 'cursor': <mysql.connector.cursor.MySQLCursor object at 0x02E3BF50>, 'connection': <mysql.connector.connection.MySQLConnection object at 0x02E01A70>, 'html': '<html>\n\t<head>\n\t\t<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head>\n\t</head>\n\t<body>\n\t\t<h1><a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/story/104188/valkyrie">Valkyrie</a></h1>\n\t\t<h2>by <a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/user/Flicka+Ravenhide">Flicka Ravenhide</a></h2>\n\n\t\t<hr />\n\n\t\t<a name=\'8\'></a><h3>Chapter 8</h3>\n<p class=\'indented\'>Commander Spitfire leaned against the oak fence surrounding the practice area, keeping an eye on her newest recruits. She pawed the turf with a forehoof thoughtfully. There were a grand total of twenty six new Cadets this year. All of them were completely green behind the ears, but in time, they\xe2\x80\x99d all make fine Wonderbolts. Well, except for one. The familiar chromatic mane stood out glaringly from the rest of the Cadets, practically screaming, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m different!\xe2\x80\x9d. Spitfire had meant what she had told her Princess. Before long, Rainbow Dash could easily take over Spitfire\xe2\x80\x99s position, if the Commander ever decided to retire. However, that abrupt turn of thoughts made her smile wryly. Her, retire? The thought was preposterous. Commander Spitfire has been commanding officer of the entire Wonderbolt military division for the past thousand years at least, and it would probably be several thousand more before she would be spent. That thought, naturally, led to yet another. Such a long timespan, to be in service to Equestria and her beloved Princess. Once upon a time, it had been more than one Princess she had served\xe2\x80\xa6 And as soon as she had that thought, Spitfire mentally slapped herself and buried the painful memories yet again. She really needed to get her mind to stop wandering like that.</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire forced herself to return back to idly watching her Cadets. They had each split off into pairs, sparring with each other. Each was dressed in a light chainmail tunic, heavy padded helm, and had wooden taloned caps on their hooves. Eventually, the recruits would progress to drilling with actual hoof caps-- albeit with blunted edges and points, and then later would choose the weapon they planned to master. But that was still some months away, by which time the less suitable recruits would have been weeded out. It was quite normal for at least a third of Wonderbolt applicants to drop out of the harsh training in the first three months. Sometimes it was the pegasus\xe2\x80\x99 choice. For others, it was at the discretion of his or her instructors or, in extreme cases, Spitfire herself. The Wonderbolts were harsh and standards were strict. They had to be. The practice yard rang with the thudding of wood against wood. At the head of the yard, Captain Soarin called the standard strokes that were being practiced. As he called out the sequence, one Cadet would administer the attacks while the other blocked them. Then, when Soarin started the same sequence over, the second Cadet would deliver while the first blocked.</p><p class="indented double">Five third-year cadets, under the direction of Lieutenant Fleetfoot, moved among the pegasi, attending to the detail of the basic hoof strikes: correcting a wrong movement here, changing the angle of a stroke there, making sure another recruit\xe2\x80\x99s caps weren\xe2\x80\x99t dropping too far as he or she struck. It was rather repetitive work under the glaring hot sun, but it was necessary. These drills might be what decides if a Wonderbolt lives or dies at some later point. These basic moves needed to be instinctual, plain and simple.</p><p class="indented double">It was actually with this thought in mind that Spitfire once more found her eyes returning to Rainbow Dash and her sparring partner, a promising young filly named Flitter. She had been watching Dash for some time now, observing the strikes the chromatic Cadet was delivering. As Soarin called out the basic strikes, Rainbow Dash was adding an extra stroke or two to her strikes, and somehow managed to not fall behind in her timing. If that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t interesting enough, <i>she was teaching Flitter how to do it</i>. Dash would add in an unexpected and uncalled strike, Flitter would counter, and then, within the next sequence, Flitter would perform the same move. Dash would counter, and then begin anew. Soarin began another sequence and Spitfire narrowed her eyes, watching the duo attentively.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSide slash! Overhead cut! Thrust! Backhoof slash! Backhoof overhead!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">And there it was. As Soarin called the backhoof overhead, Dash would deliver it, then immediately switch to a side slash, allowing the block from the backhoof overhead to redirect her weapon into the second blow. Flitter would then perform a swift block and immediately come in with a return side slash as Soarin began the sequence again, starting her return attacks. The move had been so lightning fast, it would have been devastating if Flitter had not blocked it. The opponent&#039;s own guard would have been raised high to stop the backhoof overhead, and wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been able to get his guard down fast enough to stop the attack from the side. Spitfire continued to watch as Flitter delivered the sequence, then, like Dash, added the blazing side slash. Dash blocked, and prepared to start anew. Spitfire had first became aware of this situation from the corner of her eye, noting a slight variation in the normal flurry of activity. And even then, the extra strike came so fast it still took her a while to hone in on where it was coming from.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cRest!\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin called. Spitfire then noticed that while most of the other recruits lowered their weapons and returned to standing on all fours, Rainbow Dash and Flitter maintained their ready position, forehooves up in the classic ready stance. But apparently, somepony else had finally noticed the variation in the drill. Fleetfoot called over one of the third year cadets and had a whispered conversation, gesturing at the pair. Dash and Flitter, still focused on each other, didn\xe2\x80\x99t see the exchange. They both looked up, startled, as the third year approached them.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cYou two! At training circle three. What do you two think you\xe2\x80\x99re doing?\xe2\x80\x9d Both Cadets looked a little anxious now, even more so when they realized that every eye in the area was focused on them. Including their superiors.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cMa\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x9d Both inquired at almost the same time. It was clear they didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand why they were being singled out.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cNeither one of you are following the correct pattern. Follow Captain Soarin\xe2\x80\x99s call, understand?\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire, now watching carefully, was convinced that the pair\xe2\x80\x99s confusion was very real. The first years shared a slight look, before Dash asked again.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cMa\xe2\x80\x99am? What\xe2\x80\x99re you talking about?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">The third year was starting to get annoyed now. She hadn\xe2\x80\x99t seen the extra strokes, but now assumed that the first years were simply following an attack sequence entirely of their own devising. She frowned at the pair dangerously, speaking in a voice that was far too loud for the occasion. \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Soarin calls the drills. You perform them as he calls them. No more funny business.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Rainbow Dash looked slightly angry now, glaring at the third year, and Flitter frowned herself before speaking. </p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cMa\xe2\x80\x99am\xe2\x80\xa6 We did.\xe2\x80\x9d Flitter gulped nervously. She knew she was never supposed to argue with a senior pegasus, but she <i>knew</i> they had completed the strokes as Soarin called them.</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire saw the third year hesitate. She still didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what the pair had supposedly done, but had only followed Fleetfoot\xe2\x80\x99s comments. The third year now tried to cover her hesitation with confidence. \xe2\x80\x9cOh you did, did you? Then what sequence did he call?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Rainbow Dash replied tersely. \xe2\x80\x9cSequence seven, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. Side Slash. Overhead cut. Thrust\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9c...backhoof slash. Backhoof overhead.\xe2\x80\x9d Flitter finished for her partner, proving that she had been paying attention too.</p><p class="indented double">The third year looked completely flummoxed now. She had expected the two to hesitate, or try to bluff their way through the matter. But to the best of her memory, the pair had called out the strikes perfectly, and in the correct order. The third year glanced around desperately, looking for somepony to help her. Fleetfoot finally made her way over.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s going on here, Blossom?\xe2\x80\x9d Fleetfoot had originally called this to Blossom\xe2\x80\x99s attention and told her to reprimand the pair for deviating from the pattern. That reprimand should have already been delivered, and practice resumed. But now however, the entire class had their attention, and it was being disrupted.</p><p class="indented double">Third year Blossom came to a salute. \xe2\x80\x9cMa\xe2\x80\x99am, both trainees claim they completed the sequence as it was called. They both repeated it in order.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Rainbow Dash opened her mouth to rebuke the scathing tone Blossom used, but suddenly decided against such an action. The last thing she needed was demerits.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cHold a moment.\xe2\x80\x9d Fleetfood and Blossom glanced around, a little flabbergasted. They had not seen Spitfire approaching. All around, the rest of the Cadets all came to stiff attentiveness. Both Dash and Flitter paled a little at seeing their commanding officer approach. They looked as though they could already see their immediate dismissal from the Wonderbolt Academy looming upon the horizon.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cDo you recall the sequence, Cadet Rainbow Dash, Cadet Flitter?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Both pegasi nodded eagerly. Then, remembering that this was not a suitable response in the presence of their senior, they spoke. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am! Sequence seven, ma\xe2\x80\x99am!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire noted that they both called the sequence correctly for the second time. She also doubted that any of the other Cadets could have even come close to calling it right. \xe2\x80\x9cThen perhaps you could repeat it for us again,\xe2\x80\x9d she commanded, her voice hiding her burning curiosity.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cTake your positions\xe2\x80\xa6 begin!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">The two pegasi performed the sequence flawlessly, calling the strokes as they went. \xe2\x80\x9cSide slash! Overhead cut! Thrust! Backhoof slash! Backhoof overhead!\xe2\x80\x9d The wooden caps clashed with each other magnificently. The timing was perfect. The forms of the two first years were completely flawless. Spitfire hadn\xe2\x80\x99t even seen experienced second years able to pull off a sequence so perfectly. But, this time around, there was no extra stroke. After a bit of careful consideration, Spitfire thought she knew why: The first years were focused on getting the sequence correct. They weren\xe2\x80\x99t doing everything by instinct. Soarin, attracted to the presence of his commander on the field itself, slowly approached, asking with his eyes. Spitfire barely shook her head, warning him to step lightly. She didn\xe2\x80\x99t need the Cadets to have their concentration interrupted.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSequence two! Go!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cOverhead cut! Thrust! Backstep! Cap parry! Side slash! Underhand side slash!\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin and Fleetfoot were starting to look impressed. The two Cadets were practically chanting the sequence. The partners were moving lightly on their hooves now, hoof caps flickering out and about, following the cadence nearly half as quickly again as Soarin had originally been calling them. Spitfire once more shook her head imperceptibly. She wanted to show them what she was sure was going to happen next. Before Dash and Flitter even had time to think, Spitfire called again. \xe2\x80\x9cSequence seven!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSide slash! Overhead cut! Thrust! Backhoof slash! Backhoof overhead!\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSide slash!\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire snapped and, completely instinctively, Dash executed that dangerous extra move that Flitter neatly blocked with her own blazing speed, then proceeded to do the same thing against Dash. There were very slight noises of surprise from Soarin and Fleetfoot. They understood the significance of what they had seen, and seemed even more impressed on how quickly Flitter had responded to that extra attack.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cRest!\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire ordered, and once more, her two Cadets immediately returned to their ready stances, forehooves up and weaving slightly on their hind hooves.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Rainbow Dash, Flitter.\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire said softly. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember that side slash you executed the first time?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Comprehension dawned in their eyes at roughly the same moment. \xe2\x80\x9cUm\xe2\x80\xa6 I think so, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x9d Flitter replied.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSorry ma\xe2\x80\x99am. It won&#039;t happen again.\xe2\x80\x9d Dash echoed.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cWell, no harm done. Just next time, pay better attention to what is being called.\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire turned away and was a few steps towards the fencing when she casually turned back towards Soarin and Fleetfoot.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cBy the way, I want to see you two in my office later. We have some issues to discuss regarding the state of the armory.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Both senior Wonderbolts nodded. They understood that Spitfire wanted to discuss what had happened here, but did not want Dash or Flitter to be aware.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cCarry on, then.\xe2\x80\x9d And as Commander Spitfire turned away, she heard Soarin call out the preparation orders, and then the solid sound of wood striking wood resumed.</p><p class="double"></p><p><center>&lt;&lt;((*))&gt;&gt;</center></p><br /><p class="indented double">Pinkie Pie frowned thoughtfully. This by itself was surprising; Pinkie never frowned. Ever. Since the death of her parents, Pinkie became a firm believer in smiling to make the pain go away. And being able to bring smiles to other ponies was just icing on the cake. Or maybe cupcake? Pinkie loved cupcakes more than cake, sure. Cupcakes were travel ready. The pink mare shook her head swiftly, as though to chase away those errant thoughts. Now was the time to focus, not go off on some tangent that had nothing to do with her current mission. The thought of the mission Zecora had tasked her with deepened her frown, if that was even possible. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t her superior she was annoyed with, oh no. Zecora was a really nice Zebra and an excellent teacher. But what Pinkie was upset about the most was the nature of this mission. Her parents had died in a fire, and being told to investigate the still smoldering ruins of that giant fire from last night made her uneasy, and was thus partially the source of her frown. </p><p class="indented double">The other part of her frown was simply a by product of wanting to find the culprit who had started the fire. Early intel strongly hinted at the fire being set on purpose, rather than just happening in an accident. So Pinkie was also frowning at the thought of somepony being meany pants enough to deliberately start a fire. Which was why the pink mare was out here in the first place, prowling around the outskirts of what used to be a building. Zecora firmly believed that the only way to learn the trade of an information gatherer was to actually be out in the field at all times. As Zecora had cleverly put it, you cannot hand an agent a book and expect them to learn from said book. There wasn\xe2\x80\x99t any real way to learn what needed to be learned unless you were out in the real world, learning from your mistakes and teaching yourself new tricks.</p><p class="indented double">The Royal Guards still patrolling the wreckage paid her no mind, even going so far as to stare seemingly straight through her. This caused Pinkie\xe2\x80\x99s frown to slowly melt, to be replaced by a slight smile. She touched the gem at her throat, the little thrum of magic telling her it was still active. True invisibility was something only the most adept unicorns could accomplish, so agents of Equestrian Intelligence settled for the next best thing: Being unnoticeable. Rather than attempting to cause light to bend around the pony body like most unicorns do, an Unnoticeable Charm rendered a caster well\xe2\x80\xa6 unnoticeable. Pinkie didn\xe2\x80\x99t grasp the full mechanics of it, to be honest. All she really understood was that the charm would prevent others from perceiving the fact that she was standing in plain sight. There were drawbacks to being unnoticeable, of course. If she ran into somepony the spell would fail to hide her. If she moved too quickly or made a loud noise, she could be discovered. But slinking past a pair of Royal Guards? Cake. Or cupcake. Whatever.</p><p class="indented double">Once she actually entered the burned building proper, she moved a little easier, knowing that the ash that coated everything would mask her hoofsteps. The sharp tang of burned wood greeted her everywhere she turned, and she wrinkled her nose. Her baby blue eyes glanced around carefully as she tried to decide where to start. She had entered the building from the right side, where the natural shade cast by the store next door made it even easier to make it past the guards. Judging by the stone foundations, this had been a small storage room of sorts. It was far too small to be a part of the main floor, or any of the other private rooms. After some careful prodding, she found a bent piece of metal, like what you would find in the head of an industrial broom. It seemed her assumption was correct, but this room really didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell her much of anything. Stepping lightly, Pinkie moved into what had probably been a long hall once. There were intervals in the foundation, as if doors had once stood there.</p><p class="indented double">Behind Pinkie was the outside, so she moved forward, passing non-existent doors as she went. She cast her eyes carefully from left to right, but these assumed rooms didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to offer much in the way of clues. Pinkie finally moved far enough inside she made it to what had definitely been the main room. Remnants of a dance floor dotted the ground here and there. In the very center of the room rested what was left of the stage. Trotting over for a better look, Pinkie noted the thick, relatively unscarred chains attached to all four corners. So this had been one of those popular suspended stages then. Hanging from the center of the room, such stages provided increased sound. This one looked as though it had been cracked in two when it struck the ground below, long before the flames had managed to ravish it. Easing gently around part of the stage that was canted upward, Pinkie\xe2\x80\x99s hunch was confirmed as she saw the remains of a small staircase that would have lead up to the stage floor. As the mare went to move farther into the place, she stumbled and nearly fell.</p><p class="indented double">Catching her balance swiftly, Pinkie glanced back at what she had tripped on. Eyes narrowing slightly, a forehoof gently brushed away ash. She had uncovered a fire suppression system. Or what was left of one, anyway. The metal was twisted almost completely beyond recognition, but what caught Pinkie\xe2\x80\x99s attention was the fact that the sprinkler head was still sealed with the protective seal. There was only one reason why the head would still be sealed: The fire had appeared so suddenly, and burned so hotly, that the metal piping had collapsed before the sprinkler could go off. And judging by the destruction around her, the water inside the suppression system had been nowhere near enough to put out the fire. Pinkie mentally filed away this information to be put on her report for later, and continued on.</p><p class="indented double">But no matter how much she probed into the ruined club, she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t find anything other than the failed suppression system. The only thing she really knew was that the fire had apparently appeared out of thin air, and burned hot enough to melt metals and evaporate water before it could be doused. None of this made any sense at all. A part of her wanted to just mark this off as an extremely dangerous accidental fire, but something was stopping her. There had to be something she was missing. As the pink mare turned to start heading back towards the front of the building, though, a slight flash of orange caught her eye. She whirled back around, staring intently. In one of the rear-most corners of the building, there was something orange gleaming there. It seemed to pulse, as though it were some monstrous heart. The only reason she had seen it was because the area it was resting in was overshadowed by the restaurant next door.</p><p class="indented double">Pinkie approached the thing cautiously, almost expecting an attack. But nothing happened. Whatever it was just sat there, like it had been casually tossed aside. The infiltrator in training stopped a short distance away, her head titled quizzically. It looked like nothing she had ever seen before. She stood like that for a long time, observing it. Little strands or darker red-orange snaked across the object\xe2\x80\x99s surface, almost like veins. It was the size of a small watermelon. And all the time she stared at it, it never stopped pulsing. Finally, Pinkie inched forward slowly. As she did so, she began to notice the heat. It grew slightly in intensity as she approached closer, though it never got unbearable. Finally, tentatively, Pinkie reached out a hoof and brushed the strange thing. It was warm, quite warm, but not hot enough to burn. It almost felt as though it was cooling off after whatever it had been used for. </p><p class="indented double">Pinkie lifted the round object up carefully, but the even closer inspection did not reveal any secrets to her. Hesitating for but a moment, the mare pulled open one of the saddlebags she had strapped to her sides. The thing just barely fit inside, filling the dark space with bright orange light. She waited for a moment, ensuring that whatever this was would not burn through her bag. Then, satisfied that the evidence was secure, she carefully made her way back towards her infiltration point. Pinkie didn\xe2\x80\x99t know if this odd object had caused the fire here or not, but Zecora would want to see it. The zebra might even actually know what it was.</p><p class="double"><center>&lt;&lt;((*))&gt;&gt;</center></p><p class="indented double">Spitfire had barely taken a seat behind her slightly cluttered desk before the Soarin and Fleetfoot entered. While they settled themselves, Spitfire reached off to one side and grabbed a jug of ale sitting there. She took a quick swig of the drink to clear her thoughts before she turned to regard her two officers. The commander folded her forehooves before her as she awaited the inevitable question. It was Soarin who spoke first.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cSo, you saw it. What do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d Spitfire moved to set the jug of ale on the surface before her, making a simple gesture. Soarin nodded in thanks and took a quick swig before passing it off to Fleetfoot, eyes slowly wandering around the room. Soarin had only been in Spitfire\xe2\x80\x99s office once or twice, and each time it really amazed him at how spartan it was. Other high ranking officers used their important status to decorate rather lavishly, but that simply wasn\xe2\x80\x99t how Spitfire did things. She was efficient and practical, and the surroundings drove home the point.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cI saw it,\xe2\x80\x9d Fleetfoot said. \xe2\x80\x9cWasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure if I did at first, but I saw it all right.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire shook her head. \xe2\x80\x9cYou both only saw it once. They were doing it the entire time. At first I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t even pinpoint why the rhythm seemed off. I was watching the overall drill, and not looking at specific areas. It took me a few minutes to hone in on where it was coming from, and then I watched them repeat those moves for several minutes before you became aware of it yourself, Soarin.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the only instance?\xe2\x80\x9d the male pegasus sounded as if he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t decide what emotion he wanted to feel.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t. And it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t just that drill set, either. Each drill you called out, no matter which one it was, they were adding an extra little move that could potentially have devastating effects if put into actual use.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Fleetfoot frowned slightly. \xe2\x80\x9cOkay, I kind of expect something like this from Dash. But Flitter? I mean, she\xe2\x80\x99s a good recruit, but I just can\xe2\x80\x99t see her instinctively doing something like that.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cIt was because Dash was teaching it to Flitter subconsciously. If I were to hazard a guess, Dash is going to make a very good leader someday in the near future.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cBut is that even possible? Teaching a move to somepony else without actually pausing to explain what was going on?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire shrugged slightly. \xe2\x80\x9cAll I know is what I saw. Unless Dash has been coaching Flitter outside of drill practice, it was all instinctual-- like Dash was the leader and Flitter was the follower. Dash is commander material. Plain and simple.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cLike you?\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin asked, an eyebrow arched subtly.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cYes, like me.\xe2\x80\x9d came the steady reply. Spitfire held the gazes of her officers, unflinching.</p><p class="indented double">Fleetfoot seemed to be hesitating with her next words. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think its because of her ties to\xe2\x80\xa6 well\xe2\x80\xa6. you-know-what?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Spitfire paused to actually consider the question, before the reply: \xe2\x80\x9cYes. There could be other reasons, but this is the one that makes the most sense. But to Inspire others so easily\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9c... She\xe2\x80\x99s going to be even more powerful than you were at the height of your power.\xe2\x80\x9d Soarin finished for his commanding officer.</p><p class="indented double">\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly. The signs are there. The best we can actually do right now is coach her as best we can. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let her realize that there is something unique about her. She\xe2\x80\x99s got to come into this slowly, or she risks becoming corrupt. And we <i>all</i> know what happened last time, even if you two weren\xe2\x80\x99t here for it. Now, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you both have duties to attend to. Return to them, and remember: Keep quiet about this to everypony. You\xe2\x80\x99re both not supposed to know half of what you do, but I trust you. You\xe2\x80\x99re dismissed.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="indented double">Soarin and Fleetfoot both saluted, touching their right hooves to their left aligned Wonderbolt pins. Then the two lesser officers turned smartly and left Spitfire alone with her thoughts.</p><p class="indented double"></p><p></b></u></i></span></center></blockquote></p>\t</body>\n</html>', 'values': ["//------------------------------//\n// Chapter 8// Story: Valkyrie// by Flicka Ravenhide//------------------------------//\n\n\tCommander Spitfire leaned against the oak fence surrounding the practice area, keeping an eye on her newest recruits. She pawed the turf with a forehoof thoughtfully. There were a grand total of twenty six new Cadets this year. All of them were completely green behind the ears, but in time, they\xe2\x80\x99d all make fine Wonderbolts. Well, except for one. The familiar chromatic mane stood out glaringly from the rest of the Cadets, practically screaming, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m different!\xe2\x80\x9d. Spitfire had meant what she had told her Princess. Before long, Rainbow Dash could easily take over Spitfire\xe2\x80\x99s position, if the Commander ever decided to retire. However, that abrupt turn of thoughts made her smile wryly. Her, retire? The thought was preposterous. Commander Spitfire has been commanding officer of the entire Wonderbolt military division for the past thousand years at least, and it would probably be several thousand more before she would be spent. That thought, naturally, led to yet another. Such a long timespan, to be in service to Equestria and her beloved Princess. Once upon a time, it had been more than one Princess she had served\xe2\x80\xa6 And as soon as she had that thought, Spitfire mentally slapped herself and buried the painful memories yet again. She really needed to get her mind to stop wandering like that.\r\n\r\n\tSpitfire forced herself to return back to idly watching her Cadets. They had each split off into pairs, sparring with each other. Each was dressed in a light chainmail tunic, heavy padded helm, and had wooden taloned caps on their hooves. Eventually, the recruits would progress to drilling with actual hoof caps-- albeit with blunted edges and points, and then later would choose the weapon they planned to master. But that was still some months away, by which time the less suitable recruits would have been weeded out. It was quite normal for at least a third of Wonderbolt applicants to drop out of the harsh training in the first three months. Sometimes it was the pegasus\xe2\x80\x99 choice. For others, it was at the discretion of his or her instructors or, in extreme cases, Spitfire herself. The Wonderbolts were harsh and standards were strict. They had to be. The practice yard rang with the thudding of wood against wood. At the head of the yard, Captain Soarin called the standard strokes that were being practiced. As he called out the sequence, one Cadet would administer the attacks while the other blocked them. Then, when Soarin started the same sequence over, the second Cadet would deliver while the first blocked.\r\n\r\n\tFive third-year cadets, under the direction of Lieutenant Fleetfoot, moved among the pegasi, attending to the detail of the basic hoof strikes: correcting a wrong movement here, changing the angle of a stroke there, making sure another recruit\xe2\x80\x99s caps weren\xe2\x80\x99t dropping too far as he or she struck. It was rather repetitive work under the glaring hot sun, but it was necessary. These drills might be what decides if a Wonderbolt lives or dies at some later point. These basic moves needed to be instinctual, plain and simple.\r\n\r\n\tIt was actually with this thought in mind that Spitfire once more found her eyes returning to Rainbow Dash and her sparring partner, a promising young filly named Flitter.
