It came with a slight fragrance of apple, \nreminiscent of days long past, napping in trees, casual chats about \nnothing with Applejack, thinking to the future. It\xe2\x80\x99d been a while since \none of those chats; they\xe2\x80\x99d stopped as soon as Rainbow had deemed them \xe2\x80\x98Too embarrassing\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d And yet, what\xe2\x80\x99d they replaced these times with? \nStunted, difficult words, exchanged in fleeted meetings. Just because of one night. \n\nMaybe that was one other thing Rainbow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t control: Friendship.\n\nRainbow moved her fore hooves up onto the windowsill, ready to take off, out of\n the window, but the papery feel beneath her right hoof made her think \notherwise. She looked down at the paper, and lifted her hoof up. Folded,\n it was adorned with \xe2\x80\x98Dash\xe2\x80\x99, in scruffy, yet attemptedly careful \nwriting.\n\nRainbow felt her stomach twist, she knew whose hoofwriting this was, and with \nwhat premise it was probably written after, yet still, she unfolded the \nletter as quickly as possible. After all, Rainbow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t bear to not \nknow.\n\nDash,\n\nI knew you\xe2\x80\x99d try to climb out the window, and pretend like nothing \nhappened, but I\xe2\x80\x99m hoping a loyal pony like yourself would realise that \ntheir friend needs them, and change their mind?\nWe really need to talk, but y\xe2\x80\x99know, like a proper talk. Not an \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s 3AM, \nI\xe2\x80\x99m really drunk and decided to break into Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom\xe2\x80\x99 talk.\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll be out applebucking; I\xe2\x80\x99m on a tight schedule, but come and talk to me. I can always take time out to see you.\n\nYou really did say do some interesting things last night. \n\n-That \xe2\x80\x98Other\xe2\x80\x99 Filly\n\n(Thanks for the new nickname, by the way\xe2\x80\xa6) \n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Celestia.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIf there wasn\xe2\x80\x99t such a cooling breeze, Rainbow would\xe2\x80\x99ve probably burned up and melted, right on the spot.\n\n\n\n*****\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6light?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwilight?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwilight?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nOn the uncouth awakening of having her own name shouted in her ear, it was\n obvious Twilight was going to be unhappy, but surprisingly, that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\n what had garnered the most of her early-morning contempt. What had been\n bestowed with that award was, in fact, the overall wet, ice-cold \nfeeling that surrounded her body. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwilight, why were you sleeping in the bathtub?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWithout opening her eyes, Twilight responded, groggily.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be silly, Spike, I\xe2\x80\x99m just a bit cold, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Now, if you just pass me my blanket, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to go back to sleep\xe2\x80\xa6 I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel too good.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUhh, Twi\xe2\x80\x99? Don\xe2\x80\x99t go all \xe2\x80\x98Pinkie Pie\xe2\x80\x99 on me; you\xe2\x80\x99re definitely in the bathtub.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nTwilight opened her eyes, and was met with a slightly pink-stained white, taking up her peripheries. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh.\xe2\x80\x9d \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, Twilight?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nTwilight was most definitely in the bathtub, she knew that much. However, \nfurther from that, she knew nothing. She remembered walking home, after a\n night out with Rainbow Dash, and then\xe2\x80\xa6\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwilight, are you okay?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe pony braced herself, and then put what seemed like far, far\n too much effort into lifting her body out of the chilled, pink-y \nconcoction. Although despising the effort put into the task of standing \nup, Twilight still took it upon herself to shake the blood infused water\n across the bathroom, and across her assistant, Spike.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUgh, Twilight! You\xe2\x80\x99ve been soaking in that! I don\xe2\x80\x99t want it on me!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNevertheless, Twilight, now dry, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t really fussed about her assistant\xe2\x80\x99s wellbeing. She had other things on her mind, other fillies\xe2\x80\xa6\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Rainbow\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwilight, you mean Spike, right?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nTwilight felt a light blush across herself; she hadn\xe2\x80\x99t said that out loud, had she?\n\n \xe2\x80\x9cYes, Spike.\xe2\x80\x9d\n Twilight tried to speak with an air of authority, but her voice was \nfailing, under assault from the memories from the previous night. Well, \nthe ones she could still remember.\n\nTwilight stepped out of the bathtub, onto the well-streaked tiles of the floor. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpike, you know how you\xe2\x80\x99re my number one assistant?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSpike groaned; he knew what was coming next.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYeah, yeah, I\xe2\x80\x99ll clean the bathroom for you.\xe2\x80\x9d \n\nTwilight could hear the dejectedness in Spike\xe2\x80\x99s voice, but she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t too \nfussed, she knew he\xe2\x80\x99d bounce back. After all, he really was a fantastic \nassistant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks Spike!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nTwilight spun around on the spot, turning to face the doorway. As she lifted her\n hooves, she left pale red marks upon the tiles, adding colour to the \nonce labyrinthine lines traced, the night before. \n\nTwilight could think clearly, now. There was colour to her thoughts, and colour on her mind.\n\nAs she walked out into the library, everything looked a little brighter. \nThe shelves, once imposing, stifling the library with their books, no \nlonger seemed to oppress, to demand silence. Now, they stood for \npossibilities, for opportunities, each one different. However, none of \nthe hundreds of possibilities that surrounded Twilight could have been \nanywhere near negative. \nLife was just too fantastic.\n\nAs a breeze swept in, through an open window, Twilight thought to herself; about friends, about friendship, about Rainbow Dash. \n\nShe wondered, \xe2\x80\x98All this time, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been studying friendship, and nothing has ever felt quite this fantastic. Is this true friendship?\xe2\x80\x99 \n\nEven though Rainbow had left her during the night, Twilight was sure she\xe2\x80\x99d \nhad an important reason, after all, she was the most loyal pony in all \nof Equestria, and more importantly; she was her friend, and Twilight believed in her.\n\n \xe2\x80\x9cRainbow, I just can\xe2\x80\x99t wait to see you; we have so much to talk about\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n*****\n\n\nThe view across the apple orchard was beautiful, from on top of Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s\n old hill. It was good for thinking, and for reminiscing, after all, it \nheld a lot of memories, for Applejack, at least.\n\nLost in the scent of freshly bucked trees, and their bruised bark, \nApplejack\xe2\x80\x99s mind began to drift, to the thoughts that lay within her. \nThey\xe2\x80\x99d happened so long ago, and yet, they seemed so vivid; almost \npelt-deep.\n\nEven though Granny Smith had told her otherwise, so many times, she\xe2\x80\x99d taken \nshelter under Bloomberg, during a sudden thunderstorm. It was odd; \ngetting caught in such rainstorms was commonplace, for somepony that \nworks on a farm, but for some reason, Applejack felt bothered by it.\n\nShe still wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure why, despite the amount of times she\xe2\x80\x99d been through \nthe events in her head. In the end, it didn\xe2\x80\x99t really matter, these \nthings weren\xe2\x80\x99t really the reason Applejack constantly replayed these \nmemories.\n\nIt was: when a dripping wet rainbow fell from the skies, streaked with tears, shaking, sobbing.\n\n\n Applejack had said nothing to the poor filly; they just sat, in a \ntrembling, yet compassionate embrace, nuzzling, tears soaking into her \nback. It was Dash who\xe2\x80\x99d done the talking, but it was nothing like Dash\xe2\x80\x99s\n usual, cocky speech. It was so very real.\n\nReal problems, real thoughts, real feelings.\n\nApplejack had been fine, up until that point. She liked that Dash could trust \nher, depend on her, after all the years of their banter-esqe \nrelationship. She\xe2\x80\x99d finally opened up,\n and Applejack was glad for that. Of all ponies, Applejack knew better \nthan to handle things by herself, but there was no telling Dash that. It\n was a good thing she\xe2\x80\x99d come to that conclusion herself.\n\nStill, as strong as Applejack tried to be for Dash, the next thing she said had caught her off guard. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cApplejack\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nEven looking back on it, Applejack felt embarrassed. However, that feeling was always overwhelmed by another, every time. \n \n\xe2\x80\x9cI think\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nOverwhelmed by confusion.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I l\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nConfusion, tinged with sadness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLove you\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nApplejack felt the trio of emotions inundate her, as if she was reliving the memory, of that rainy eve, on Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy\xe2\x80\x99d yew have ta go and puzzle me so, Dash? You toying with me or something?\xe2\x80\x9d \n\nApplejack frowned through her sad, embarrassed confusion. One minute Dash was \nfighting with her, over even the most trivial things, the next? Dash \nwould be on top of her, crying into her arms once more, as if they never\n argued, as if all Applejack were was just a friendly face in the dark, somewhere to dump her emotions.\n\nApplejack sighed, and thought to herself. \xe2\x80\x98I guess that\xe2\x80\x99s what y\xe2\x80\x99all get for being the most dependable pony in Ponyville, huh?\xe2\x80\x99\n\n\n\n*****\n\n\nRainbow Dash didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like flying. Her heart wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in it. \n\nIt was elsewhere, occupied, gone.\n Rainbow Dash slowly trotted up in-between the rows of carefully planted\n apple trees, towards where she thought it lay; in the hooves of that other filly, at the top of Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill.\n\nRainbow shook her head, a desperate attempt to try to understand what was \nhappening. Everything she had, everything she\xe2\x80\x99d made, albeit \naccidentally, was falling apart. \n\nIt\xe2\x80\x99d been fantastic, even if it had only been a choice few evenings, shrouded in rain, teary-eyed.\n\nIf only she had another reason to spend time like that with her. Nopony else could know, after all, Dash had to be cool.\n\nRainbow gulped, and continued her slow, pained walk, up to Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill, two thoughts reverberating around her mind.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have I done?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do I have to be cool?\xe2\x80\x9d\n', 5, 41, '<html>\n\t<head>\n\t\t<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head>\n\t</head>\n\t<body>\n\t\t<h1><a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/story/15/with-a-heavy-heart">With a Heavy Heart</a></h1>\n\t\t<h2>by <a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/user/Krypqe">Krypqe</a></h2>\n\n\t\t<hr />\n\n\t\t<a name=\'5\'></a><h3>Mechanisms</h3>\n<p>Rainbow felt pain, coursing through her body. Only aching within her legs and </p><p>wings, it was mainly concentrated upon her head. It was as if somepony </p><p>had tried to dig into her brain. Even if it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t so; it still felt </p><p>that way.</p><p class="double">As much as Rainbow tried to shut it out, she could see the warm light </p><p>through her eyelids; there was no way she could pretend it was still </p><p>night. As much as she respected Princess Celestia, Rainbow wished she </p><p>hadn\xe2\x80\x99t brought the day about so soon.</p><p class="double">Rainbow hauled her eyelids open, tentatively, easing her eyes into the bright </p><p>morning light.&nbsp;&nbsp;She looked over at the open window, and watched the </p><p>piercing sunlight, reflecting off of flecks of dust, swirling around, </p><p>forming dappled, complex patterns, seemingly restless. </p><p class="double">The ground was hard against Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s hindquarters, as she sat up, trying </p><p>to shrug the aches off of her back. She stretched her back out, fore </p><p>hooves reaching up to the clouds. Or rather, the ceiling.</p><p class="double">Rainbow felt dizzy, for a moment, her vision slowly, but only partially leaving her for a second. Her home was made of clouds, not ceilings, windows and hard, wooden floors\xe2\x80\xa6 Where was she?</p><p class="double">She looked around slowly, being kind to her over-sensitive eyes. The </p><p>floorboards looked rough, untreated. Rainbow swept her hoof across them;</p><p> they felt rough, yet worn; devoid of splinters. </p><p class="double">The walls were also wooden, but seemed more reassuringly smooth, but </p><p>Rainbow supposed that it could have just been to do with the fact that </p><p>the walls were just further away than the floor, but she decided to stop thinking of further complexities; it was the morning, after all. </p><p class="double">Rainbow stretched her forelegs out once more, and decided to brave standing up.</p><p> She grudgingly lifted her body off of the ground, and whilst arching </p><p>her back, she spread her wings out, extending from tip to tip, cutting </p><p>through the dust-laden air. Slowly, wings folding away, she clopped </p><p>towards the window, the window with apple-print curtains. </p><p>Rainbow realised where she was, moments before the view of the Sweet Apple </p><p>Acres\xe2\x80\x99 apple orchard came into view.&nbsp;&nbsp;She\xe2\x80\x99d spent the night at Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\xa6</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Celestia\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d Rainbow groaned, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you do last night, Dash?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow stood there, for a while, letting the tiniest of breezes wash over her,</p><p> airing her stale, matted mane. Rainbow was clearing her thoughts, or </p><p>attempting to, at least. She let a groan out into the quiet voice of the</p><p> wind.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x98I think I just need to go\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x99</p><p> Rainbow thought. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t an easy decision to make, after all, things </p><p>with Applejack were tenuous at best, and whatever had happened last </p><p>night, well, it probably didn\xe2\x80\x99t help their relations all that much at all. Although she wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t admit it, Rainbow knew all too well what she was like after a few drinks\xe2\x80\xa6</p><p class="double">Things would probably be better after she\xe2\x80\x99d mulled them over a bit, and Rainbow really didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to drum up any awkward conversation between herself and Applejack; she had problem enough thinking about that sort of stuff, let alone talking. </p><p class="double">Rainbow pushed against the window\xe2\x80\x99s frame, exposing herself to the fullness of </p><p>the farm\xe2\x80\x99s calm breeze. It came with a slight fragrance of apple, </p><p>reminiscent of days long past, napping in trees, casual chats about </p><p>nothing with Applejack, thinking to the future. It\xe2\x80\x99d been a while since </p><p>one of those chats; they\xe2\x80\x99d stopped as soon as Rainbow had deemed them \xe2\x80\x98Too embarrassing\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d And yet, what\xe2\x80\x99d they replaced these times with? </p><p>Stunted, difficult words, exchanged in fleeted meetings. Just because of one night. </p><p class="double">Maybe that was one other thing Rainbow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t control: Friendship.</p><p class="double">Rainbow moved her fore hooves up onto the windowsill, ready to take off, out of</p><p> the window, but the papery feel beneath her right hoof made her think </p><p>otherwise. She looked down at the paper, and lifted her hoof up. Folded,</p><p> it was adorned with \xe2\x80\x98Dash\xe2\x80\x99, in scruffy, yet attemptedly careful </p><p>writing.</p><p class="double">Rainbow felt her stomach twist, she knew whose hoofwriting this was, and with </p><p>what premise it was probably written after, yet still, she unfolded the </p><p>letter as quickly as possible. After all, Rainbow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t bear to not </p><p>know.</p><p class="double"><i>Dash,</p><p class="double">I knew you\xe2\x80\x99d try to climb out the window, and pretend like nothing </p><p>happened, but I\xe2\x80\x99m hoping a loyal pony like yourself would realise that </p><p>their friend needs them, and change their mind?</p><p>We really need to talk, but y\xe2\x80\x99know, like a proper talk. Not an \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s 3AM, </p><p>I\xe2\x80\x99m really drunk and decided to break into Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom\xe2\x80\x99 talk.</p><p>I\xe2\x80\x99ll be out applebucking; I\xe2\x80\x99m on a tight schedule, but come and talk to me. I can always take time out to see you.</p><p class="double">You really did say do some interesting things last night. </p><p class="double">-That \xe2\x80\x98Other\xe2\x80\x99 Filly</p><p class="double">(Thanks for the new nickname, by the way\xe2\x80\xa6) </i></p><p class="double"></p><p>\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Celestia.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">If there wasn\xe2\x80\x99t such a cooling breeze, Rainbow would\xe2\x80\x99ve probably burned up and melted, right on the spot.</p></p><br /><p><p class="double">*****</p><p class="double"></p><p>\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6light?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cTwilight?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cTwilight?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">On the uncouth awakening of having her own name shouted in her ear, it was</p><p> obvious Twilight was going to be unhappy, but surprisingly, that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t</p><p> what had garnered the most of her early-morning contempt. Is this true friendship?\xe2\x80\x99 </p><p class="double">Even though Rainbow had left her during the night, Twilight was sure she\xe2\x80\x99d </p><p>had an important reason, after all, she was the most loyal pony in all </p><p>of Equestria, and more importantly; she was her friend, and Twilight believed in her.</p><p class="double"> \xe2\x80\x9cRainbow, I just can\xe2\x80\x99t wait to see you; we have so much to talk about\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p></p><br /><p><p class="double">*****</p><p class="double"></p><p>The view across the apple orchard was beautiful, from on top of Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s</p><p> old hill. Only aching within her legs and \nwings, it was mainly concentrated upon her head. It was as if somepony \nhad tried to dig into her brain. Even if it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t so; it still felt \nthat way.\n\nAs much as Rainbow tried to shut it out, she could see the warm light \nthrough her eyelids; there was no way she could pretend it was still \nnight. As much as she respected Princess Celestia, Rainbow wished she \nhadn\xe2\x80\x99t brought the day about so soon.\n\nRainbow hauled her eyelids open, tentatively, easing her eyes into the bright \nmorning light.  She looked over at the open window, and watched the \npiercing sunlight, reflecting off of flecks of dust, swirling around, \nforming dappled, complex patterns, seemingly restless. \n\nThe ground was hard against Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s hindquarters, as she sat up, trying \nto shrug the aches off of her back. She stretched her back out, fore \nhooves reaching up to the clouds. Or rather, the ceiling.\n\nRainbow felt dizzy, for a moment, her vision slowly, but only partially leaving her for a second. Her home was made of clouds, not ceilings, windows and hard, wooden floors\xe2\x80\xa6 Where was she?\n\nShe looked around slowly, being kind to her over-sensitive eyes. The \nfloorboards looked rough, untreated. Rainbow swept her hoof across them;\n they felt rough, yet worn; devoid of splinters. \n\nThe walls were also wooden, but seemed more reassuringly smooth, but \nRainbow supposed that it could have just been to do with the fact that \nthe walls were just further away than the floor, but she decided to stop thinking of further complexities; it was the morning, after all. \n\nRainbow stretched her forelegs out once more, and decided to brave standing up.\n She grudgingly lifted her body off of the ground, and whilst arching \nher back, she spread her wings out, extending from tip to tip, cutting \nthrough the dust-laden air. Slowly, wings folding away, she clopped \ntowards the window, the window with apple-print curtains. \nRainbow realised where she was, moments before the view of the Sweet Apple \nAcres\xe2\x80\x99 apple orchard came into view.  She\xe2\x80\x99d spent the night at Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\xa6\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Celestia\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d Rainbow groaned, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you do last night, Dash?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow stood there, for a while, letting the tiniest of breezes wash over her,\n airing her stale, matted mane. Rainbow was clearing her thoughts, or \nattempting to, at least. It came with a slight fragrance of apple, \nreminiscent of days long past, napping in trees, casual chats about \nnothing with Applejack, thinking to the future. Well, \nthe ones she could still remember.\n\nTwilight stepped out of the bathtub, onto the well-streaked tiles of the floor. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpike, you know how you\xe2\x80\x99re my number one assistant?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSpike groaned; he knew what was coming next.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYeah, yeah, I\xe2\x80\x99ll clean the bathroom for you.\xe2\x80\x9d \n\nTwilight could hear the dejectedness in Spike\xe2\x80\x99s voice, but she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t too \nfussed, she knew he\xe2\x80\x99d bounce back. There was colour to her thoughts, and colour on her mind.\n\nAs she walked out into the library, everything looked a little brighter. \nThe shelves, once imposing, stifling the library with their books, no \nlonger seemed to oppress, to demand silence. Now, they stood for \npossibilities, for opportunities, each one different. However, none of \nthe hundreds of possibilities that surrounded Twilight could have been \nanywhere near negative. \nLife was just too fantastic.\n\nAs a breeze swept in, through an open window, Twilight thought to herself; about friends, about friendship, about Rainbow Dash. \n\nShe wondered, \xe2\x80\x98All this time, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been studying friendship, and nothing has ever felt quite this fantastic. It was odd; \ngetting caught in such rainstorms was commonplace, for somepony that \nworks on a farm, but for some reason, Applejack felt bothered by it.\n\nShe still wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure why, despite the amount of times she\xe2\x80\x99d been through \nthe events in her head. In the end, it didn\xe2\x80\x99t really matter, these \nthings weren\xe2\x80\x99t really the reason Applejack constantly replayed these \nmemories.\n\nIt was: when a dripping wet rainbow fell from the skies, streaked with tears, shaking, sobbing.\n\n\n Applejack had said nothing to the poor filly; they just sat, in a \ntrembling, yet compassionate embrace, nuzzling, tears soaking into her \nback. It was Dash who\xe2\x80\x99d done the talking, but it was nothing like Dash\xe2\x80\x99s\n usual, cocky speech. She liked that Dash could trust \nher, depend on her, after all the years of their banter-esqe \nrelationship. She\xe2\x80\x99d finally opened up,\n and Applejack was glad for that. With each tree she passed, her mind wandered more and more \ntowards Applejack, and what Rainbow had said to her. \nNot that Rainbow really remembered.\nApplejack\xe2\x80\x99s letter had jogged her memory a tad, and the wound upon Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head \nhad helped it on its way, but it still wasn\xe2\x80\x99t all there.\n\nShe remembered about Twilight and herself, almost begrudgingly. However, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t remembering the events that jarred Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s mind so. It was her own thoughts and feelings. \nThoughts and feelings that nopony could really synthesise, even in \nretrospect. They were very much real.\n\nFrom Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s experience, she only knew these feelings from a tiny amount \nof night encounters before, but all from the same place.\n\nA place which now, seemed only to be foreshadowed with doubt, despite its open, airy atmosphere.\n\nBloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill.\n\n\n*****\n\n\nTwilight was sprawled out on her sofa, happy, merely through just existing. She \nexhaled, in a long sigh, finally relaxed after her night on cold enamel \nand water.\n\nOn breathing back in, Twilight noticed a slight odour. One that was \nsomewhat familiar, yet alien, to the library at least. She moved her \ngaze down, and against the white fabric of the sofa, Twilight saw faint,\n pale fibres. Curiously, Twilight brought her head down to the fabric, \nand gave it a quick, speculative sniff. \nTwilight knew that was quite unscientific, and could be considered as odd,\n but in the situation, she\xe2\x80\x99d decided it was the right thing to do. \nBesides, nopony was in the library with her, so nopony else would know \nto be able to call it odd. Not that she would have minded, anyway.\n\nAfter a couple of minutes, Twilight realised what was so familiar about the \nscent, after all, she\xe2\x80\x99d spent a good part of the night before engulfed \nin it. The scent had caressed her, surrounded her and been with her.\n\nTwilight lightly pushed her face into the sofa\xe2\x80\x99s cushions, and inhaled as deeply\n as she could, swimming in the memories of Rainbow and herself. Yet, as \nshe was deepest in thought, she involuntarily broke down into a fit of \nchildish giggles. \n\xe2\x80\x98Wow, Twilight\xe2\x80\x99 she thought to herself. \xe2\x80\x98That really was odd\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x99\n\nRegardless, Twilight just immersed herself in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s scent once more. She\xe2\x80\x99d \noften wondered why everypony in romance novels did things like this; \njust sitting, thinking about their loved ones, inhaling their scent. \n\nNow, though, things were different.\n\nPerhaps, like in those books, she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t odd, but she was in love.\n\nTwilight inhaled another gasp of Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s scent, and filled her thoughts with \nthe pegasus. Nopony had ever quite shone in this sort of light to \nTwilight before, and so, she intended to make the most of it.\nAfter all, it felt good.\n\n\n*****\n\n\nApplejack had been laid out on Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill for quite some time now, \nexasperated. Not that she minded the location, but she really had to get\n back to work on the farm.  She was the most dependable pony in Ponyville, and knew she really should get back to bucking, but\xe2\x80\xa6\nApplejack didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like doing anything.\n\nNot out of laziness, Applejack was far from lazy, and she knew it; but somehow, that made it worse.\nHowever, her disdain for it did nothing to counteract it. The one thing that \ngave Applejack solace was that at least she knew what was causing her \nlistlessness.\n\nLight hoof-fall began to puncture the murmuring soundscape of rustling leaves\n and light breeze, and with each muffled clop, Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts \nbegan to run amok. She was painting situations in her head, some more \nbrash, whilst others were tenderer.\n\nApplejack knew it was silly, but she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stop acting the scenes out in the safety of her own mind.\nShe could get the words just right in there.\n\nThere was a modest sound of setting down, beside her, and Applejack, still with her eyes firmly closed, knew who was there.\n\nShe heard a sigh. Not one of exasperation, but a long, drawn out sigh of relief. Applejack found it reassuring.\n\nShe laid there, basking in the sunlight, alongside her counterpart, just \ndoing nothing, just revelling in her company. Applejack would have liked\n it to stay that way, Rainbow and herself, just sat around. Applejack \ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t even have to open her eyes to acknowledge Dash; they both knew \nthat presence was merely enough.\nYet, Dash didn\xe2\x80\x99t make that possible. She had to keep up the whole \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99 charade. They couldn\xe2\x80\x99t just bask in the ambience of Equestria, not when other ponies were around. \n\nDash was so intent on keeping their \xe2\x80\x98rivalry\xe2\x80\x99 up, that it seemed to be \nclouding over what they had between them.  Applejack wished, even though\n she thought it a bit foalish to do so, but she still wished. She wished\n that Dash could just learn to switch off.\nEven though Applejack had such feelings for her, Dash was starting to wear \non her patience. As time went on, more time, according to Dash, had to \nbe spent \xe2\x80\x98keeping up appearances\xe2\x80\x99.\n\nAs much as Applejack hated to have to lie to everypony, as the two of them put more and more effort into covering up, times like these became more and more precious. They came to mean \nmore than they ever used to.\nTimes when Applejack and Dash had nowhere to be, nothing to do. Just to be. \nTo be, but together.\n\nHowever, as much as Applejack wanted to dwell on such a seldom moment like this,\n she knew she had to break her much sought silence, and for a  conversation she didn\xe2\x80\x99t really want to start. In fact, Applejack was  quite sure, for a moment, at least, if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the element of  honesty, well\xe2\x80\xa6 She wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have even thought of starting a conversation about such a thing.\nEspecially when the obvious results weren\xe2\x80\x99t going to be something either pony engaged would have wanted, but Applejack knew what the right thing to do\n was. \nFor a moment, Applejack caught herself thinking.\n\xe2\x80\x98If only I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the element of Honesty.\xe2\x80\x99\n\nApplejacksighed, but unlike Dash\xe2\x80\x99s earlier sigh, it was an exasperated, annoyed \nsigh. Even though she was troubled with the fact that she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to  disown her own element, Applejack knew she was in the wrong, and she knew that if she could accept it already, her honesty wasn\xe2\x80\x99t far gone.\n\nNevertheless, this only accentuated Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s thought. This conversation needed to happen. If she was questioning her own element, well, that\xe2\x80\x99d be like questioning a cutie mark.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDash?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nApplejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was quiet, yet harsh, overshadowed by Dash\xe2\x80\x99s now increasing breaths. At least Applejack knew she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the only anxious pony.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat in tarnation was last night about, eh?\n\nApplejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was still hushed, yet not as quiet as it had been, she had Dash to contend with as well, now.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cApplejack, I-\xe2\x80\x9c\n\nDash cut herself short. Applejack wasn\xe2\x80\x99t surprised, she\xe2\x80\x99d sounded uncertain from the first letter of her name.\nApplejack opened her eyes, into the sunlight. Everything was bleached, shades of  white. She looked over her shoulder, at Dash, and smiled, even though  the rainbow pony looked so morose. \nIt was strange, seeing the majestic Dash in a whitened colourless format. \nIt was almost as if she was a different pony.\n\n\n*****\n\n\nRainbow Dash looked up to the sky.\n\nShe could feel the words she wanted to say, building up inside of her. Yet, none of them would come out, no matter how hard she coaxed them.  Rainbow was annoyed by this. It was almost as if she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t control  herself at all.\nIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t as bad when it had just been her wings that acted up, but now? Everything was moving too fast.\nNot in speed, of course, Rainbow was still the fastest, she was quite sure of that. It was just in everything else she did.\nIt was as if Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s life wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in her own hooves anymore. Seemingly, it belonged to everypony else. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDash, y\xe2\x80\x99know you can say anything to me, right?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow was still looking to the sky for answers.  She remembered the days in which she could just fly, not thinking about anything, just to move, and fast!\nThe sky had stayed the same since then, a place where a pony can be free, no worries, no thoughts. \nIt was funny, but upsetting. The sky, which had been her friend, was unable to help her, as it was free, emotionless.\n\nRainbow Dash levelled her gaze, and brought her eyes to meet Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s. As \nmuch as she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to stare away, and let time go on; Rainbow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\n just let Applejack hang like that. After all, it was her own fault.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just\xe2\x80\xa6 so sorry\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow felt her eyes begin to water, and a wave of melancholy hit her, with more force than she thought it would.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so sorry for what I said, and what I did\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nEven though it was an apology, it was bittersweet. For even though Rainbow \nknew she was saying the right thing, the right feelings weren\xe2\x80\x99t behind \nthem. Mainly, this was due to the fact that she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t really remember\n what she was apologising for.\n\nThere were things that Rainbow did remember, though. She remembered that the \nwhole night was shrouded by her own crestfallen state. She remembered \nsitting with Applejack, crying into her mane, and most of all, the \noverwhelming feeling of regret.\nOne particular image stuck in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head; the morose smile of a pony, one who looked let down, deceived. \nA pony with beautiful, green eyes. \nHowbeit, Rainbow didn\xe2\x80\x99t see them, not anymore, as they were clouded, hidden  behind a veil of emotion. Even though they tried to be honest, to be dependable, Rainbow knew them well. \nShe knew that they were anything but.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow gasped.\nThat was brash, even for Applejack.\n\nRainbow tried to keep her gaze locked with Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s, but the dampness of her\n own eyes forced her to look down at the ground, as she tried to regain \ncontrol of her own tear ducts.\n\nRainbow thought for a while. \n\xe2\x80\x98What about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x99\n\nTwilight was nice, and all. Well, she was very nice.\n\nInitially, Dash had thought that Twilight was boring, always buried in books, telling everypony \xe2\x80\x9cinteresting facts\xe2\x80\x9d, obsessed with learning. Dash was her friend; she just didn\xe2\x80\x99t like the things Twilight did.\n\nYet, over time, Twilight changed.\nNot completely. She still had a thirst for knowledge, as she probably \nalways would. In fact, it was probably that thirst for knowledge that \nchanged her; due to her study of friendship.\nTwilight had developed a whole new social side, and Rainbow liked it.\n\nHowever, Twilight still had much to learn, and Rainbow knew so. Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t that the reason she\xe2\x80\x99d asked Twilight to come out? \n\nFor Rainbow, it was nice to be the one teaching, for once. Not to be the \none in control, but to be able to help another pony, who\xe2\x80\x99d have complete\n faith in her, even if she only knew a little.\n\nIt was a nice change to how things with herself and Applejack went. They \nwere just stumbling around in the dark; neither pony had known how \nanything had \xe2\x80\x98worked\xe2\x80\x99, per se.\n\nIt\xe2\x80\x99d been uncertain, and each time spur of the moment, and that was fine, for Dash, at the time. After all, she was \xe2\x80\x98The Fastest Flier in all of Equestria,\xe2\x80\x99 and didn\xe2\x80\x99t have time for anything serious. \nNot that she\xe2\x80\x99d known what anything serious would have actually meant.\n\nHowever, Rainbow wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure if she wanted that anymore.\nShe wasn\xe2\x80\x99t even sure about herself anymore.\n\nEventhough her time with Twilight had been short and impulsive, much like the spurts of time she\xe2\x80\x99d spent with Applejack, Rainbow could see the start of something much more reliable with Twilight. \nReliable.\n\nWas that what she needed?\n\nWas that what she wanted?\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUhh\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow\xe2\x80\x99s voice still wavered, huskier than usual, the immersion in emotion taking its toll on her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6I need to go and think, Applejack.\xe2\x80\x9d\n    \nRainbow looked back towards Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s gaze, once more. Her green eyes were no longer just clouded. The clouds had burst, and begun to leak; two lines traced across the freckles that pockmarked her face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re always moving, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you? Why can\xe2\x80\x99t you just slow down?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nApplejack sounded hurt. It was as if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t trying to hide it now, her honesty shining bright, even when shrouded in upset.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you about it properly, Applejack\xe2\x80\xa6 but another time. \xe2\x80\x9c\n\nRainbow hated having to shirk such an important talk off, especially in one of the few times the two of them would normally so desperately strive to have. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI just need to sort my head out.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh can see that, Dash.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow passed an unhappy smile Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s way. She knew she needed to sort it out, but the words Applejack had fed back had hurt. \nBut Rainbow knew she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it. \nShe was the element of honesty.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you as soon as I\xe2\x80\x99ve worked it out\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow\xe2\x80\x99s words faltered, momentarily, and a thought lapsed up; \xe2\x80\x98Was that really the best thing to say?\xe2\x80\x99\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow felt her chest tighten.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow stood up, rather more quickly than she meant to, and with the biggest  trace of a reassuring smile as she could muster, she turned away from  Applejack, and began the decent from Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill, step by step, down between the apple trees, letting their swaying branches\xe2\x80\x99 sounds engulf her once more.\n\nRainbow Dash just didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to fly.', 'chapter_number': 6, 'parent_chapter_id': 56, 'chapter_html': '<html>\n\t<head>\n\t\t<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head>\n\t</head>\n\t<body>\n\t\t<h1><a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/story/15/with-a-heavy-heart">With a Heavy Heart</a></h1>\n\t\t<h2>by <a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/user/Krypqe">Krypqe</a></h2>\n\n\t\t<hr />\n\n\t\t<a name=\'6\'></a><h3>With You</h3>\n<p>Chills surrounded Rainbow Dash.</p><p>Chills of temperature, and chills of doubt.</p><p class="double">Rainbow had never really experienced doubt before; she was a confident, strong, \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99 pony. </p><p>Only twice had she done so, yet her previous experiences still hadn\xe2\x80\x99t </p><p>managed to shirk the way it smothered her. Nor did it lessen the blow on</p><p> her insides; lurching around with every contemplation of every possible</p><p> eventuality.</p><p class="double">She\xe2\x80\x99d thought that the somewhat scenic walk through the apple orchards </p><p>coating Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill would be able to calm her, to ease her angst, </p><p>yet, as Rainbow increased in her altitude, she got further and further </p><p>away from what felt safe. Rainbow thought this was odd, as she\xe2\x80\x99d </p><p>normally feel at ease rushing up through the clouds, engulfed in their </p><p>strangely comforting, soft, ethereal feel. Nevertheless, now, they </p><p>didn\xe2\x80\x99t emanate any positive vibes at all; the cool positivity now seemed</p><p> like cold, sad detachment. That\xe2\x80\x99s what Rainbow thought, anyway.</p><p>Perhaps she was spending too much time with earth ponies.</p><p class="double">The systematic abundance of the apple trees didn\xe2\x80\x99t help Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s state of </p><p>mind either. With each tree she passed, her mind wandered more and more </p><p>towards Applejack, and what Rainbow had said to her. </p><p>Not that Rainbow really remembered.</p><p>Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s letter had jogged her memory a tad, and the wound upon Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head </p><p>had helped it on its way, but it still wasn\xe2\x80\x99t all there.</p><p class="double">She remembered about Twilight and herself, almost begrudgingly. However, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t remembering the events that jarred Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s mind so. It was her own thoughts and feelings. </p><p>Thoughts and feelings that nopony could really synthesise, even in </p><p>retrospect. They were very much real.</p><p class="double">From Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s experience, she only knew these feelings from a tiny amount </p><p>of night encounters before, but all from the same place.</p><p class="double">A place which now, seemed only to be foreshadowed with doubt, despite its open, airy atmosphere.</p><p class="double">Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill.</p><p class="double"></p><p>*****</p><p class="double"></p><p>Twilight was sprawled out on her sofa, happy, merely through just existing. She </p><p>exhaled, in a long sigh, finally relaxed after her night on cold enamel </p><p>and water.</p><p class="double">On breathing back in, Twilight noticed a slight odour. One that was </p><p>somewhat familiar, yet alien, to the library at least. She moved her </p><p>gaze down, and against the white fabric of the sofa, Twilight saw faint,</p><p> pale fibres. Curiously, Twilight brought her head down to the fabric, </p><p>and gave it a quick, speculative sniff. </p><p>Twilight knew that was quite unscientific, and could be considered as odd,</p><p> but in the situation, she\xe2\x80\x99d decided it was the right thing to do. </p><p>Besides, nopony was in the library with her, so nopony else would know </p><p>to be able to call it odd. Not that she would have minded, anyway.</p><p class="double">After a couple of minutes, Twilight realised what was so familiar about the </p><p>scent, after all, she\xe2\x80\x99d spent a good part of the night before engulfed </p><p>in it. The scent had caressed her, surrounded her and been with her.</p><p class="double">Twilight lightly pushed her face into the sofa\xe2\x80\x99s cushions, and inhaled as deeply</p><p> as she could, swimming in the memories of Rainbow and herself. Yet, as </p><p>she was deepest in thought, she involuntarily broke down into a fit of </p><p>childish giggles. </p><p>\xe2\x80\x98Wow, Twilight\xe2\x80\x99 she thought to herself. \xe2\x80\x98That really was odd\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">Regardless, Twilight just immersed herself in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s scent once more. Nopony had ever quite shone in this sort of light to </p><p>Twilight before, and so, she intended to make the most of it.</p><p>After all, it felt good.</p><p class="double"></p><p>*****</p><p class="double"></p><p>Applejack had been laid out on Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill for quite some time now, </p><p>exasperated. Not that she minded the location, but she really had to get</p><p> back to work on the farm.&nbsp;&nbsp;She was the most dependable pony in Ponyville, and knew she really should get back to bucking, but\xe2\x80\xa6</p><p>Applejack didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like doing anything.</p><p class="double">Not out of laziness, Applejack was far from lazy, and she knew it; but somehow, that made it worse.</p><p>However, her disdain for it did nothing to counteract it. Not one of exasperation, but a long, drawn out sigh of relief. Applejack found it reassuring.</p><p class="double">She laid there, basking in the sunlight, alongside her counterpart, just </p><p>doing nothing, just revelling in her company. This conversation needed to happen. If she was questioning her own element, well, that\xe2\x80\x99d be like questioning a cutie mark.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cDash?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was quiet, yet harsh, overshadowed by Dash\xe2\x80\x99s now increasing breaths. She looked over her shoulder, at Dash, and smiled, even though&nbsp;&nbsp;the rainbow pony looked so morose. </p><p>It was strange, seeing the majestic Dash in a whitened colourless format. </p><p>It was almost as if she was a different pony.</p><p class="double"></p><p>*****</p><p class="double"></p><p>Rainbow Dash looked up to the sky.</p><p class="double">She could feel the words she wanted to say, building up inside of her.
