The sky, which had been her friend, was unable to help her, as it was free, emotionless.</p><p class="double">Rainbow Dash levelled her gaze, and brought her eyes to meet Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s. As </p><p>much as she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to stare away, and let time go on; Rainbow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t</p><p> just let Applejack hang like that. After all, it was her own fault.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just\xe2\x80\xa6 so sorry\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow felt her eyes begin to water, and a wave of melancholy hit her, with more force than she thought it would.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so sorry for what I said, and what I did\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Even though it was an apology, it was bittersweet. For even though Rainbow </p><p>knew she was saying the right thing, the right feelings weren\xe2\x80\x99t behind </p><p>them. Mainly, this was due to the fact that she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t really remember</p><p> what she was apologising for.</p><p class="double">There were things that Rainbow did remember, though. She remembered that the </p><p>whole night was shrouded by her own crestfallen state. She remembered </p><p>sitting with Applejack, crying into her mane, and most of all, the </p><p>overwhelming feeling of regret.</p><p>One particular image stuck in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head; the morose smile of a pony, one who looked let down, deceived. </p><p>A pony with beautiful, green eyes. </p><p>Howbeit, Rainbow didn\xe2\x80\x99t see them, not anymore, as they were clouded, hidden&nbsp;&nbsp;behind a veil of emotion. Even though they tried to be honest, to be dependable, Rainbow knew them well. </p><p>She knew that they were anything but.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow gasped.</p><p>That was brash, even for Applejack.</p><p class="double">Rainbow tried to keep her gaze locked with Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s, but the dampness of her</p><p> own eyes forced her to look down at the ground, as she tried to regain </p><p>control of her own tear ducts.</p><p class="double">Rainbow thought for a while. </p><p>\xe2\x80\x98What about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">Twilight was nice, and all. Well, she was very nice.</p><p class="double">Initially, Dash had thought that Twilight was boring, always buried in books, telling everypony \xe2\x80\x9cinteresting facts\xe2\x80\x9d, obsessed with learning. Dash was her friend; she just didn\xe2\x80\x99t like the things Twilight did.</p><p class="double">Yet, over time, Twilight changed.</p><p>Not completely. She still had a thirst for knowledge, as she probably </p><p>always would. In fact, it was probably that thirst for knowledge that </p><p>changed her; due to her study of friendship.</p><p>Twilight had developed a whole new social side, and Rainbow liked it.</p><p class="double">However, Twilight still had much to learn, and Rainbow knew so. Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t that the reason she\xe2\x80\x99d asked Twilight to come out? </p><p class="double">For Rainbow, it was nice to be the one teaching, for once. Not to be the </p><p>one in control, but to be able to help another pony, who\xe2\x80\x99d have complete</p><p> faith in her, even if she only knew a little.</p><p class="double">It was a nice change to how things with herself and Applejack went. They </p><p>were just stumbling around in the dark; neither pony had known how </p><p>anything had \xe2\x80\x98worked\xe2\x80\x99, per se.</p><p class="double">It\xe2\x80\x99d been uncertain, and each time spur of the moment, and that was fine, for Dash, at the time. After all, she was \xe2\x80\x98The Fastest Flier in all of Equestria,\xe2\x80\x99 and didn\xe2\x80\x99t have time for anything serious. </p><p>Not that she\xe2\x80\x99d known what anything serious would have actually meant.</p><p class="double">However, Rainbow wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure if she wanted that anymore.</p><p>She wasn\xe2\x80\x99t even sure about herself anymore.</p><p class="double">Eventhough her time with Twilight had been short and impulsive, much like the spurts of time she\xe2\x80\x99d spent with Applejack, Rainbow could see the start of something much more reliable with Twilight. </p><p>Reliable.</p><p class="double">Was that what she needed?</p><p class="double">Was that what she wanted?</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cUhh\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s voice still wavered, huskier than usual, the immersion in emotion taking its toll on her.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6I need to go and think, Applejack.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow looked back towards Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s gaze, once more. Her green eyes were no longer just clouded. The clouds had burst, and begun to leak; two lines traced across the freckles that pockmarked her face.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re always moving, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you? Why can\xe2\x80\x99t you just slow down?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Applejack sounded hurt. It was as if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t trying to hide it now, her honesty shining bright, even when shrouded in upset.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you about it properly, Applejack\xe2\x80\xa6 but another time. \xe2\x80\x9c</p><p class="double">Rainbow hated having to shirk such an important talk off, especially in one of the few times the two of them would normally so desperately strive to have. </p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI just need to sort my head out.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cAh can see that, Dash.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow passed an unhappy smile Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s way. She knew she needed to sort it out, but the words Applejack had fed back had hurt. </p><p>But Rainbow knew she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it. </p><p>She was the element of honesty.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you as soon as I\xe2\x80\x99ve worked it out\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s words faltered, momentarily, and a thought lapsed up; \xe2\x80\x98Was that really the best thing to say?\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow felt her chest tighten.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI promise.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow stood up, rather more quickly than she meant to, and with the biggest&nbsp;&nbsp;trace of a reassuring smile as she could muster, she turned away from&nbsp;&nbsp;Applejack, and began the decent from Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill, step by step, down between the apple trees, letting their swaying branches\xe2\x80\x99 sounds engulf her once more.</p><p class="double">Rainbow Dash just didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to fly.</b></u></i></span></center></blockquote></p>\t</body>\n</html>', 'version': 1, 'parent_story_id': 15}, 'chapter_id': 56, 'cursor': <mysql.connector.cursor.MySQLCursor object at 0x02E5FB70>, 'connection': <mysql.connector.connection.MySQLConnection object at 0x02E01A70>, 'html': '<html>\n\t<head>\n\t\t<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head>\n\t</head>\n\t<body>\n\t\t<h1><a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/story/15/with-a-heavy-heart">With a Heavy Heart</a></h1>\n\t\t<h2>by <a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/user/Krypqe">Krypqe</a></h2>\n\n\t\t<hr />\n\n\t\t<a name=\'6\'></a><h3>With You</h3>\n<p>Chills surrounded Rainbow Dash.</p><p>Chills of temperature, and chills of doubt.</p><p class="double">Rainbow had never really experienced doubt before; she was a confident, strong, \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99 pony. </p><p>Only twice had she done so, yet her previous experiences still hadn\xe2\x80\x99t </p><p>managed to shirk the way it smothered her. Nor did it lessen the blow on</p><p> her insides; lurching around with every contemplation of every possible</p><p> eventuality.</p><p class="double">She\xe2\x80\x99d thought that the somewhat scenic walk through the apple orchards </p><p>coating Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill would be able to calm her, to ease her angst, </p><p>yet, as Rainbow increased in her altitude, she got further and further </p><p>away from what felt safe. Rainbow thought this was odd, as she\xe2\x80\x99d </p><p>normally feel at ease rushing up through the clouds, engulfed in their </p><p>strangely comforting, soft, ethereal feel. Nevertheless, now, they </p><p>didn\xe2\x80\x99t emanate any positive vibes at all; the cool positivity now seemed</p><p> like cold, sad detachment. That\xe2\x80\x99s what Rainbow thought, anyway.</p><p>Perhaps she was spending too much time with earth ponies.</p><p class="double">The systematic abundance of the apple trees didn\xe2\x80\x99t help Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s state of </p><p>mind either. With each tree she passed, her mind wandered more and more </p><p>towards Applejack, and what Rainbow had said to her. </p><p>Not that Rainbow really remembered.</p><p>Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s letter had jogged her memory a tad, and the wound upon Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head </p><p>had helped it on its way, but it still wasn\xe2\x80\x99t all there.</p><p class="double">She remembered about Twilight and herself, almost begrudgingly. However, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t remembering the events that jarred Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s mind so. It was her own thoughts and feelings. </p><p>Thoughts and feelings that nopony could really synthesise, even in </p><p>retrospect. They were very much real.</p><p class="double">From Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s experience, she only knew these feelings from a tiny amount </p><p>of night encounters before, but all from the same place.</p><p class="double">A place which now, seemed only to be foreshadowed with doubt, despite its open, airy atmosphere.</p><p class="double">Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill.</p><p class="double"></p><p>*****</p><p class="double"></p><p>Twilight was sprawled out on her sofa, happy, merely through just existing. She </p><p>exhaled, in a long sigh, finally relaxed after her night on cold enamel </p><p>and water.</p><p class="double">On breathing back in, Twilight noticed a slight odour. One that was </p><p>somewhat familiar, yet alien, to the library at least. She moved her </p><p>gaze down, and against the white fabric of the sofa, Twilight saw faint,</p><p> pale fibres. Curiously, Twilight brought her head down to the fabric, </p><p>and gave it a quick, speculative sniff. </p><p>Twilight knew that was quite unscientific, and could be considered as odd,</p><p> but in the situation, she\xe2\x80\x99d decided it was the right thing to do. </p><p>Besides, nopony was in the library with her, so nopony else would know </p><p>to be able to call it odd. Not that she would have minded, anyway.</p><p class="double">After a couple of minutes, Twilight realised what was so familiar about the </p><p>scent, after all, she\xe2\x80\x99d spent a good part of the night before engulfed </p><p>in it. The scent had caressed her, surrounded her and been with her.</p><p class="double">Twilight lightly pushed her face into the sofa\xe2\x80\x99s cushions, and inhaled as deeply</p><p> as she could, swimming in the memories of Rainbow and herself. Yet, as </p><p>she was deepest in thought, she involuntarily broke down into a fit of </p><p>childish giggles. </p><p>\xe2\x80\x98Wow, Twilight\xe2\x80\x99 she thought to herself. \xe2\x80\x98That really was odd\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">Regardless, Twilight just immersed herself in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s scent once more. She\xe2\x80\x99d </p><p>often wondered why everypony in romance novels did things like this; </p><p>just sitting, thinking about their loved ones, inhaling their scent. </p><p class="double">Now, though, things were different.</p><p class="double">Perhaps, like in those books, she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t odd, but she was in love.</p><p class="double">Twilight inhaled another gasp of Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s scent, and filled her thoughts with </p><p>the pegasus. Nopony had ever quite shone in this sort of light to </p><p>Twilight before, and so, she intended to make the most of it.</p><p>After all, it felt good.</p><p class="double"></p><p>*****</p><p class="double"></p><p>Applejack had been laid out on Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill for quite some time now, </p><p>exasperated. Not that she minded the location, but she really had to get</p><p> back to work on the farm.&nbsp;&nbsp;She was the most dependable pony in Ponyville, and knew she really should get back to bucking, but\xe2\x80\xa6</p><p>Applejack didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like doing anything.</p><p class="double">Not out of laziness, Applejack was far from lazy, and she knew it; but somehow, that made it worse.</p><p>However, her disdain for it did nothing to counteract it. The one thing that </p><p>gave Applejack solace was that at least she knew what was causing her </p><p>listlessness.</p><p class="double">Light hoof-fall began to puncture the murmuring soundscape of rustling leaves</p><p> and light breeze, and with each muffled clop, Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts </p><p>began to run amok. She was painting situations in her head, some more </p><p>brash, whilst others were tenderer.</p><p class="double">Applejack knew it was silly, but she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stop acting the scenes out in the safety of her own mind.</p><p>She could get the words just right in there.</p><p class="double">There was a modest sound of setting down, beside her, and Applejack, still with her eyes firmly closed, knew who was there.</p><p class="double">She heard a sigh. Not one of exasperation, but a long, drawn out sigh of relief. Applejack found it reassuring.</p><p class="double">She laid there, basking in the sunlight, alongside her counterpart, just </p><p>doing nothing, just revelling in her company. Applejack would have liked</p><p> it to stay that way, Rainbow and herself, just sat around. Applejack </p><p>didn\xe2\x80\x99t even have to open her eyes to acknowledge Dash; they both knew </p><p>that presence was merely enough.</p><p>Yet, Dash didn\xe2\x80\x99t make that possible. She had to keep up the whole \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99 charade. They couldn\xe2\x80\x99t just bask in the ambience of Equestria, not when other ponies were around. </p><p class="double">Dash was so intent on keeping their \xe2\x80\x98rivalry\xe2\x80\x99 up, that it seemed to be </p><p>clouding over what they had between them.&nbsp;&nbsp;Applejack wished, even though</p><p> she thought it a bit foalish to do so, but she still wished. She wished</p><p> that Dash could just learn to switch off.</p><p>Even though Applejack had such feelings for her, Dash was starting to wear </p><p>on her patience. As time went on, more time, according to Dash, had to </p><p>be spent \xe2\x80\x98keeping up appearances\xe2\x80\x99.</p><p class="double">As much as Applejack hated to have to lie to everypony, as the two of them put more and more effort into covering up, times like these became more and more precious. They came to mean </p><p>more than they ever used to.</p><p>Times when Applejack and Dash had nowhere to be, nothing to do. Just to be. </p><p>To be, but together.</p><p class="double">However, as much as Applejack wanted to dwell on such a seldom moment like this,</p><p> she knew she had to break her much sought silence, and for a&nbsp;&nbsp;conversation she didn\xe2\x80\x99t really want to start. In fact, Applejack was&nbsp;&nbsp;quite sure, for a moment, at least, if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the element of&nbsp;&nbsp;honesty, well\xe2\x80\xa6 She wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have even thought of starting a conversation about such a thing.</p><p>Especially when the obvious results weren\xe2\x80\x99t going to be something either pony engaged would have wanted, but Applejack knew what the right thing to do</p><p> was. </p><p>For a moment, Applejack caught herself thinking.</p><p>\xe2\x80\x98If only I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the element of Honesty.\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">Applejacksighed, but unlike Dash\xe2\x80\x99s earlier sigh, it was an exasperated, annoyed </p><p>sigh. Even though she was troubled with the fact that she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to&nbsp;&nbsp;disown her own element, Applejack knew she was in the wrong, and she knew that if she could accept it already, her honesty wasn\xe2\x80\x99t far gone.</p><p class="double">Nevertheless, this only accentuated Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s thought. This conversation needed to happen. If she was questioning her own element, well, that\xe2\x80\x99d be like questioning a cutie mark.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cDash?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was quiet, yet harsh, overshadowed by Dash\xe2\x80\x99s now increasing breaths. At least Applejack knew she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the only anxious pony.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cWhat in tarnation was last night about, eh?</p><p class="double">Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was still hushed, yet not as quiet as it had been, she had Dash to contend with as well, now.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cApplejack, I-\xe2\x80\x9c</p><p class="double">Dash cut herself short. Applejack wasn\xe2\x80\x99t surprised, she\xe2\x80\x99d sounded uncertain from the first letter of her name.</p><p>Applejack opened her eyes, into the sunlight. Everything was bleached, shades of&nbsp;&nbsp;white. She looked over her shoulder, at Dash, and smiled, even though&nbsp;&nbsp;the rainbow pony looked so morose. </p><p>It was strange, seeing the majestic Dash in a whitened colourless format. </p><p>It was almost as if she was a different pony.</p><p class="double"></p><p>*****</p><p class="double"></p><p>Rainbow Dash looked up to the sky.</p><p class="double">She could feel the words she wanted to say, building up inside of her. Yet, none of them would come out, no matter how hard she coaxed them.&nbsp;&nbsp;Rainbow was annoyed by this. It was almost as if she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t control&nbsp;&nbsp;herself at all.</p><p>It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t as bad when it had just been her wings that acted up, but now? Everything was moving too fast.</p><p>Not in speed, of course, Rainbow was still the fastest, she was quite sure of that. It was just in everything else she did.</p><p>It was as if Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s life wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in her own hooves anymore. Seemingly, it belonged to everypony else. </p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cDash, y\xe2\x80\x99know you can say anything to me, right?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow was still looking to the sky for answers.&nbsp;&nbsp;She remembered the days in which she could just fly, not thinking about anything, just to move, and fast!</p><p>The sky had stayed the same since then, a place where a pony can be free, no worries, no thoughts. </p><p>It was funny, but upsetting. The sky, which had been her friend, was unable to help her, as it was free, emotionless.</p><p class="double">Rainbow Dash levelled her gaze, and brought her eyes to meet Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s. As </p><p>much as she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to stare away, and let time go on; Rainbow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t</p><p> just let Applejack hang like that. After all, it was her own fault.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just\xe2\x80\xa6 so sorry\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow felt her eyes begin to water, and a wave of melancholy hit her, with more force than she thought it would.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so sorry for what I said, and what I did\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Even though it was an apology, it was bittersweet. For even though Rainbow </p><p>knew she was saying the right thing, the right feelings weren\xe2\x80\x99t behind </p><p>them. Mainly, this was due to the fact that she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t really remember</p><p> what she was apologising for.</p><p class="double">There were things that Rainbow did remember, though. She remembered that the </p><p>whole night was shrouded by her own crestfallen state. She remembered </p><p>sitting with Applejack, crying into her mane, and most of all, the </p><p>overwhelming feeling of regret.</p><p>One particular image stuck in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head; the morose smile of a pony, one who looked let down, deceived. </p><p>A pony with beautiful, green eyes. </p><p>Howbeit, Rainbow didn\xe2\x80\x99t see them, not anymore, as they were clouded, hidden&nbsp;&nbsp;behind a veil of emotion. Even though they tried to be honest, to be dependable, Rainbow knew them well. </p><p>She knew that they were anything but.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow gasped.</p><p>That was brash, even for Applejack.</p><p class="double">Rainbow tried to keep her gaze locked with Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s, but the dampness of her</p><p> own eyes forced her to look down at the ground, as she tried to regain </p><p>control of her own tear ducts.</p><p class="double">Rainbow thought for a while. </p><p>\xe2\x80\x98What about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">Twilight was nice, and all. Well, she was very nice.</p><p class="double">Initially, Dash had thought that Twilight was boring, always buried in books, telling everypony \xe2\x80\x9cinteresting facts\xe2\x80\x9d, obsessed with learning. Dash was her friend; she just didn\xe2\x80\x99t like the things Twilight did.</p><p class="double">Yet, over time, Twilight changed.</p><p>Not completely. She still had a thirst for knowledge, as she probably </p><p>always would. In fact, it was probably that thirst for knowledge that </p><p>changed her; due to her study of friendship.</p><p>Twilight had developed a whole new social side, and Rainbow liked it.</p><p class="double">However, Twilight still had much to learn, and Rainbow knew so. Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t that the reason she\xe2\x80\x99d asked Twilight to come out? </p><p class="double">For Rainbow, it was nice to be the one teaching, for once. Not to be the </p><p>one in control, but to be able to help another pony, who\xe2\x80\x99d have complete</p><p> faith in her, even if she only knew a little.</p><p class="double">It was a nice change to how things with herself and Applejack went. They </p><p>were just stumbling around in the dark; neither pony had known how </p><p>anything had \xe2\x80\x98worked\xe2\x80\x99, per se.</p><p class="double">It\xe2\x80\x99d been uncertain, and each time spur of the moment, and that was fine, for Dash, at the time. After all, she was \xe2\x80\x98The Fastest Flier in all of Equestria,\xe2\x80\x99 and didn\xe2\x80\x99t have time for anything serious. </p><p>Not that she\xe2\x80\x99d known what anything serious would have actually meant.</p><p class="double">However, Rainbow wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure if she wanted that anymore.</p><p>She wasn\xe2\x80\x99t even sure about herself anymore.</p><p class="double">Eventhough her time with Twilight had been short and impulsive, much like the spurts of time she\xe2\x80\x99d spent with Applejack, Rainbow could see the start of something much more reliable with Twilight. </p><p>Reliable.</p><p class="double">Was that what she needed?</p><p class="double">Was that what she wanted?</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cUhh\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s voice still wavered, huskier than usual, the immersion in emotion taking its toll on her.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6I need to go and think, Applejack.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow looked back towards Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s gaze, once more. Her green eyes were no longer just clouded. The clouds had burst, and begun to leak; two lines traced across the freckles that pockmarked her face.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re always moving, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you? Why can\xe2\x80\x99t you just slow down?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Applejack sounded hurt. It was as if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t trying to hide it now, her honesty shining bright, even when shrouded in upset.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you about it properly, Applejack\xe2\x80\xa6 but another time. \xe2\x80\x9c</p><p class="double">Rainbow hated having to shirk such an important talk off, especially in one of the few times the two of them would normally so desperately strive to have. </p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI just need to sort my head out.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cAh can see that, Dash.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow passed an unhappy smile Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s way. She knew she needed to sort it out, but the words Applejack had fed back had hurt. </p><p>But Rainbow knew she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it. </p><p>She was the element of honesty.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you as soon as I\xe2\x80\x99ve worked it out\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s words faltered, momentarily, and a thought lapsed up; \xe2\x80\x98Was that really the best thing to say?\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow felt her chest tighten.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI promise.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow stood up, rather more quickly than she meant to, and with the biggest&nbsp;&nbsp;trace of a reassuring smile as she could muster, she turned away from&nbsp;&nbsp;Applejack, and began the decent from Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill, step by step, down between the apple trees, letting their swaying branches\xe2\x80\x99 sounds engulf her once more.</p><p class="double">Rainbow Dash just didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to fly.</b></u></i></span></center></blockquote></p>\t</body>\n</html>', 'values': ['//------------------------------//\n// With You// Story: With a Heavy Heart// by Krypqe//------------------------------//\n\nChills surrounded Rainbow Dash.\nChills of temperature, and chills of doubt.\n\nRainbow had never really experienced doubt before; she was a confident, strong, \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99 pony. \nOnly twice had she done so, yet her previous experiences still hadn\xe2\x80\x99t \nmanaged to shirk the way it smothered her. Nor did it lessen the blow on\n her insides; lurching around with every contemplation of every possible\n eventuality.\n\nShe\xe2\x80\x99d thought that the somewhat scenic walk through the apple orchards \ncoating Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill would be able to calm her, to ease her angst, \nyet, as Rainbow increased in her altitude, she got further and further \naway from what felt safe. Rainbow thought this was odd, as she\xe2\x80\x99d \nnormally feel at ease rushing up through the clouds, engulfed in their \nstrangely comforting, soft, ethereal feel. Nevertheless, now, they \ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t emanate any positive vibes at all; the cool positivity now seemed\n like cold, sad detachment. That\xe2\x80\x99s what Rainbow thought, anyway.\nPerhaps she was spending too much time with earth ponies.\n\nThe systematic abundance of the apple trees didn\xe2\x80\x99t help Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s state of \nmind either. With each tree she passed, her mind wandered more and more \ntowards Applejack, and what Rainbow had said to her. \nNot that Rainbow really remembered.\nApplejack\xe2\x80\x99s letter had jogged her memory a tad, and the wound upon Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head \nhad helped it on its way, but it still wasn\xe2\x80\x99t all there.\n\nShe remembered about Twilight and herself, almost begrudgingly. However, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t remembering the events that jarred Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s mind so. It was her own thoughts and feelings. \nThoughts and feelings that nopony could really synthesise, even in \nretrospect. They were very much real.\n\nFrom Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s experience, she only knew these feelings from a tiny amount \nof night encounters before, but all from the same place.\n\nA place which now, seemed only to be foreshadowed with doubt, despite its open, airy atmosphere.\n\nBloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill.\n\n\n*****\n\n\nTwilight was sprawled out on her sofa, happy, merely through just existing. She \nexhaled, in a long sigh, finally relaxed after her night on cold enamel \nand water.\n\nOn breathing back in, Twilight noticed a slight odour. One that was \nsomewhat familiar, yet alien, to the library at least. She moved her \ngaze down, and against the white fabric of the sofa, Twilight saw faint,\n pale fibres. Curiously, Twilight brought her head down to the fabric, \nand gave it a quick, speculative sniff. \nTwilight knew that was quite unscientific, and could be considered as odd,\n but in the situation, she\xe2\x80\x99d decided it was the right thing to do. \nBesides, nopony was in the library with her, so nopony else would know \nto be able to call it odd. Not that she would have minded, anyway.\n\nAfter a couple of minutes, Twilight realised what was so familiar about the \nscent, after all, she\xe2\x80\x99d spent a good part of the night before engulfed \nin it. The scent had caressed her, surrounded her and been with her.\n\nTwilight lightly pushed her face into the sofa\xe2\x80\x99s cushions, and inhaled as deeply\n as she could, swimming in the memories of Rainbow and herself. Yet, as \nshe was deepest in thought, she involuntarily broke down into a fit of \nchildish giggles. \n\xe2\x80\x98Wow, Twilight\xe2\x80\x99 she thought to herself. \xe2\x80\x98That really was odd\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x99\n\nRegardless, Twilight just immersed herself in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s scent once more. She\xe2\x80\x99d \noften wondered why everypony in romance novels did things like this; \njust sitting, thinking about their loved ones, inhaling their scent. \n\nNow, though, things were different.\n\nPerhaps, like in those books, she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t odd, but she was in love.\n\nTwilight inhaled another gasp of Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s scent, and filled her thoughts with \nthe pegasus. Nopony had ever quite shone in this sort of light to \nTwilight before, and so, she intended to make the most of it.\nAfter all, it felt good.\n\n\n*****\n\n\nApplejack had been laid out on Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill for quite some time now, \nexasperated. Not that she minded the location, but she really had to get\n back to work on the farm.  She was the most dependable pony in Ponyville, and knew she really should get back to bucking, but\xe2\x80\xa6\nApplejack didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like doing anything.\n\nNot out of laziness, Applejack was far from lazy, and she knew it; but somehow, that made it worse.\nHowever, her disdain for it did nothing to counteract it. The one thing that \ngave Applejack solace was that at least she knew what was causing her \nlistlessness.\n\nLight hoof-fall began to puncture the murmuring soundscape of rustling leaves\n and light breeze, and with each muffled clop, Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts \nbegan to run amok. She was painting situations in her head, some more \nbrash, whilst others were tenderer.\n\nApplejack knew it was silly, but she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stop acting the scenes out in the safety of her own mind.\nShe could get the words just right in there.\n\nThere was a modest sound of setting down, beside her, and Applejack, still with her eyes firmly closed, knew who was there.\n\nShe heard a sigh. Not one of exasperation, but a long, drawn out sigh of relief. Applejack found it reassuring.\n\nShe laid there, basking in the sunlight, alongside her counterpart, just \ndoing nothing, just revelling in her company. Applejack would have liked\n it to stay that way, Rainbow and herself, just sat around. Applejack \ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t even have to open her eyes to acknowledge Dash; they both knew \nthat presence was merely enough.\nYet, Dash didn\xe2\x80\x99t make that possible. She had to keep up the whole \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99 charade. They couldn\xe2\x80\x99t just bask in the ambience of Equestria, not when other ponies were around. \n\nDash was so intent on keeping their \xe2\x80\x98rivalry\xe2\x80\x99 up, that it seemed to be \nclouding over what they had between them.  Applejack wished, even though\n she thought it a bit foalish to do so, but she still wished. She wished\n that Dash could just learn to switch off.\nEven though Applejack had such feelings for her, Dash was starting to wear \non her patience. As time went on, more time, according to Dash, had to \nbe spent \xe2\x80\x98keeping up appearances\xe2\x80\x99.\n\nAs much as Applejack hated to have to lie to everypony, as the two of them put more and more effort into covering up, times like these became more and more precious. They came to mean \nmore than they ever used to.\nTimes when Applejack and Dash had nowhere to be, nothing to do. Just to be. \nTo be, but together.\n\nHowever, as much as Applejack wanted to dwell on such a seldom moment like this,\n she knew she had to break her much sought silence, and for a  conversation she didn\xe2\x80\x99t really want to start. In fact, Applejack was  quite sure, for a moment, at least, if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the element of  honesty, well\xe2\x80\xa6 She wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have even thought of starting a conversation about such a thing.\nEspecially when the obvious results weren\xe2\x80\x99t going to be something either pony engaged would have wanted, but Applejack knew what the right thing to do\n was. \nFor a moment, Applejack caught herself thinking.\n\xe2\x80\x98If only I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the element of Honesty.\xe2\x80\x99\n\nApplejacksighed, but unlike Dash\xe2\x80\x99s earlier sigh, it was an exasperated, annoyed \nsigh. Even though she was troubled with the fact that she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to  disown her own element, Applejack knew she was in the wrong, and she knew that if she could accept it already, her honesty wasn\xe2\x80\x99t far gone.\n\nNevertheless, this only accentuated Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s thought. This conversation needed to happen. If she was questioning her own element, well, that\xe2\x80\x99d be like questioning a cutie mark.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDash?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nApplejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was quiet, yet harsh, overshadowed by Dash\xe2\x80\x99s now increasing breaths. At least Applejack knew she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the only anxious pony.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat in tarnation was last night about, eh?\n\nApplejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was still hushed, yet not as quiet as it had been, she had Dash to contend with as well, now.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cApplejack, I-\xe2\x80\x9c\n\nDash cut herself short. Applejack wasn\xe2\x80\x99t surprised, she\xe2\x80\x99d sounded uncertain from the first letter of her name.\nApplejack opened her eyes, into the sunlight. Everything was bleached, shades of  white. She looked over her shoulder, at Dash, and smiled, even though  the rainbow pony looked so morose. \nIt was strange, seeing the majestic Dash in a whitened colourless format. \nIt was almost as if she was a different pony.\n\n\n*****\n\n\nRainbow Dash looked up to the sky.\n\nShe could feel the words she wanted to say, building up inside of her. Yet, none of them would come out, no matter how hard she coaxed them.  Rainbow was annoyed by this. It was almost as if she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t control  herself at all.\nIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t as bad when it had just been her wings that acted up, but now? Everything was moving too fast.\nNot in speed, of course, Rainbow was still the fastest, she was quite sure of that. It was just in everything else she did.\nIt was as if Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s life wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in her own hooves anymore. Seemingly, it belonged to everypony else. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDash, y\xe2\x80\x99know you can say anything to me, right?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow was still looking to the sky for answers.  She remembered the days in which she could just fly, not thinking about anything, just to move, and fast!\nThe sky had stayed the same since then, a place where a pony can be free, no worries, no thoughts. \nIt was funny, but upsetting. The sky, which had been her friend, was unable to help her, as it was free, emotionless.\n\nRainbow Dash levelled her gaze, and brought her eyes to meet Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s. As \nmuch as she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to stare away, and let time go on; Rainbow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\n just let Applejack hang like that. After all, it was her own fault.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just\xe2\x80\xa6 so sorry\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow felt her eyes begin to water, and a wave of melancholy hit her, with more force than she thought it would.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so sorry for what I said, and what I did\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nEven though it was an apology, it was bittersweet. For even though Rainbow \nknew she was saying the right thing, the right feelings weren\xe2\x80\x99t behind \nthem. Mainly, this was due to the fact that she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t really remember\n what she was apologising for.\n\nThere were things that Rainbow did remember, though. She remembered that the \nwhole night was shrouded by her own crestfallen state. She remembered \nsitting with Applejack, crying into her mane, and most of all, the \noverwhelming feeling of regret.\nOne particular image stuck in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head; the morose smile of a pony, one who looked let down, deceived. \nA pony with beautiful, green eyes. \nHowbeit, Rainbow didn\xe2\x80\x99t see them, not anymore, as they were clouded, hidden  behind a veil of emotion. Even though they tried to be honest, to be dependable, Rainbow knew them well. \nShe knew that they were anything but.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow gasped.\nThat was brash, even for Applejack.\n\nRainbow tried to keep her gaze locked with Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s, but the dampness of her\n own eyes forced her to look down at the ground, as she tried to regain \ncontrol of her own tear ducts.\n\nRainbow thought for a while. \n\xe2\x80\x98What about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x99\n\nTwilight was nice, and all. Well, she was very nice.\n\nInitially, Dash had thought that Twilight was boring, always buried in books, telling everypony \xe2\x80\x9cinteresting facts\xe2\x80\x9d, obsessed with learning. Dash was her friend; she just didn\xe2\x80\x99t like the things Twilight did.\n\nYet, over time, Twilight changed.\nNot completely. She still had a thirst for knowledge, as she probably \nalways would. In fact, it was probably that thirst for knowledge that \nchanged her; due to her study of friendship.\nTwilight had developed a whole new social side, and Rainbow liked it.\n\nHowever, Twilight still had much to learn, and Rainbow knew so. Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t that the reason she\xe2\x80\x99d asked Twilight to come out? \n\nFor Rainbow, it was nice to be the one teaching, for once. Not to be the \none in control, but to be able to help another pony, who\xe2\x80\x99d have complete\n faith in her, even if she only knew a little.\n\nIt was a nice change to how things with herself and Applejack went. They \nwere just stumbling around in the dark; neither pony had known how \nanything had \xe2\x80\x98worked\xe2\x80\x99, per se.\n\nIt\xe2\x80\x99d been uncertain, and each time spur of the moment, and that was fine, for Dash, at the time. After all, she was \xe2\x80\x98The Fastest Flier in all of Equestria,\xe2\x80\x99 and didn\xe2\x80\x99t have time for anything serious. \nNot that she\xe2\x80\x99d known what anything serious would have actually meant.\n\nHowever, Rainbow wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure if she wanted that anymore.\nShe wasn\xe2\x80\x99t even sure about herself anymore.\n\nEventhough her time with Twilight had been short and impulsive, much like the spurts of time she\xe2\x80\x99d spent with Applejack, Rainbow could see the start of something much more reliable with Twilight. \nReliable.\n\nWas that what she needed?\n\nWas that what she wanted?\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUhh\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow\xe2\x80\x99s voice still wavered, huskier than usual, the immersion in emotion taking its toll on her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6I need to go and think, Applejack.\xe2\x80\x9d\n    \nRainbow looked back towards Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s gaze, once more. Her green eyes were no longer just clouded. The clouds had burst, and begun to leak; two lines traced across the freckles that pockmarked her face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re always moving, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you? Why can\xe2\x80\x99t you just slow down?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nApplejack sounded hurt. It was as if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t trying to hide it now, her honesty shining bright, even when shrouded in upset.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you about it properly, Applejack\xe2\x80\xa6 but another time. \xe2\x80\x9c\n\nRainbow hated having to shirk such an important talk off, especially in one of the few times the two of them would normally so desperately strive to have. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI just need to sort my head out.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh can see that, Dash.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow passed an unhappy smile Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s way. She knew she needed to sort it out, but the words Applejack had fed back had hurt. \nBut Rainbow knew she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it. \nShe was the element of honesty.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you as soon as I\xe2\x80\x99ve worked it out\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow\xe2\x80\x99s words faltered, momentarily, and a thought lapsed up; \xe2\x80\x98Was that really the best thing to say?\xe2\x80\x99\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow felt her chest tighten.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow stood up, rather more quickly than she meant to, and with the biggest  trace of a reassuring smile as she could muster, she turned away from  Applejack, and began the decent from Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill, step by step, down between the apple trees, letting their swaying branches\xe2\x80\x99 sounds engulf her once more.\n\nRainbow Dash just didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to fly.', 6, 56, '<html>\n\t<head>\n\t\t<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head>\n\t</head>\n\t<body>\n\t\t<h1><a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/story/15/with-a-heavy-heart">With a Heavy Heart</a></h1>\n\t\t<h2>by <a href="http://www.fimfiction.net/user/Krypqe">Krypqe</a></h2>\n\n\t\t<hr />\n\n\t\t<a name=\'6\'></a><h3>With You</h3>\n<p>Chills surrounded Rainbow Dash.</p><p>Chills of temperature, and chills of doubt.</p><p class="double">Rainbow had never really experienced doubt before; she was a confident, strong, \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99 pony. </p><p>Only twice had she done so, yet her previous experiences still hadn\xe2\x80\x99t </p><p>managed to shirk the way it smothered her. Nor did it lessen the blow on</p><p> her insides; lurching around with every contemplation of every possible</p><p> eventuality.</p><p class="double">She\xe2\x80\x99d thought that the somewhat scenic walk through the apple orchards </p><p>coating Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill would be able to calm her, to ease her angst, </p><p>yet, as Rainbow increased in her altitude, she got further and further </p><p>away from what felt safe. Rainbow thought this was odd, as she\xe2\x80\x99d </p><p>normally feel at ease rushing up through the clouds, engulfed in their </p><p>strangely comforting, soft, ethereal feel. Nevertheless, now, they </p><p>didn\xe2\x80\x99t emanate any positive vibes at all; the cool positivity now seemed</p><p> like cold, sad detachment. One that was </p><p>somewhat familiar, yet alien, to the library at least. She moved her </p><p>gaze down, and against the white fabric of the sofa, Twilight saw faint,</p><p> pale fibres. Not that she would have minded, anyway.</p><p class="double">After a couple of minutes, Twilight realised what was so familiar about the </p><p>scent, after all, she\xe2\x80\x99d spent a good part of the night before engulfed </p><p>in it. The scent had caressed her, surrounded her and been with her.</p><p class="double">Twilight lightly pushed her face into the sofa\xe2\x80\x99s cushions, and inhaled as deeply</p><p> as she could, swimming in the memories of Rainbow and herself. Yet, as </p><p>she was deepest in thought, she involuntarily broke down into a fit of </p><p>childish giggles. </p><p>\xe2\x80\x98Wow, Twilight\xe2\x80\x99 she thought to herself. \xe2\x80\x98That really was odd\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">Regardless, Twilight just immersed herself in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s scent once more. Nopony had ever quite shone in this sort of light to </p><p>Twilight before, and so, she intended to make the most of it.</p><p>After all, it felt good.</p><p class="double"></p><p>*****</p><p class="double"></p><p>Applejack had been laid out on Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill for quite some time now, </p><p>exasperated. Not that she minded the location, but she really had to get</p><p> back to work on the farm.&nbsp;&nbsp;She was the most dependable pony in Ponyville, and knew she really should get back to bucking, but\xe2\x80\xa6</p><p>Applejack didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like doing anything.</p><p class="double">Not out of laziness, Applejack was far from lazy, and she knew it; but somehow, that made it worse.</p><p>However, her disdain for it did nothing to counteract it. The one thing that </p><p>gave Applejack solace was that at least she knew what was causing her </p><p>listlessness.</p><p class="double">Light hoof-fall began to puncture the murmuring soundscape of rustling leaves</p><p> and light breeze, and with each muffled clop, Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts </p><p>began to run amok. She was painting situations in her head, some more </p><p>brash, whilst others were tenderer.</p><p class="double">Applejack knew it was silly, but she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stop acting the scenes out in the safety of her own mind.</p><p>She could get the words just right in there.</p><p class="double">There was a modest sound of setting down, beside her, and Applejack, still with her eyes firmly closed, knew who was there.</p><p class="double">She heard a sigh. Not one of exasperation, but a long, drawn out sigh of relief. Applejack found it reassuring.</p><p class="double">She laid there, basking in the sunlight, alongside her counterpart, just </p><p>doing nothing, just revelling in her company. Applejack would have liked</p><p> it to stay that way, Rainbow and herself, just sat around. Applejack </p><p>didn\xe2\x80\x99t even have to open her eyes to acknowledge Dash; they both knew </p><p>that presence was merely enough.</p><p>Yet, Dash didn\xe2\x80\x99t make that possible. She had to keep up the whole \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99 charade. They couldn\xe2\x80\x99t just bask in the ambience of Equestria, not when other ponies were around. </p><p class="double">Dash was so intent on keeping their \xe2\x80\x98rivalry\xe2\x80\x99 up, that it seemed to be </p><p>clouding over what they had between them.&nbsp;&nbsp;Applejack wished, even though</p><p> she thought it a bit foalish to do so, but she still wished. She wished</p><p> that Dash could just learn to switch off.</p><p>Even though Applejack had such feelings for her, Dash was starting to wear </p><p>on her patience. As time went on, more time, according to Dash, had to </p><p>be spent \xe2\x80\x98keeping up appearances\xe2\x80\x99.</p><p class="double">As much as Applejack hated to have to lie to everypony, as the two of them put more and more effort into covering up, times like these became more and more precious. They came to mean </p><p>more than they ever used to.</p><p>Times when Applejack and Dash had nowhere to be, nothing to do. Just to be. </p><p>To be, but together.</p><p class="double">However, as much as Applejack wanted to dwell on such a seldom moment like this,</p><p> she knew she had to break her much sought silence, and for a&nbsp;&nbsp;conversation she didn\xe2\x80\x99t really want to start. In fact, Applejack was&nbsp;&nbsp;quite sure, for a moment, at least, if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the element of&nbsp;&nbsp;honesty, well\xe2\x80\xa6 She wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have even thought of starting a conversation about such a thing.</p><p>Especially when the obvious results weren\xe2\x80\x99t going to be something either pony engaged would have wanted, but Applejack knew what the right thing to do</p><p> was. </p><p>For a moment, Applejack caught herself thinking.</p><p>\xe2\x80\x98If only I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the element of Honesty.\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">Applejacksighed, but unlike Dash\xe2\x80\x99s earlier sigh, it was an exasperated, annoyed </p><p>sigh. Even though she was troubled with the fact that she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to&nbsp;&nbsp;disown her own element, Applejack knew she was in the wrong, and she knew that if she could accept it already, her honesty wasn\xe2\x80\x99t far gone.</p><p class="double">Nevertheless, this only accentuated Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s thought. This conversation needed to happen. If she was questioning her own element, well, that\xe2\x80\x99d be like questioning a cutie mark.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cDash?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was quiet, yet harsh, overshadowed by Dash\xe2\x80\x99s now increasing breaths. At least Applejack knew she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the only anxious pony.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cWhat in tarnation was last night about, eh?</p><p class="double">Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was still hushed, yet not as quiet as it had been, she had Dash to contend with as well, now.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cApplejack, I-\xe2\x80\x9c</p><p class="double">Dash cut herself short. Applejack wasn\xe2\x80\x99t surprised, she\xe2\x80\x99d sounded uncertain from the first letter of her name.</p><p>Applejack opened her eyes, into the sunlight. Everything was bleached, shades of&nbsp;&nbsp;white. She looked over her shoulder, at Dash, and smiled, even though&nbsp;&nbsp;the rainbow pony looked so morose. </p><p>It was strange, seeing the majestic Dash in a whitened colourless format. </p><p>It was almost as if she was a different pony.</p><p class="double"></p><p>*****</p><p class="double"></p><p>Rainbow Dash looked up to the sky.</p><p class="double">She could feel the words she wanted to say, building up inside of her. Yet, none of them would come out, no matter how hard she coaxed them.&nbsp;&nbsp;Rainbow was annoyed by this. It was almost as if she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t control&nbsp;&nbsp;herself at all.</p><p>It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t as bad when it had just been her wings that acted up, but now? Everything was moving too fast.</p><p>Not in speed, of course, Rainbow was still the fastest, she was quite sure of that. It was just in everything else she did.</p><p>It was as if Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s life wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in her own hooves anymore. Seemingly, it belonged to everypony else. </p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cDash, y\xe2\x80\x99know you can say anything to me, right?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow was still looking to the sky for answers.&nbsp;&nbsp;She remembered the days in which she could just fly, not thinking about anything, just to move, and fast!</p><p>The sky had stayed the same since then, a place where a pony can be free, no worries, no thoughts. </p><p>It was funny, but upsetting. The sky, which had been her friend, was unable to help her, as it was free, emotionless.</p><p class="double">Rainbow Dash levelled her gaze, and brought her eyes to meet Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s. As </p><p>much as she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to stare away, and let time go on; Rainbow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t</p><p> just let Applejack hang like that. After all, it was her own fault.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just\xe2\x80\xa6 so sorry\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow felt her eyes begin to water, and a wave of melancholy hit her, with more force than she thought it would.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so sorry for what I said, and what I did\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Even though it was an apology, it was bittersweet. For even though Rainbow </p><p>knew she was saying the right thing, the right feelings weren\xe2\x80\x99t behind </p><p>them. Mainly, this was due to the fact that she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t really remember</p><p> what she was apologising for.</p><p class="double">There were things that Rainbow did remember, though. She remembered that the </p><p>whole night was shrouded by her own crestfallen state. She remembered </p><p>sitting with Applejack, crying into her mane, and most of all, the </p><p>overwhelming feeling of regret.</p><p>One particular image stuck in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head; the morose smile of a pony, one who looked let down, deceived. </p><p>A pony with beautiful, green eyes. </p><p>Howbeit, Rainbow didn\xe2\x80\x99t see them, not anymore, as they were clouded, hidden&nbsp;&nbsp;behind a veil of emotion. Even though they tried to be honest, to be dependable, Rainbow knew them well. </p><p>She knew that they were anything but.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow gasped.</p><p>That was brash, even for Applejack.</p><p class="double">Rainbow tried to keep her gaze locked with Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s, but the dampness of her</p><p> own eyes forced her to look down at the ground, as she tried to regain </p><p>control of her own tear ducts.</p><p class="double">Rainbow thought for a while. </p><p>\xe2\x80\x98What about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">Twilight was nice, and all. Well, she was very nice.</p><p class="double">Initially, Dash had thought that Twilight was boring, always buried in books, telling everypony \xe2\x80\x9cinteresting facts\xe2\x80\x9d, obsessed with learning. Dash was her friend; she just didn\xe2\x80\x99t like the things Twilight did.</p><p class="double">Yet, over time, Twilight changed.</p><p>Not completely. She still had a thirst for knowledge, as she probably </p><p>always would. In fact, it was probably that thirst for knowledge that </p><p>changed her; due to her study of friendship.</p><p>Twilight had developed a whole new social side, and Rainbow liked it.</p><p class="double">However, Twilight still had much to learn, and Rainbow knew so. Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t that the reason she\xe2\x80\x99d asked Twilight to come out? </p><p class="double">For Rainbow, it was nice to be the one teaching, for once. Not to be the </p><p>one in control, but to be able to help another pony, who\xe2\x80\x99d have complete</p><p> faith in her, even if she only knew a little.</p><p class="double">It was a nice change to how things with herself and Applejack went. They </p><p>were just stumbling around in the dark; neither pony had known how </p><p>anything had \xe2\x80\x98worked\xe2\x80\x99, per se.</p><p class="double">It\xe2\x80\x99d been uncertain, and each time spur of the moment, and that was fine, for Dash, at the time. After all, she was \xe2\x80\x98The Fastest Flier in all of Equestria,\xe2\x80\x99 and didn\xe2\x80\x99t have time for anything serious. </p><p>Not that she\xe2\x80\x99d known what anything serious would have actually meant.</p><p class="double">However, Rainbow wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure if she wanted that anymore.</p><p>She wasn\xe2\x80\x99t even sure about herself anymore.</p><p class="double">Eventhough her time with Twilight had been short and impulsive, much like the spurts of time she\xe2\x80\x99d spent with Applejack, Rainbow could see the start of something much more reliable with Twilight. </p><p>Reliable.</p><p class="double">Was that what she needed?</p><p class="double">Was that what she wanted?</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cUhh\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s voice still wavered, huskier than usual, the immersion in emotion taking its toll on her.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6I need to go and think, Applejack.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow looked back towards Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s gaze, once more. Her green eyes were no longer just clouded. The clouds had burst, and begun to leak; two lines traced across the freckles that pockmarked her face.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re always moving, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you? Why can\xe2\x80\x99t you just slow down?\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Applejack sounded hurt. It was as if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t trying to hide it now, her honesty shining bright, even when shrouded in upset.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you about it properly, Applejack\xe2\x80\xa6 but another time. \xe2\x80\x9c</p><p class="double">Rainbow hated having to shirk such an important talk off, especially in one of the few times the two of them would normally so desperately strive to have. </p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI just need to sort my head out.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cAh can see that, Dash.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow passed an unhappy smile Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s way. She knew she needed to sort it out, but the words Applejack had fed back had hurt. </p><p>But Rainbow knew she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it. </p><p>She was the element of honesty.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you as soon as I\xe2\x80\x99ve worked it out\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s words faltered, momentarily, and a thought lapsed up; \xe2\x80\x98Was that really the best thing to say?\xe2\x80\x99</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow felt her chest tighten.</p><p class="double">\xe2\x80\x9cI promise.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="double">Rainbow stood up, rather more quickly than she meant to, and with the biggest&nbsp;&nbsp;trace of a reassuring smile as she could muster, she turned away from&nbsp;&nbsp;Applejack, and began the decent from Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill, step by step, down between the apple trees, letting their swaying branches\xe2\x80\x99 sounds engulf her once more.</p><p class="double">Rainbow Dash just didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to fly.</b></u></i></span></center></blockquote></p>\t</body>\n</html>', 1, 15], 'parent_story_id': 15, 'txt': '//------------------------------//\n// With You// Story: With a Heavy Heart// by Krypqe//------------------------------//\n\nChills surrounded Rainbow Dash.\nChills of temperature, and chills of doubt.\n\nRainbow had never really experienced doubt before; she was a confident, strong, \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99 pony. \nOnly twice had she done so, yet her previous experiences still hadn\xe2\x80\x99t \nmanaged to shirk the way it smothered her. Nor did it lessen the blow on\n her insides; lurching around with every contemplation of every possible\n eventuality.\n\nShe\xe2\x80\x99d thought that the somewhat scenic walk through the apple orchards \ncoating Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill would be able to calm her, to ease her angst, \nyet, as Rainbow increased in her altitude, she got further and further \naway from what felt safe. Rainbow thought this was odd, as she\xe2\x80\x99d \nnormally feel at ease rushing up through the clouds, engulfed in their \nstrangely comforting, soft, ethereal feel. Nevertheless, now, they \ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t emanate any positive vibes at all; the cool positivity now seemed\n like cold, sad detachment. That\xe2\x80\x99s what Rainbow thought, anyway.\nPerhaps she was spending too much time with earth ponies.\n\nThe systematic abundance of the apple trees didn\xe2\x80\x99t help Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s state of \nmind either. With each tree she passed, her mind wandered more and more \ntowards Applejack, and what Rainbow had said to her. \nNot that Rainbow really remembered.\nApplejack\xe2\x80\x99s letter had jogged her memory a tad, and the wound upon Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head \nhad helped it on its way, but it still wasn\xe2\x80\x99t all there.\n\nShe remembered about Twilight and herself, almost begrudgingly. However, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t remembering the events that jarred Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s mind so. It was her own thoughts and feelings. \nThoughts and feelings that nopony could really synthesise, even in \nretrospect. They were very much real.\n\nFrom Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s experience, she only knew these feelings from a tiny amount \nof night encounters before, but all from the same place.\n\nA place which now, seemed only to be foreshadowed with doubt, despite its open, airy atmosphere.\n\nBloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill.\n\n\n*****\n\n\nTwilight was sprawled out on her sofa, happy, merely through just existing. She \nexhaled, in a long sigh, finally relaxed after her night on cold enamel \nand water.\n\nOn breathing back in, Twilight noticed a slight odour. One that was \nsomewhat familiar, yet alien, to the library at least. She moved her \ngaze down, and against the white fabric of the sofa, Twilight saw faint,\n pale fibres. Curiously, Twilight brought her head down to the fabric, \nand gave it a quick, speculative sniff. \nTwilight knew that was quite unscientific, and could be considered as odd,\n but in the situation, she\xe2\x80\x99d decided it was the right thing to do. \nBesides, nopony was in the library with her, so nopony else would know \nto be able to call it odd. Not that she would have minded, anyway.\n\nAfter a couple of minutes, Twilight realised what was so familiar about the \nscent, after all, she\xe2\x80\x99d spent a good part of the night before engulfed \nin it. The scent had caressed her, surrounded her and been with her.\n\nTwilight lightly pushed her face into the sofa\xe2\x80\x99s cushions, and inhaled as deeply\n as she could, swimming in the memories of Rainbow and herself. Yet, as \nshe was deepest in thought, she involuntarily broke down into a fit of \nchildish giggles. \n\xe2\x80\x98Wow, Twilight\xe2\x80\x99 she thought to herself. \xe2\x80\x98That really was odd\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x99\n\nRegardless, Twilight just immersed herself in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s scent once more. She\xe2\x80\x99d \noften wondered why everypony in romance novels did things like this; \njust sitting, thinking about their loved ones, inhaling their scent. \n\nNow, though, things were different.\n\nPerhaps, like in those books, she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t odd, but she was in love.\n\nTwilight inhaled another gasp of Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s scent, and filled her thoughts with \nthe pegasus. Nopony had ever quite shone in this sort of light to \nTwilight before, and so, she intended to make the most of it.\nAfter all, it felt good.\n\n\n*****\n\n\nApplejack had been laid out on Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill for quite some time now, \nexasperated. Not that she minded the location, but she really had to get\n back to work on the farm.  She was the most dependable pony in Ponyville, and knew she really should get back to bucking, but\xe2\x80\xa6\nApplejack didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like doing anything.\n\nNot out of laziness, Applejack was far from lazy, and she knew it; but somehow, that made it worse.\nHowever, her disdain for it did nothing to counteract it. The one thing that \ngave Applejack solace was that at least she knew what was causing her \nlistlessness.\n\nLight hoof-fall began to puncture the murmuring soundscape of rustling leaves\n and light breeze, and with each muffled clop, Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts \nbegan to run amok. She was painting situations in her head, some more \nbrash, whilst others were tenderer.\n\nApplejack knew it was silly, but she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stop acting the scenes out in the safety of her own mind.\nShe could get the words just right in there.\n\nThere was a modest sound of setting down, beside her, and Applejack, still with her eyes firmly closed, knew who was there.\n\nShe heard a sigh. Not one of exasperation, but a long, drawn out sigh of relief. Applejack found it reassuring.\n\nShe laid there, basking in the sunlight, alongside her counterpart, just \ndoing nothing, just revelling in her company. Applejack would have liked\n it to stay that way, Rainbow and herself, just sat around. Applejack \ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t even have to open her eyes to acknowledge Dash; they both knew \nthat presence was merely enough.\nYet, Dash didn\xe2\x80\x99t make that possible. She had to keep up the whole \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99 charade. They couldn\xe2\x80\x99t just bask in the ambience of Equestria, not when other ponies were around. \n\nDash was so intent on keeping their \xe2\x80\x98rivalry\xe2\x80\x99 up, that it seemed to be \nclouding over what they had between them.  Applejack wished, even though\n she thought it a bit foalish to do so, but she still wished. She wished\n that Dash could just learn to switch off.\nEven though Applejack had such feelings for her, Dash was starting to wear \non her patience. As time went on, more time, according to Dash, had to \nbe spent \xe2\x80\x98keeping up appearances\xe2\x80\x99.\n\nAs much as Applejack hated to have to lie to everypony, as the two of them put more and more effort into covering up, times like these became more and more precious. They came to mean \nmore than they ever used to.\nTimes when Applejack and Dash had nowhere to be, nothing to do. Just to be. \nTo be, but together.\n\nHowever, as much as Applejack wanted to dwell on such a seldom moment like this,\n she knew she had to break her much sought silence, and for a  conversation she didn\xe2\x80\x99t really want to start. In fact, Applejack was  quite sure, for a moment, at least, if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the element of  honesty, well\xe2\x80\xa6 She wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have even thought of starting a conversation about such a thing.\nEspecially when the obvious results weren\xe2\x80\x99t going to be something either pony engaged would have wanted, but Applejack knew what the right thing to do\n was. \nFor a moment, Applejack caught herself thinking.\n\xe2\x80\x98If only I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the element of Honesty.\xe2\x80\x99\n\nApplejacksighed, but unlike Dash\xe2\x80\x99s earlier sigh, it was an exasperated, annoyed \nsigh. Even though she was troubled with the fact that she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to  disown her own element, Applejack knew she was in the wrong, and she knew that if she could accept it already, her honesty wasn\xe2\x80\x99t far gone.\n\nNevertheless, this only accentuated Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s thought. This conversation needed to happen. If she was questioning her own element, well, that\xe2\x80\x99d be like questioning a cutie mark.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDash?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nApplejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was quiet, yet harsh, overshadowed by Dash\xe2\x80\x99s now increasing breaths. At least Applejack knew she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the only anxious pony.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat in tarnation was last night about, eh?\n\nApplejack\xe2\x80\x99s voice was still hushed, yet not as quiet as it had been, she had Dash to contend with as well, now.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cApplejack, I-\xe2\x80\x9c\n\nDash cut herself short. Applejack wasn\xe2\x80\x99t surprised, she\xe2\x80\x99d sounded uncertain from the first letter of her name.\nApplejack opened her eyes, into the sunlight. Everything was bleached, shades of  white. She looked over her shoulder, at Dash, and smiled, even though  the rainbow pony looked so morose. \nIt was strange, seeing the majestic Dash in a whitened colourless format. \nIt was almost as if she was a different pony.\n\n\n*****\n\n\nRainbow Dash looked up to the sky.\n\nShe could feel the words she wanted to say, building up inside of her. Yet, none of them would come out, no matter how hard she coaxed them.  Rainbow was annoyed by this. It was almost as if she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t control  herself at all.\nIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t as bad when it had just been her wings that acted up, but now? Everything was moving too fast.\nNot in speed, of course, Rainbow was still the fastest, she was quite sure of that. It was just in everything else she did.\nIt was as if Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s life wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in her own hooves anymore. Seemingly, it belonged to everypony else. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDash, y\xe2\x80\x99know you can say anything to me, right?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow was still looking to the sky for answers.  She remembered the days in which she could just fly, not thinking about anything, just to move, and fast!\nThe sky had stayed the same since then, a place where a pony can be free, no worries, no thoughts. \nIt was funny, but upsetting. The sky, which had been her friend, was unable to help her, as it was free, emotionless.\n\nRainbow Dash levelled her gaze, and brought her eyes to meet Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s. As \nmuch as she\xe2\x80\x99d wanted to stare away, and let time go on; Rainbow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\n just let Applejack hang like that. After all, it was her own fault.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just\xe2\x80\xa6 so sorry\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow felt her eyes begin to water, and a wave of melancholy hit her, with more force than she thought it would.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so sorry for what I said, and what I did\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nEven though it was an apology, it was bittersweet. For even though Rainbow \nknew she was saying the right thing, the right feelings weren\xe2\x80\x99t behind \nthem. Mainly, this was due to the fact that she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t really remember\n what she was apologising for.\n\nThere were things that Rainbow did remember, though. She remembered that the \nwhole night was shrouded by her own crestfallen state. She remembered \nsitting with Applejack, crying into her mane, and most of all, the \noverwhelming feeling of regret.\nOne particular image stuck in Rainbow\xe2\x80\x99s head; the morose smile of a pony, one who looked let down, deceived. \nA pony with beautiful, green eyes. \nHowbeit, Rainbow didn\xe2\x80\x99t see them, not anymore, as they were clouded, hidden  behind a veil of emotion. Even though they tried to be honest, to be dependable, Rainbow knew them well. \nShe knew that they were anything but.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow gasped.\nThat was brash, even for Applejack.\n\nRainbow tried to keep her gaze locked with Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s, but the dampness of her\n own eyes forced her to look down at the ground, as she tried to regain \ncontrol of her own tear ducts.\n\nRainbow thought for a while. \n\xe2\x80\x98What about Twilight?\xe2\x80\x99\n\nTwilight was nice, and all. Well, she was very nice.\n\nInitially, Dash had thought that Twilight was boring, always buried in books, telling everypony \xe2\x80\x9cinteresting facts\xe2\x80\x9d, obsessed with learning. Dash was her friend; she just didn\xe2\x80\x99t like the things Twilight did.\n\nYet, over time, Twilight changed.\nNot completely. She still had a thirst for knowledge, as she probably \nalways would. In fact, it was probably that thirst for knowledge that \nchanged her; due to her study of friendship.\nTwilight had developed a whole new social side, and Rainbow liked it.\n\nHowever, Twilight still had much to learn, and Rainbow knew so. Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t that the reason she\xe2\x80\x99d asked Twilight to come out? \n\nFor Rainbow, it was nice to be the one teaching, for once. Not to be the \none in control, but to be able to help another pony, who\xe2\x80\x99d have complete\n faith in her, even if she only knew a little.\n\nIt was a nice change to how things with herself and Applejack went. They \nwere just stumbling around in the dark; neither pony had known how \nanything had \xe2\x80\x98worked\xe2\x80\x99, per se.\n\nIt\xe2\x80\x99d been uncertain, and each time spur of the moment, and that was fine, for Dash, at the time. After all, she was \xe2\x80\x98The Fastest Flier in all of Equestria,\xe2\x80\x99 and didn\xe2\x80\x99t have time for anything serious. \nNot that she\xe2\x80\x99d known what anything serious would have actually meant.\n\nHowever, Rainbow wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure if she wanted that anymore.\nShe wasn\xe2\x80\x99t even sure about herself anymore.\n\nEventhough her time with Twilight had been short and impulsive, much like the spurts of time she\xe2\x80\x99d spent with Applejack, Rainbow could see the start of something much more reliable with Twilight. \nReliable.\n\nWas that what she needed?\n\nWas that what she wanted?\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUhh\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow\xe2\x80\x99s voice still wavered, huskier than usual, the immersion in emotion taking its toll on her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6I need to go and think, Applejack.\xe2\x80\x9d\n    \nRainbow looked back towards Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s gaze, once more. Her green eyes were no longer just clouded. The clouds had burst, and begun to leak; two lines traced across the freckles that pockmarked her face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re always moving, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you? Why can\xe2\x80\x99t you just slow down?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nApplejack sounded hurt. It was as if she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t trying to hide it now, her honesty shining bright, even when shrouded in upset.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you about it properly, Applejack\xe2\x80\xa6 but another time. \xe2\x80\x9c\n\nRainbow hated having to shirk such an important talk off, especially in one of the few times the two of them would normally so desperately strive to have. \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI just need to sort my head out.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh can see that, Dash.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow passed an unhappy smile Applejack\xe2\x80\x99s way. She knew she needed to sort it out, but the words Applejack had fed back had hurt. \nBut Rainbow knew she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it. \nShe was the element of honesty.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to you as soon as I\xe2\x80\x99ve worked it out\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow\xe2\x80\x99s words faltered, momentarily, and a thought lapsed up; \xe2\x80\x98Was that really the best thing to say?\xe2\x80\x99\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow felt her chest tighten.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRainbow stood up, rather more quickly than she meant to, and with the biggest  trace of a reassuring smile as she could muster, she turned away from  Applejack, and began the decent from Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s hill, step by step, down between the apple trees, letting their swaying branches\xe2\x80\x99 sounds engulf her once more.\n\nRainbow Dash just didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to fly.', 'epub': None}
